text: Staffing shortages and cut backs are taking their toll on the service, making contact ( us will your staff) difficult- particular over the phone, when email access is difficult and off putting for me.

#
Staff very friendly always there if needed very helpful patient I would stay here again no complaints very good food recommend this hospital
'Cos it is good, they helped me and you have helped me'.

* As someone who prefers face-to-face appointments, I thought it was disappointing that only my first appointment was face-to-face. I was told all subsequent appointments had to be either a phone call, or via a video call providing I was happy for my appointment to be recorded and used for training purposes, which I wasn't.

* During my first phone appointment I explained that I really didn't find the online questionnaire useful and would prefer not to do it and was told I had to. I felt Talking Therapies was too structured and regimented and there was very little flexibility. The sessions revolved around questionnaires and worksheets which felt like completing homework.

* After only a couple of appointments my therapist went off sick for a couple of months. Whilst this is totally understandable, I feel I should have been offered another therapist rather than having no-one.

* When my therapist did return, I received a rather rude email saying she was back and had been trying to contact me, and if I didn't repsond I would be removed from Talking Therapies. I checked and I'd only received one phone call earlier that morning from a private number and no message, so I had no way to know who called me and was unable to respond. The message felt rather abrupt and made it sound like I'd been ignoring her, which I hadn't.

* Give use more preparation to what to bring to the appointment.
* have patience.
* Give treatment plan.

*1. Husband had to wait down for more than 3 hours and was not shared my room details or my whereabouts, even though I needed him to be with me. 

2. Shared and handed over all my prescription medicines to the pharmacist, but throughout my stay my regular medication was not given to me even once. 

3. Nurses were very nice to talk to but that's that. Nurse Michelle was too busy to even get me from the recovery room where i had to wait for her for more than 2 hours, after many reminders from the recovery room nurse, she send someone else to get me; my call remote was kept far; bed alarm didn't work; lost my dignity while trying to go to the toilet after surgery and had an accident; nurses telling me to raise my arms even though i am not supposed to raise my arms for 3 months; no communication between the nurses on duty, every time i had to explain what my surgery details are and what i can do & what not; my husband was quoted approx £200 for his stay or more if he choose to stay with me; I was in tears to get any pain medication; No nurse came for helping with personal hygiene as well.  

4. Doctor on duty, well, i met with Dr George at around 1:30 pm where I was quoted that they forgot about me! I told him he is not the only one!! Throughout my stay that's the only time i met a doctor after surgery.

5. No cleaning of the room or toilets. for the first time in my life i got a UTI and fluid on the site of surgery. I am currently on strong antibiotics. I am a sepsis survivor and have a week immunity and with the lack of any cleaning there, this is ought to happen. 

6.This is a NEW hospital, but not a very well organised hospital. Having no parking on site is a joke as well. I have never in my life seen a hospital where there is no parking, Cleveland hospital is the first!

- Answered my questions.
- Gave you information you wanted to know.
- Fatigue advice.

- Back to activity sessions were really good.
- Tailored to individual need.

- Be welcoming (the reception staff are very welcoming)
- Listen actively
- Show empathy
- Have sensitivity
- Routinely offer to send a record of recommended exercises by email
- Explain fully why further appointments are not necessary (and if it's about funding/resources, be honest)

- Clinicians could be more compassionate when people are visually distressed. 

- As someone who hasn't been with mental health services before, I was taken aback by how little the clinicians cared about my safety in that moment of crisis.

- Good reception.  It made me feel welcome and comfortable.
-  Good engagement with Consultant.  He was very professional, Good listening and respectful towards me.  It made me feel relaxed to talk.  I had time to express my needs to him.
- I cannot fault my fantastic consultant who was kind, professional and clear. appointment was able to take place earlier than scheduled which is good.

- I feel on first session, an introduction could be given explaining the aim of the programme and what to expect.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Instead of going straight into the warm up.
- an information session on different benefits that we could be entitled to would be good.

- I think the reception staff probably need more training. They were slightly slow and didn’t seem completely focused 

- I think it would also be nice to have a selection of refreshments available for patients in the waiting room. If there were any I didn’t see them 

- I’ve found appointment arrangements a bit scatty and confusing - my appointment got shifted to another site with not that much notice

- Listened to me
- Not tried to palm me off to another service unnecessarily 
- Responding to my GP would have been helpful, instead of ignoring them for months
- Dropping me from therapy after 3 sessions is a complete joke
- A rather pathetic discharge letter, the contents of which are very much the opposite of the truth, which is utmost disappointing 
- I was made to feel like a complete inconvenience to everyone I spoke to
- No regard for the difficulty of in- person attendance due to my full time job, of which is of a hugely sensitive nature and importance to victims of serious criminal offences, including last minute court appearances (I was made to feel like I was making excuses). But I take my job seriously and I don’t think this was even slightly acknowledged.

- Need more staff on the wweekend and doctor at the night shift.
- Change the halal meal so it's had the same everyday.
- Give [name removed] patient communication skills and do not leave here alone talking to a patient again.

- Not be Judgemental
- Communicate in a more understanding manner
- Actually listen to me in appointments and address my needs

- Nurse was very nice and kind to my daughter.
- Knew what was wrong and how to help.

- Simone was very gentle; it was the best blood test I have ever had!
- Dr Joan was wonderful and very thorough

- The curtains in the room are very annoying as you can't control the opening One of the curtains out of its total. I want you to open them all To shut them all off. - The level of professional nurses is much lower than required One of the nurses does not wear protective medical gloves when I start treatment and take medical readings Another nurse cannot control his hand in a unique way when taking a blood sample to check for sugar. Every time his hand trembles and he is unable to take the sample from the first time  - The level of catering service does not match the hospital's reputation As almost every pill order, there is a lack of the required contents, which affects the quality of the food that will be eaten

- The diet advice could have been issued as hand-outs - did not take A/C of current research eg value and context of breakfast.
- Tell participants why doing particular exercises.

- improve the admission process, it was extremely stressful for both my partner and I to wait more than 10 hours to be taken to theatre
- improve the communication about what was happening on admission day - different stories from different members of staff
- listened to well.

- not be accused of failing to attend a session
- being able to receive therapy at a suitable time (my last one was very rushed in a hot car in a car park as there wasn’t another time available)
- not being rushed; my mum had just passed away and my daughter had been assaulted, but these events were brushed aside
- have a therapist who cares and is not just focused on rushing through a set of questions when somebody is clearly in a lot of distress

-Location in London is easily accessible
- reception staff throughout very helpful
- clean environment
- minimal waiting times
- polite staff
- appointment with Dr Haidry himself was exceptional

-My period of care was quite short, I feel like I never get support long enough to be able to get into a place where a crisis won't happen again. 
-There isn't any follow-up care after discharge.
. I was treated with compassion, kindness, respect and empathy. I have had a lot of treatment in the private sector and this experience has been the best by far.
1) As ECG was taken, should have improved the patient to not apply moisture.

1) Didn't get many details about the actual procedure pre-visit - what to do or not do afterwards etc.
2) See above para.

1) On booking the appointment with Professor PS I informed his secretary, at her request, that needed advice on incontinence. When I met Professor PS he told me that he did not give advice on that, and referred me to a colleague. So the appointment was a waste of my time and his.
2) No one said anything about the cost of my visit. I raised this with Prof PS, who said that was normal, since I am insured. However, that is not an acceptable answer. First, as I told Prof PS, I have a high excess on the policy, and, second, I may, in any event, choose not to go ahead with treatment. In either case, it would be me who would pay the cost of obtaining advice at the first consultation. Thirdly, I am the patient, not the insurance company, and so am entitled to be told the cost of the care that I am to receive. I note that one of the questions asked in this survey is whether the costs of the treatment were communicated to me: I infer that Prof PS was mistaken in saying that I should not expect that.

1) call patients back
2) assess them in a timely manner
3) psychiatrist assessments asap
4) 2 year waiting lists - really? Outrageous
5) talk to your colleagues, communicate
6) read the case notes
7) talk to the child and parent and listen
8) provide professional caring support for vulnerable patients
9) don’t fob off to other departments/colleagues or inappropriate services

1- I should’ve been attended by the person I was referred to .
2- Physiotherapy should involved atleast some physiotherapy. 
3- Trainees shouldn’t be allowed to attend a patient alone.

1- not interview me 
2- calm me down before asking questions 
3- inform me it’s an assessment 
4- don’t ask people why they are triggers when someone is in crisis
5- encourage service users to regulate and use skills 
6- actually read the care plan 
7- keep the person in crisis in the loop
8- don’t say your going to call then don’t
1-1 support instead of groups
1-2-1 more private for all.

1.  The staff who worked in the food department were extremely polite, yet, I experienced several miscommunications with them. 
Meals were missed and when I tried to explain I was diabetic they were confused and said my profile only listed I was allergic to crustaceans (!) yet I was hospitalized for severe hyperglycaemia due to diabetes.
Meals were either on time, delayed an hour or missed altogether - so several inconsistencies in the food chain of command.
2.  Discharge took a couple of hours.  I brought in medication of my own and the pharmacy misplaced it and then eventually found it. Getting future appointments, discharge summary and meds. took at least 2 hours.  A bit of hurry up and wait.

1. A first appointment should be face to face and within one hour of the stated time.
2. Doctors should have more empathy with their patients aware that patients may be frightened and overwhelmed in coping with new longterm serious conditions.
3. The waiting time for a first appointment is unacceptable ....
I had to give up my job because j could not cope with my symptoms! Also I got seriously low thinking some of my symptoms were due to severe stress and consequenyly I have been given mental health counselling (I may not have needed this if I had been diagnosed more promptly!)

1. After the blood test and the echo scan an assistant called me to ask if i was in the hospital immediately prior to my appointment with Dt Narbeh Melikian (who is excellent). I would not have had the prior tests if I was not present in the hospital.

2. No soap in the dispenser of a WC facility I used.

1. Although I had the visit planned for a few weeks, for an endoscopy, I did not receive any communication until the day before my visit - and this was only upon reaching out and pushing the topic. The time of the procedure was not communicated to me until the day before which caused many challenges including requesting the appropriate time off work, arranging childcare so my wife could collect me after the procedure, and travel logistics. To give patients a single day's notice to communicate the time of a procedure is very poor
2. Upon arrival, the receptionist could not initially find any record of my appointment. He eventually was able to, blaming the delay on 'the system'
3. I was not given a patient ID bracelet upon entrance. When I was brought into the endoscopy room, the entire team was unable to proceed until an ID was printed and brought to me. This didn't take very long, but still, it wasted the entire team's time, was inefficient, and indicative of questionable administrative practices. It is hard to quantify the cost of such a delay, but if it happens with any regularity, the financial impact would be appreciable

1. Cleaner upholstery on the couches within the premise.
2.  Clearer communication between nursing staff and patients over section 17 leave.
3.  Better administration of section 17 leave.
4.  Less sensitive alarm systems.
5.  Larger rooms beyond a months stay.

1. Dr. Ian Webb - fanatastic experience and felt super secure in his hands
2. Jessica Bivand - on the phone - super structured and precise.
3. Jezel (Day unit nurse) - compassionate, great listener, expert at her role, one of the best nurse experiences I've had.
4. Recovery nurse ( forget her name ) - compassionate, great listener, expert at her role, one of the best nurse experiences I've had.

Overall everyone involved (the angiogram team, the support nurses) were on extremely professional and caring. Very thankful to the day care unit, recovery nurses and the angiogram team.

1. Explain purpose of my admission to the community heat function (it was to super use my transmission to new drug but I thought that Brompton hospital was 'done' with me.
2. Get bloods forms out faster. 2-3 week phlebotomy window.

1. I called up to book an appointment and was told to email the referral letter which I did - 24 hours later had received no response so had to call up and chase. 
2. Received a response to the referral letter saying that it wasn't specific enough about where I needed the MRI. I challenged this (as the referral letter was specific) and then suddenly they changed their mind and sent me the registration email request (which included loads of typos and didn't even make sense). 
3. The next morning I receive an email saying that there is an appointment available that day at 1:30pm so I replied immediately confirming I will attend. Had no response until 1:20pm when I am almost at the clinic saying that appointment had been held for someone else and was no longer available. Incredibly frustrating. 
4. Was offered an appointment for Monday morning which I accepted, logged in to the portal and it says the appointment has been booked for Saturday so had to call up and get it sorted, next available appointment is the following Thursday - a week since I initially tried to book an MRI scan. 
5. Referred to as Mr in all emails, even though I am a Ms and this is how I filled out the registration form. 
6. Then had to wait 6 days for the imaging results to be sent to my physio, and these were only sent once I had chased (and called up numerous times with no answer). 
Whole experience has been totally unsatisfactory (apart from the MRI itself) and will not be using the Cleveland Clinic for any future appointments.

1. Improve handover procedures between nursing staff. 2. Joint feedback/handover session post-operation between consultant, physio, nurse, radiologist (relevant staff) - notes were sometimes vague contributing to conflict/confusion between staff. Also avoids need for patient to act as a ‘bridge’ between personnel, which can be unreliable particularly post-op 3. Little/no offering of mental health support that I was aware of (I was supported by partner but others are not so lucky) - a recognised point of contact to offer support could be important to some. 4. Offer pre-orders for food to better understand demand and prioritise orders. 5. Consistent use of day plan board by all care staff (maybe digitise via tv and mychart as an option?) - helps gives day structure and key to understanding plan of care from all contributing personnel. 6. Ensure patient has sufficient support after leaving the hospital - a questionnaire or discussion is essential (again im lucky to have partner support at home but others not so lucky) walking up and down few steps shouldn’t be the only criteria to ensure patient safety and independence at home.  Please note this should be seen as positive constructive feedback - I was overall very pleased with my experience.

1. Make sure all details are communicated as far in advance as possible. Chasing around 48 hours before just creates stress.  2. A nursing station on the ward would be helpful.  3. Set timescales and keep to them. Nursing team could be away for long periods of time and meant we were unaware of what happens next

1. More physio to actually rehabilitate me. I was taken to the level of getting in/out of bed and a few steps with a walking aid.
2. Some of the nurses were abrupt. Rude and made me afraid to ask for assistance.

1. See above - your staff could be significantly more polite and diplomatic when asking patients to settle their bills, given that such patients are not permitted past the Reception before they have done so.  2. See above - your staff should be better trained to give patients the correct information on the whereabouts of Consultants on your premises.

1. Some confusion about initial booking: 2 scans were required but were booked hours apart
2. MRI table extremely flat and uncomfortable for long position; are you sure some pillows couldn't have been used ?
3. In pre-booking, form on arrival and nurse interview I went THREE TIMES through the same quiz about metal objects etc. Obviously important, but you will get more thoughtful answers if you ask once.
4. Cleveland Clinic sends out too many, overlong questionnaires;

1. Support for College and Gp registration and... 
2. Gifts such as financial vouchers for continuing education and sports for a better mood or food and hygiene.

1. The nurses or doctors didn’t tell me how the surgery went afterwards, but they did tell me wife though. 

2, the food is unbeatable, and I am not fussy.

1. The telephone admission clerk called Anne may be better suited to cleaning due to her poor social and telephone skills.

2. The delay to my advised theatre slot was not communicated at all. As a disabled patient, I found this inconsiderate to the point of  rudeness, or at best arrogant.

3.The facilities are magnificent.

The staff, excluding consultants, whilst new, were knowledgable and helpful - and certainly tried their very best.

4. The consultant in my case gave the impression of always being in a hurry, which was probably the case, and has very poor case management skills.

5. The costs are not competitive and appear to be 'price gouging' when compared with  the costs of identical proceedures in other private hospitals in Geater London.
10 out if 10 for the service and help provided
100% efficiently a courtesy utterly professional service.

100% positive experience - [name removed] was so understanding and took into account my thoughts and feelings as well as my sons! We felt like we were involved in the process throughout rather than it just being ‘done to us’.

[name removed] made regular contact with myself to keep me up to date and was understanding when I had to reschedule. She was consistent in scheduling and attending  my sons appointments and he really looked forward to them. He really felt like he was listened to and the techniques and strategies he was taught have been invaluable. I know that my son will use them going forward and I feel confident that my husband and I understand what he has been taught and can help him if he needs support.
111 Should have said the walk in doesn't take appointments.
111 response time of 63 minutes is very disappointing

11th April - Admissions was incredibly unorganized for a private hospital. My 77 year old father was kept waiting in the reception for an hour+ with no information given and very basic instructions. I arrived at 6:45 for my appointment and was still not admitted at 07:50. 

The reception staff told us to wait at the chairs but no information was given at all. The single  admissions staff when they turned up were picking people up at random and not in order of arrival. This stressed my father as his surgery was booked in just under an hours time. 

In my view the communication was very poor during the admissions and could see no reason for the lack of coordination and the lateness of admissions. Unfortunately the admission service was disappointing considering it was self-paying procedure. Very disappointing and quite let down. 

Once on the ward on the fifth floor, the nurses were friendly, helpful and caring. They took time to care for my father before his surgery

Some highlights from time in the ward:

11 Apr - Kirie and Claudine were very attentive, friendly and helpful after surgery.
 Claudine took very good care of my father visiting every 10-15 mins and gave her full care and attention to my father. I was very impressed with support I saw. 

12th Apr - According to my father nurse Anita left him twice with a wet bed and only when he insisted something happened, she said she would ask Billy to change but on second occasionally she completely forgot.  Only when Billy came to do observations was this sorted.
One further occasional he had blood on his leg and she asked him to clean it himself. From observation she was keen to delegate work and not action anything herself. Charge Nurse Antonio was caring and had to step in to cover some of the behaviours.

14 Apr - Nurse Paolo was very patient providing care and consideration and helped with pain relief he was always at hand and spent an hour plus trying to clear blood clots using the irrigation. 

Sarah Wills Lee Urologist Nurse gave my father a lot of time and has a very caring nature. She provided exceptional care over the 4 days he was on the ward. I was also pleased with the outcome of the surgery conducted by Mr Nathan and he took time to visit me during my recovery. 

Overall the stay in the hospital was positive apart from the very unorganized admissions process and one day on the ward on 12 Apr.
15 min delay for waiting, but that can’t be helped.
1st class attention by everyone at the clinic.

1st class care from a fantastic team. Special thanks to Candy, Claire, Hayley and Jasmine. Nothing was too much trouble. Caring and compassionate throughout my stay, good treatment and no delays, even for medication and discharge
2 individual night staff were less than professional and  in my opinion they would benefit from extra training. Felt under staffed as delayed response in getting back with information

2 members for exercise felt too long made it fun.
Good communication.

2 of the reception staff where short tempered and bossy . When I asked them why they hadn’t put my NHS number in to the form they said ‘the form doesn’t have that option’ when clearly it was left blank on the registration form.

2 years earlier would have been good! We have had no community support since the nurses were unable to change the catheter at home. Eventually the urology nurses at Heatherwood intervened and made the request as my daughter is very capable. Once again possibly due to pressure on the NHS.
24PP and Mr Toby Colgate Stone are brilliant .
2hr long wait, but this is understandable as it is drop in and que system. Add a water dispenser, it gets hot in the waiting area.
30 minute consultation would have been sufficient. 45 minutes to long.
30min delay for appointment
4 hour wait time whist in pain.
4 sessions only a taste - a longer course would aid learning and motivation.

4 stars instead of 5 for information only because I understood very little about the test results, even what some of them were for. Of course it was good to see that most of them were in the green zone. A clear simple explanation would have been great.
6 hour wait.
6 week course was very informative and the accompanying book useful.
7:45am arrival but no one is seen until 9am.
8 sessions was received to 6 due to canullar illness on 2 sessions. The extra 2 would have helped tremendously I was not enough and we were starting to get to be solution.
9/10 professional, compassionate, caring, good listeners. They all went the extra mile right medication I am making a good recovery.
? Could have a better call out system and quite difficult to hear on a busy day.
A  bit more time. One and half hours was not quite sufficient.
A "one size fits all" approach is not working for me. I need to receive the care that is suitable for me and is going to fix my problems.
A 1st class service and excellent and friendly xray technician.
A 2 hour assessment for someone with memory issues is too long. It should be carried out in 2 parts and at home to help with anxiety.
A Very helpful and friendly person dealt with my care . She was wonderful
A You tube video of the exercises and breathing techniques would have been very extremely useful.
A basic level of care and understanding.
A because they were very kind.
A better and correct description of the medication prescribed. I was left confused.

A better online app for therapy sessions would have been helpful.  Time was wasted trying to get this to work. It was unfortunate that I couldn't have worked with her face-to-face.

My therapist was very good, and I would happily work with her again, but I felt that the way the therapy would be structured through the sessions wasn't explained clearly.  However, she was empathetic and sensitive - I'm glad I met her!
A better smell in the building

A better understanding of whether/which delays in waiting for scans/ treatments etc might or might not affect the outcome. Not knowing causes extra worrying.


Nevertheless, THANK YOU so much for everything.

A big thank you to the team that has taken an exceptional care of me during my OGD procedure on 1st September! Dr Murray, Joseph & Alana were ever so reassuring prior to my procedure! Vic, Amelia & Michael made sure I was welcomed with kindness and they were all very friendly to approach, checking in on me regularly. They have also given me enough time to recover before sending me home. I received very clear after care instructions verbally and on paper to take home.  The team has definitely proven there was no need to be anxious. Exceptional care!!
A big thank you. Your help really eased my time passing through the stages.
A bigger room.
A bit difficult to get hold of.
A bit longer than six weeks.
A bit longer time wise
A bit more explanation could have been given. But that's only because I struggle with communication.
A bit more info post op about the operation,l did not see a x ray or have a good talk to the doctors about it.
A bit more notice might have been given
A bit more personal rather than the information being provided to be generic
A bit more sympathetic to my issues

A blood test to be checked on the spot could have been better as I went there for chest pain. I was high BP too.
A brief overview of your expectations from us.

A brilliant service. I was really apprehensive about joining the group at first but I am so glad I did. Not only was the sessions informative but the staff made them fun. We managed the heatwave by taking longer breaks between exercises or they were made easier on these sessions. Would I attend again if I needed too YES without any doubt.
A caregiver called Paz was exceptional.
A cleaner with trolley used same lift as us.
A combination of the procedure going to plan and everyone I met was professional, friendly and accommodating.
A comprehensive check with very good explanations.

A constant barrage of information is asked for pre admission which the staff seemed unable to access ie medication and medical history despite you sending me confirmation you already had it. Twice my medication was recorded incorrectly.
A copy of the outcome letter from consultant need to be chased for.
A couple of the staff were very quietly and softly spoken resulting in information being missed at times.

A couple of things: Billing - I paid a certain amount of my excess over the phone and was told I would receive a receipt by email which I have not yet received. Still unclear as to how my payments work.
Post discharge notes: These listed that there would be a follow up with my surgeon on 17th (I assumed by phone as I had my follow up face to face appointment on 21st) however this didn't happen. I understood why as I knew he was away on holiday until 17th but it was confusing and I had to contact his secretary to check that I wouldn't hear results until my follow up appointment on 21st.

A couple of very minor points:
1. Your computer systems seem to be disconnected. On my first visit some tests were done. When I was invited for pre-operation assessment I was asked questions which were already available from the earlier visit. It is this reason why I have given my observation.
2. Results of all my tests were available separately in MyChart. However there is no option to have a single .pdf file with all tests in it. This could be something your IT people could look into.  
3. In your survey you ask me to review the Doctors but the Doctor who attended to me is not directly employed by CCLH but an independent consultant. Why do you not seek a review for such consultants?

A couple of visits ago I witnessed a patient struggling with one of the inner fire doors to the waiting room.   Between her age, the fire door and wrangling crutches she couldn't get into the waiting room without assistance.

I mentioned it to [name removed] and the receptionist
A course on understanding/coping with narcissistic individuals.
A cup of coffee would have been nice.
A cup of tea would have been nice. More time for discussion/questions – 2 hours was too short.
A direct phone line

A doctor  that listens , face to face if not had that a long time especially when trying to establish if has adhd ! 

Taken seriously about the issues they having

A doctor who actually listens to me and actually cares about what I say.

Look through my notes and understand my history so they know how to treat me. 

The team actually taking the time to talk to me.
A fantastic hospital with super stall and caring

A few issues: (1) one member of staff (black ethnicity; female; dark blue uniform) was extremely rude, would not communicate and she felt highly discriminatory - she needs serious unconscious bias, diversity, and effective communication training (and otherwise suspended from her post in the interim); (2) the nurses try very hard, but some were clearly ‘bodies’ and lacked substance, and this was clear when follow-ups were not dealt with and it frustrated the more substantive nurses; (3) on discharge, I was told for 4.5 hours to wait on the doctor, only for the doctor not to bother turning up and I was told I could leave without the doctor (or anything having been explained to me) - this was quite honestly the most shocking part of the care - the staff kept asking me if I had been seen and it was always a no and they were confused as to why. My operation was three days ago and I have still not had a follow-up appointment scheduled with the surgeon (Senthil Nathan) which I was told to expect since he had done the surgery (this is separate from my appointment with Ramesh). 

On a positive note, the check-in was very good, there were a couple of nurses who were amazing, the overnight team was great, the anaesthetic team were so incredible with my first-time surgery nerves, and both surgeons were fantastic when I spoke with them, in particular Ramesh who had been in touch throughout the weekend before surgery and evidently cares for his patients very much, without an ounce of judgement. Both surgeons seem very special! The organisation around them is a little lacking though.
A few members of staff have quieter communication styles, maybe not knocking before entering the room, not introducing themselves or turning the lights on in the middle of the night.
A few more regular visits would have enabled me to make better faster progress.
A few more sessions please, but I'm ok for now, I think
A few more sessions please, but I'm ok for now, I think. Even of the additional sessions were remote, it would be an improvement
A few of the night nurses should be less impatient and unkind to frail less able patients.

A few points:

1. Time from GP to community mental health was very long - about 6 months, during which time other delaying services (such as MRi scan) could have been scheduled. Care operating in sequential blocks with no information passed from one stage to the next until it had completed is very in-efficient in overall terms and does not allow optimisations to take place. The oft stated response that "this is how it is done in the NHS" have become wearing. If IT or construction projects operated in this way we would still be in the third world. It has nothing to do with funding but does have to do with thinking and organisation.

2. MRi scan process. There are two points to bring out here. The first is that the service is very variable across the Berkshire trust. I was faced with a long wait before the scan which I challenged and manage to get earlier than expected date. The delay between scan and results is even worse being about 3 months. My wife had an MRI scan in Reading which was booked on a saturday, took place early the next day (Sunday) with results provided by Sunday lunchtime. This was the same trust. The second point is that when the scan process was started, I was in contact with the MRI unit in Andover, which was free at the time and could have scanned me within an hour. Unfortunately the NHS trust model, which strongly points out that this is not a national health service but a set of independent parallel inefficient organisations, could not make use of this "national" resource and would require going back 6 months to the GP stage and starting from scratch. I was therefore trapped into an inefficient system. The MRI scans are merely files that could be transferred from Andover to Thatcham securely, but this is not how the NHS works - in fact it fights against these optimisations.

3. The diagnosis: It would be useful to have a little more information on the F067 outcome since this has several sub-classifications that have a potential statistical risk for future pathways and life expectancy. This increases stress levels because I have little information to direct study of the subject and remdial actions. I point out the obvious that short term memory loss does make it difficult to remember every detail of conversations and so is lost to the process. This is a general problem throughout the service from GP to consultant and not directed at any individual.

A first-rate medical practice, the doctors and nurses very caring and helpful, having successfully helped me over many years. It is easy and quick to contact the practice by telephone, soon answered and the AskmyGP works well, quickly answered. A better medical practice would be difficult to find. Highly recommended with my grateful thanks for many years of help
A folder so everyone has the same information or knowledge.
A follow up 1-2 months. Possibly for a combination of more than one cohort?
A follow up appointment would of been good before a discharge email
A follow up letter describing the outcome would be helpful - perhaps it is coming??
A friendly and caring experience.
A friendly and efficient service

A friendly and very inclusive person. Listened to me and my husband.
Timely and efficient.
A full 45 minute assessment perhaps?
A full assessment perhaps
A good all round course well delivered.
A good listener and very patient, she made the meeting lovely and pleasent.
A good understanding to my issue.

A great deal of care has been taken from the notification of appointments to the punctuality of the nurses and doctors.
We have been particularly grateful to Paul Maxwell for his informative consultants and detailed follow-up letters.
A great experience and (Dr) Mr Gilda is the best!

A great experience overall. Our health visitor was knowledgeable and answered all our concerns. She reaffirmed our efforts and also highlighted areas where we can improve.  The fact she could come and meet us at home was very helpful too.

We would genuinely like to thank her for the time and suggestions she left us with.
A great experience with the echocardiogram and the exercise ecg team
A health questionnaire maybe before the appointment
A high offered of personal attention and exercises designed for my practioner Parkinsons problems. PD group - Lucy.

A highly efficient organisation with top class medical practitioners.  Mr. Perry was outstanding in diagnosing my neurological problem (where others had mis-diagnosed) and explained what action was required in clear and concise terms.  He engenders great confidence which is extremely comforting.
A ingle point follow up is necessary. After my CT scan, someone should’ve commentated with me to tell me what the findings were and what’s the next action required.
A junior doctor treated me with respect.

A lady come to see me, I think her name is Lisa. She was really understanding and seemed caring. She said she would work with me, it made me feel like I can overcome some of the issues I am struggling to deal with. But I know she has a lot on her caseload so I won't see much of her.
A link to a Web page that had all the helpful information that the TV screen and walls had.
A list of exercises would be useful.
A little bit more specific when prepping for ecg, as i didn't expect the bike and the body shaving was a little excessive
A little children play area for children to busy themselves while waiting as the environment gets very busy and you can’t hear staff calling names.
A little delay on arrival but once I was taken to my room the care was exemplary. Very nice and understanding staff at every point. All in all excellent.

A little information about the availability of spaces available as I rang previously and had been told spaces were available. I also wasn't made aware of triage appointments with nurses are available at 12:30.
A little more explanation could help
A little more explanation on how to book on line. The site appears to say appointments up to 24 hours in advance when they can be up to 48 hours.
A little more flexible on timings as we ran out of time. As a detail focused person I wasn't able to sufficiently explore my challenging symptoms yet.

A little more information to us while waiting for our appointment, as to why the delay and how long to wait, would have helped.
   Also, I understand as a private patient, but the fees are too high for a simple follow-up.
A little more physiotherapy.
A little more time spent with me.
A little more time when surgery was not busy
A little more time would be beneficial
A little quicker maybe, but I know how the services are overstretched and completely under resourced.  I am a firm believer in ‘prevention rather than cure’.

A long time to receive results, I only got them when visiting again. Results text is sometimes vague. Have online information of which days are only for peace of mind/with symptoms exams. Send precise email listing, which exams came out negative, or let me opt in to receive it like that.
A long wait!
A longer appointment.
A longer course or an additional in-depth course - very thought provoking and interesting.
A longer period of sessions. Six were not enough.
A longer period of sessions. these sessions need to be in person

A lot of being left. We had to wait a long time after the procedure to get any food having not eaten all day. . Had to ask several times and it was awful. Tomato soup was not as expected and inedible. 
Our nurse Jes was lovely and very caring. 
I did have to go and ask for help with a few things during my husbands short stay. I didn’t feel the private experience was really up to the mark.but getting an earlier diagnosis was key for us.
A lot of care
A lot of different people covering different things.
A lot of help, very respectful and made me feel valued
A lot of information came at me very fast. Because of my condition it would have helped if the lady slowed down with the information so I could take it in.
A lot of information not known to me.
A lot of information to take in so may be an improvement could be done in that.
A lot of information to take in.
A lot of people at once was a little tedious stopping for questions and going through each individuals needs waiting for your turn near the end.

A lot of repetition of questions I had already answered 
But do understand why
A lot of the staff were really nice.
A lot of useful information.
A lot was explained about my condition and the staff were very friendly and helpful.
A lovely clean clinic in a good location with a warm welcome. The team at the door were excellent.
A lovely welcome and kind members of staff.
A manual sign in service so relatives know which carers have been in
A member of staff spoke inappropriately about other patients when alone with me. I was upset by his comments.

A mixed ward and different age range. 
More male then female staff.

 Age range 18-65 in my opinion is a large age range. The ward worked well in 2013 when the patients were mixed. 
Some women feel more safe with men rather than women. The use of restraining is appealing. There is no dignity. Other then that Dr igae is a brilliant consultation and I respect him implicitly.

A more compact team of carers
Greater comms re why my procedure was delayed by nearly 2 hours
A more detailed breakdown of the expected cost would have been appreciated.
A more personal intro with a little less info
A more personalised experience.
A more suitable room with enough chairs for everyone.
A most impressive hospital, spotlessly clean, quiet and all the staff were fantastic.
A most impressive hospital, spotlessly clean, quiet, comfortable and all the staff were fantastic. The best experience I have had being in hospital.
A much shorter waiting time.
A new bed and cushion to help my back and my sores

A number of things I just thought were part of growing old were explained as part of COPD and what I could do about them. The course improve my physical strength and gave me the incentive to continue that physical improvement when it finished.
A nurse held my hand through the whole process then checked up on me after

A nurse named Hamjar (apologies for misspelled name) who was working on Sunday afternoon, went above and beyond in his care for me and my husband. He was kind, empathetic and listened and understood our situation and tried everything in his power for ages to get me into a safe space.
He is a credit to this unit and I hope others who are distraught with hopelessness see his kind ,lovely face and manner.
Thank you so much Hamjar, you have restored my faith a little, I was lucky to meet you .
Best wishes
Nadine Rickaby
A nurse visited every time we rang for assistance. Every nurse was kind and helpful.
A phone number to respond and ask any questions
A pleasant nurse called me for pre-surgery assessment, but did not have a great deal of knowledge re my proposed procedure..
A positive, receptive and professional approach. Wat you do and achieve is superb.

A printed out exercise sheet to work from as the emailed information is very in-depth and good but too small for me to print off and use effectively though much better than the initial videos on the first course .
A professional atmosphere with warm and friendly people
A professional in our corner who understands what we are going through.

A prominent reason I moved my care recently to Cleveland Clinic London (CCL) was in the knowledge that Cleveland Clinic US (CCUS) is a world class provider of healthcare, as well as known for its research. Last summer, I had engaged CCUS for a Virtual 2nd Opinion.  Since then, I have been disappointed in the lack of a reasonable link between CCL and CCUS.  For example, documents and scans provided to CCUS from me here in the UK for the 2nd opinion were initially not made available to CCL. In addition, there seems to be little if any link between CCL-based healthcare providers and their US counterparts. Also, I do not believe CCL is adequately "plugged in" to what research and advances are being undertaken at CCUS.  I assume my healthcare provider would benefit from such an association. But at the moment, it seems as if CCL and CCUS are at variance with each other, rather than being complimentary.
A quicker appointment.

A really pleasant practice visit and I felt very well looked after. The facilities are in a great shape and look very inviting. I particularly liked how well coordinated the various teams and individuals were during my short stay. Thank you so much!
A really wonderful experience. Thank you. Perfect from arrival to discharge. Attentive, friendly, amazing and calm surroundings. A faultless few hours with you.

A referral was made to children’s services which is fine however this should have been communicated to me. They have closed the case immediately but as I wasn’t expecting the call this caused immediate low mood. Although it’s not easy to tell someone a referral will be made it should still be communicated. I was also told I would have an appointment with a psychiatrist and it was actually a mental health nurse at st Micheal’s that also threw me when I arrived.
A reminder of the video link the day before
A safe space to question and learn. Informative and well delivered.
A sample of a fill in routine sheet.
A scan would have told us the cause of the problem.
A second opinion would be welcome.

A second short tea break?   

Sign with directions at the entrance to the building.
A session or part specific to my injury.
A short break if time permits.
A shortcut to a mental health assessment
A shorter time span from start to finish.
A shorter waiting list as some are more urgent than othwts
A sign on main door to say it only opens at 8:30 am.
A slightly quicker response to the call bell on occasions
A smile is good for everyone
A social media group such as fbook so people can reconnect after course if they feel like it.
A staff with listening ears would have been great. As well as continuity as opposed to an assessment then being left high and dry with no support. It’s appalling honestly.

A stunning hospital with wonderful professional helpful staff throughout the whole process
An obvious attention throughout to respect dignity and kindness

A text with my latest PSA test result saves everyone’s time. What it doesn’t do is tell me if the result is good/bad, normal or not. i.e. I don’t know what the result means compared to previous results.
A therapist should have a number the client can call and engage gently a two way conversation instead of just following the script
A time for the waiting.

A very attentive approach made by all care givers. 

Recovery team excelled in their care of me during the difficult process of coming round. 

Ward nurses were excellent too 
Had no problem in getting may questions answered or anything I needed.
A very good all-round professional service
A very good and informative experience
A very good over all experience from start to finish. Excellent welcome and very knowledgeable consultant who provided the best course of care.
A very good service and very helpful service providers.

A very good service, to listening, structure tasks and information provided which I have not received before.  

The booklet I received I will go through this week.

In relation to health below, had primary breast cancer 2019, now 0% and being checked for epilepsy in November 2023. Also Osteoarthritis.
A very kind physio who has helped me deal with my pain even if not able to resolve them.
A very kind, helpful and patient lady who came to do the assessment. Made to feel very at ease.
A very nice young lady.
A very organised group of medical & admin staff
A very pleasant experience with pleasant atmosphere and staff. Adequate parking is available too.

A very pleasant/successful appointment with charming efficient medical staff.

Better still the injection I was given is now (one day later) alleviating the previous pain.
A very polite and informative medical person.
A very professional and well organised course with everything we wanted to be made aware of was fully explained in a way that was easy to understand.
A very professional service from start to finish, no complaints!
A very quick, clean, polite, efficient visit
A very reasonable waiting time and a very clean environment.

A very well structured 2 Day course and Tracy was very clear and made what sometimes seems a struggle for me a lot more clearer and manageable. I am now putting allot of what I learnt into practice. Thank you ver much.
A warm, friendly and relaxed environment. My consultant is kind and professional and listens in a compassionate way. The check in desk staff were smiling and helpful as always.
A way of contacting my social worker would have been good as I had to go through my GP
A weekly maintainance meeting would have been beneficial
A welcome at the clinic - it's weird sitting in an empty waiting room not knowing if they know you have arrived.

A wonderful clinic , superbly run . A totally patient-focused mind-set and system of working.The availability of world -leading consultants in their respective fields ( such as Mr S Nathan in urology) makes the Cleveland  utterly unique in the UK and woukd venture to say in Europe. .
A wonderful service from start to finish with a team of incredibly compassionate and knowledgeable caregivers
A worry free experience in comfortable surroundings, confident and professional attention

Abi in dietetics was brillant , gave me encouragement and support for my treatment plan. Abi listened and showed genuine empathy and concern for my condition.  Her guidance was spot on and delivered  in a clear, professional manner  and any questions I had she answered well
Ability to book appointments in advance.
Abingdon was convenient, parking good, waiting time not too long
Able to access services provided. Staff were informative, kind and I thank them all for being so helpful.
Able to focus on my current plans for the future. Lots of reassurance given by the HTT.
Able to have insight of my current symptoms, signposted me to CMHS. Mood increased since input from HTT.
Able to respond, referring me to GP for review and other services.
Able to talk me through my current steps and options.
Able to talk to HTT with my current stressors. Now able to contact further support and focus on the future, many thanks.
Able to understand myself and my feelings.

About 2 hours into waiting I became anxious. This is because I have some sensory processing needs. I asked the lady at reception (Ann) if there was anything that could be done and she very quickly pointed me to a quiet space around the corner. Was pleasantly surprised!- Thanks.

Above and beyond care and compassion was really noticeable from my very first outpatient appointment right through to being carefully portered downstairs in a wheelchair to the car to go home. I felt listened to and valued and my anxieties where not overlooked.
Above: I do think more communication about delays or not as the case may be could have been better. I was told many times, it wont be long now and it really was ...
Absolutely a nice person and supported me.

Absolutely amazing care from a dedicated, wonderful team. We feel completely supported in our scary new Type 1 world. I can't imagine (and don't want to imagine!) trying to navigate Type 1 without their help and support. I cannot praise them enough.
Absolutely amazing team. So accommodating to our needs as a family and the care given was fantastic.
Absolutely brilliant care from Tony & Matt
Absolutely brilliant,  no complaints,   staff were excellent.  Even better than the doctors surgery!!
Absolutely brilliant. Gives me confidence.

Absolutely brilliant. This was my first procedure for 47 years and I was incredibly nervous. The team knew of my phobia with BP readings after I briefed Alex Woollard. It was all handled with incredible sensitivity and just gave me the necessary reassurance that it would all be ok…the level of professionalism was very impressive

Absolutely fantastic - brilliant care from admission to discharge with regular check ups. My consultant and anaesthetist were unparalleled and I am so grateful for their time and assistance during a difficult and painful time.
Absolutely fantastic service providing me with lots of encouragement and support and giving me information and practical advice.
Absolutely first class care from minute of arrival to min I left
Absolutely horrendous treatment from Tony and all the other staff members. There are no words to describe my pain.

Absolutely incredible hospital facility with outstanding levels of care. From my consultant cardiologist to the person who took me to X-ray, everyone professional, compassionate and understanding. Having come from an NHS hospital where I had been wrongly diagnosed, left in a corridor overnight next to the lavatories, I literally wept with relief when I got into my room.
Absolutely nothing.

Absolutely outstanding - best care I’ve ever received. Thanks to all the nurses on the fifth floor particularly Angela and Anjelica. I’m only sorry I couldn’t do the food better justice - it was really good but my appetite had gone post surgery. Really don’t have anything negative to say about my experience - it really felt world class.
Absolutely outstanding care from start to finish - everyone I met was truly kind and delightful.  I can't thank them enough.
Absolutely professional in every way.  Timely treatment and excellent joined up care pathways from admission through treatment to dispensed drugs and departure.

Absolutely wonderful care from start to finish. Nurses, HCA's and Consultants all gave the highest degree of care throughout my stay ensuring I was comfortable and pain free. The food and beverage choices were healthy and extremely tasty. Clearly good team work.
Accept the care given.
Acceptional care and staff and good food delivered at regular times each day
Access to physio not as straightforward as pre-COVID.
Access to podiatry (too long a wait).
Access to previous MRI would have helped.  Fortunately I had my report from previous IPASS examinations with me.
Accommodating to the child's needs.
According to my child , he needs frequent and regular visits to make his progress more beneficial for him to be more independent .
Active listening.
Active referral to someone who could help. Following through on sending information on where to get help from

Actively communicate with patients, especially if the therapist is the one to cancel an appointment it should not be down to the patient to then rebook. When I had to cancel an appointment I was always told the therapist would contact me to reschedule and this never happened so it feels like you’re being lied to or it’s just very disorganised.
Actually being given clearer instructions of how to reach the clinic would be helpful. It is not called hut 57 but it has a name and a car park. A map would ve very helpful

Actually care.
- Do what they say

Actually cared and offered me an alternative- CBT is not the only therapy available
Actually contacting me woukd be a very good start!

Actually did what you were asked for.I was not llistened too it was a token exercise with a pre determined verdict of anxiety.I did not even get a second appointment but all the questions were from accrual
A script and every time I had an appointment the therapist was sick.No relevant questions were even asked and she did not know anything about me despite being referred by my GP.So I was given the runaround.
Actually do your job and be a DOCTOR
Actually get back to people. Leave a voice mail if phone not answered.
Actually getting the appointment booked was confusing and not very clear .
Actually given me an appointment with a counsellor after my inital wait and not put me back to the end of the list after four poxy breathing sessions.
Actually informed me about discharge
Actually listen
Actually listen to me and not dismiss me immediately
Actually listen to me, offer me a tissue as I was balling my eyes out, talking down to me etc.
Actually listen to what I have to say instead of just hearing what u want
Actually listen to what patients are saying and stop gaslighting patients!

Actually listened to me, or even my therapist. There isn’t enough space here to explain what you could have done better, I’d be more than happy to have a meeting with someone to explain in more detail.
Actually provided support and treatment, kept me informed about what you're doing, not make safety plans and other things without me

Actually read the messages from the people you are treating and respond in a way that makes them feel heard. Don’t send everyone down the CBT route and SilverCloud if it’s not appropriate for them. Actually talk to the people your trying to help.
Actually respond to folk when they enquire would be a start
Actually speak to peple

Actually try helping patients and Oh contact them instead of saying “oh we are just following a care plan” this care plan hasn’t been reviewed in over a year. Yet there has been massive changes in circumstances so how hasn’t it been changed??
Adapt the role of the sponsor to focus more on the impact of using the App on your current challenges, discuss more where you might struggle.
Add more weekend activities. Some staff (agency) don't attend to patient's needs and are often using phones and are disinterested in how the patients are doing.
Added me in communicating my needs to help me remain at work. Treated with kindness and dignity.

Address all of the identified negatives:
- Handover between shifts could have been better, especially between HCAs.
- On occasions, apparently poorly trained HCAs.

Adelaide explained all aspects really clearly and listened to the concerns that I had

Admin consistently is not easy at Cleveland. Could be improved drastically. 

Rest of the experience is lovely. Fantastic surgeons, doctors and nurses. Facility is very good.
Admin sadly lacking in any cohesion
Admin teams could do with better training in treating patients with some understanding and empathy.
Admin was not able to confirm crucial details of my procedure before arrival. Impossible to plan for work.

Admin, communication and infrastructure seems only workable if the fancy IT system is working. Seemed no one was thinking outside the box to make a situation better unless the system allowed you to do. I asked to speak with a manager when I was checked in, but no one came to
Speak with me in my entire stay. 
Admin is better at other private hospitals.

Administration is confusing. I seems they ate not in the same page. I was told I need to pay before I eas discharged by medics. Then I was discharged, then I was told I will be invoiced to pay online, and free to go, then as I am ready to go Someone came to male me pay before I go. I am very happy to oay but this is stressful
Administration staff through to the nursing and care staff were excellent

Admissions letter contains admission time and instructions on fasting before procedure, but does not record procedure time. This makes it harder to ensure that the instructions are met. Perhaps the admissions letter could record "earliest likely procedure time"?

Admissions: I was told to take a seat when I arrived and waited for half an hour before I complained about people arriving after me being served before me. The admissions clerk told me there was no system and she simply took the people closest to the front. You should have an automatic queuing system system activated when people arrive at the front desk or alternative (but working) system.

Food was generally adequate but would not rank as good. Too often it was only lukewarm.
Admitted me for few days
Advance and efficient notification of assessment Nurse visit. Nurse was extremely efficient, helpful and kind. Assessment duly completed successfully.
Advance information about the place and what could be expected would have been useful.
Advice and help.

Advice from 111 was confusing and had I followed it my daughter would not have been seen so quickly, it was only after I questioned further than she was offered an appointment and this was deemed necessary.
Advice given.
Advice more therapy

Advice on what I could do post op 
Eg exercising
Advise if number has changed/appointment is cancelled.
Advise the patient, on discharge from hospital, to keep a diary/journal focusing on physical and emotional experiences.
Advise what the cost of the treatment was going to be.
Advised pt at last visit that he was being discharged from caseload

After NHS op cancellations and no sign of a new op date, we decided to use our family savings to go private.  The surgeon's secretary has been faultless throughout and very helpful and efficient.  The pre op tests were done on Friday. The hospital is a very clinical environment with little signage which is a bit of a double edge sword as the subtely is welcome from a privacy perspective but from a practical perspective it is hard to know where to go/what to do etc.  It lacks a little 'warmth' in terms of the professional approach being almost business like as opposed to compassionate.  The staff doing the tests were kind and did their roles very quickly and efficiently which was great. We were seen swiftly and the nurses explained where we had to go and when we could leave.  The Nurse who performed the ECG was especially kind in that she showed us the admission rooms upstairs to help Mum see in advance of her op, where she might be and what the room might be like.  For a nervous patient this was especially welcome.

After a fall at Christmas, my 93 year old mother was placed under the care of our local Palliative care team at home, mostly Andy Harris and Kaye Riches, both of whom were exceptional with regards to their professionalism, knowledge of medical care, compassion shown to mum and the whole family and kindness and understanding at an extremely difficult time. I cared for my mum at home, but felt 100% supported by the palliative team, district nurses and our carers ProActive Medicare, not once did I feel afraid that there would be no one there to help if I needed them 24/7 and I had to call on their services many times, nothing was ever too much trouble. This team deserves an award for their absolute dedication to their work, their patients and their families. It is with great sadness that I have to say we lost our dear mum earlier this week, but I know in my heart that she was treated with dignity and the utmost care and respect right to the very end, we could have done no more, please please please pass on my thanks to these beautiful humans, they truly are amazing people.

After a wait of around three months, Holly Bruce called and explained the process and asked if I still needed help. I was initially a little unsure, but Holly was encouraging so I said yes. Holly also explained she was still training and asked if that would be a problem. It wasn’t.

Throughout my treatment, Holly has been kind, supportive and encouraging. She’s been extremely clear in what I need to do and how I should think about things in different and more constructive ways. This was backed up with resources and hand outs that she emailed me.

Holly was able to adapt really well to my changing needs and was happy to go off-plan if needed. She’d always ask me which order I’d like to go in these situations.

At no point was anything rushed, or missed. I feel that I’m in a far better place following my sessions with Holly, and I’m extremely grateful to have been referred to someone who is brilliant at their job. I’d be very happy for you to share my comments with Holly.
After a wait to be seen. The whole Lighthouse staff are lovely, caring & professional. It made our first visit a comfortable one.

After a while it become a nuisance to go out and explain again and again my situation.
A few times they would ask me a question and then would ask me again and again.

After an unpleasant experience at the Wellington Clinic for an ankle replacement (no problem with the surgery, which was excellent, but several nurses were very slow in providing pain relief which they had promised, the hospital was unable to provide a hot meal at 9pm when I awoke from surgery, the discharge pharmacy was very slow, and there was a general feeling of disconnection) I had a lovely experience at the Cleveland Clinic for a knee replacement. Everyone seemed highly competent and efficient. Technology was excellent (all obs readings input straight into a digital file, drugs protocol kept online so any changes were executed immediately). The good service seemed rooted in good management. For example, all nurses came to say hi when they came on shift. That's nice. Support staff, even cleaners, usually said hi as well. This really helps. The food was remarkable - perfectly cooked eggs royale each morning, one evening my lamb steak was pinkish inside, perfectly cooked. I've never enjoyed a hospital experience so much.

After my appointment I'm none the wiser and frankly far more confused than before.
I couldn't understand the consultant and kept having to ask him to repeat what he had just said.
He suggested a podcast to listen to and gave me some notes.
As the school and my results were different ( he said it's doubtful but then suggested something else which after looking up is actually a symptom not a diagnosis. 
So I'm not happy with my last appointment as I really don't understand exactly what was meant at all.
I'm thinking of getting a second opinion as I don't feel that the right questions were asked and I really don't think he really saw my son as he is a clever masker.

After my stroke I felt very vunerable and scared of what happens now.  The team were kind thoughtful and took into consideraton of my needs.  I felt safe and confident in my care able to ask questions and made to feel , that what I was feeling was perfectly normal after a stroke and everything takes time to right it self .
The team [name removed] and [name removed] were professional, approachable and I am incredibly grateful for  their care

After my stroke I felt very vunerable and scared of what happens now. The team were kind thoughtful and took into consideraton of my needs. I felt safe and confident in my care able to ask questions and made to feel , that what I was feeling was perfectly normal after a stroke and everything takes time to right it self .
The team [name removed] and [name removed] were professional, approachable and I am incredibly grateful for their care

After my treatment it appears that the ward were not aware of my overnight stay. Michael did everything he could to get me on to the ward, however I heard this being discussed on the phone numerous times and it appeared that the admissions process had some flaws. This left me in recovery for circa 2 hours before moving upstairs.

Also, I ordered dinner on the 5th floor at 6pm, this was arranged for delivery at 7.45pm which was the earliest slot available (which is fair enough), however the food did not arrive until c.9.15pm after the nurse had chased it several times for me.

After the care I had with another clinic .. This was truly a 10 Star treatment and most of all kindness and respect was given to me but also with all of the team for each other, there was great respect and thoughtfulness. 

It was a pleasure to be there for my 3 days of healthy wellness check up. 

Dr Helen Mitakidis is a very compassionate woman who showed great patience to me and I never felt rushed or an inconvenience to her. 
For the first time I left a health check up feeling healthy!!! My last provided had me feeling like I was a very sickly person. 
Thank you to all the staff for their kindness and care. 

Most Sincerely,
Sandra Williams 
Ireland

After the first day I was never asked if I needed help in getting washed, brushing my teeth & was never offered a shower or even shown how the shower worked.
No one came to make or straighten my bed & I had to ask for towels. I was completely left to my own devices.

The nurses were all very pleasant and friendly

After the initial consultation in 2019/2020. Diagnosed with mild COPD and later told it was not. I was then, in 2022 referred to the breathing physiotherapy department. I found they took more notice of me than the consultant.

After the scan I was left on my own to change into my clothes and I felt very faint but there was no-one there to speak to so I sat down and once I felt stronger I went to the waiting area to have some water and wait for my cab.  The waiting room had a dirty floor and the staff behind the desk were talking to each other and did not pay any attention to me. I opened my own water and was not asked if I was OK.
After visit a phone call would have helped not just a letter of discharge

After waiting 7 months for this assessment, booking half a day off work and preparing my anxious 8 year old son about this meeting, It was an utter waste of time. 
- video call didn’t work properly so it ended up being a phone call 
- [name removed] the therapist didn’t at any point acknowledge my son 
- I was asked questions that were clearly already on paper work but nobody had bothered to read this before the call 
- at no point was my son involved or spoken to 
- the call was over in 14 minutes 
- the advise, I literally could have read off the internet.
Aftercare
Aftercare off met to make possible, in long term outpatients care.
Again the only thing to be done better was the initial waiting time after my assessment
Again, Dr Sporton was really helpful and clear.

Again, the clinical care was top class - the radiographer in particular was outstanding in terms of how she delivered the clinical care and how helpful and understanding she was in helping with my mobility due to the condition for which I am being treated. She as absolutely top class!
Agency staff need the same level of training as regular staff or learn to listen to the person they are treating

Aghogho is fantastic to understand.

All I do is come to these pointless meetings with johnson   He tells me “life is good and I have to have a positive outlook on life” 
He books these appointments KNOWING I loose 3 hours of my working day. 
He calls me knowing it’s the middle of my working day. 

I ask when will I get ACTUAL therapy. And he tells me I have to be patient and “NEXT” meeting he will refer me for counselling 

Everytime he calls me he THREATENS to discharge me if I don’t do as he says. Come to the appointments he sets me that I have no choice over. Just to hear a “god is great follow the lord” speech. God will heal you if you have a positive outlook. 

He doesn’t listen to what I say.  Every time me makes me recount the same reasons as to why I’m here and he writes it down. And treats me like it’s the first time we have met. 

He’s nearly always late. I’m always waiting for him. 

I’m considering discharging myself as this is causing me more distress than gain. I’ve had ZERO benefit so far. 
Zero treatment. 
And more than 30 threats of discharge

Absolutely lovely, kind and informative.  The surgical specialists and theatre 
Staff were friendly and relaxed and made the whole experience un-frightening 
And reassuring. 

However, your admin staff and systems ate worthy of Faulty Towers. 

I was phoned at lunchtime the day before the operation to be
Informed I needed to come in by 6.30 the next morning.  Luckily for me 
I had chased and chased a couple of weeks earlier to get this info.  System 
Wide the right hand does not know what the left hand is doing. 

When you arrive at Portland Place there are always three or so people 
Hanging about looking bored but you have to wait up to ten minutes to see
One of the two receptionists, even if you have already checked in and 
Paid online.  Why?  Why only two receptionists?  Why can't the 
Greeting staff see on their ipads that you are all ready to go up?

The secretarial staff seem to be on a wholly different planet.

The day before this procedure I had decided to find a new GP
Because I was so fed up with the hopelessness of the admin but
The wonderful experience at Grosvenor Place has pursued me to 
Give it one more chance. 

I suspect all the effort has gone into getting a world class medical 
Set up, less so the support systems.

All staff were superb.  Definitely the hospital's strongest asset.  And I mean all staff, from consultants through to cleaners.  Admin, catering, pharmacy, everyone.  Well trained, pateinet-friendly and a credit to the organisation.  I was comfortable and well cared for.  But 2 criticisms:
1.  My room looked beautiful, but was dysfunctional!  I was on the top floor in a corner room with a magnificent view out of 2 of the 3 windows, but face to face with an office full of people (in the building aross the road) in the other.  The only means of privacy was to close the blind in that window.  But all the blinds work together, so either I had to close all blinds on all windows and be without natural light or any outlook, or remain on display to the office workers.  Why on earth couldn't that window be frosted, like the bathroom window next to it?  Or have a blind that works independently.  None of the blinds could be partly closed - it was all or nothing.
The clock in the room is not visible from the bed or the patient's easy-chair.  The chair and its electric lead are something of an encumbrance or a trip-hazzard, getting in and out of the bathroom.  There are no hooks in the bathroom to hang your clothes/dressing gown.  Nowhere in the room to hang anything longer than a shirt, the securinty safe is at knee level and no drawer or shelf for belongings at a convenient level.
2.  Lack of communication between the consultant's team and the nursing team caused long delays.  I was informed that that the consultant who had performed my operation would visit me the next morning, to check me and advise if I could start taking liquids of food again.  I (and the nusinig staff) waited all day and until midday the following day until anyone from that team came.  That meant I remained without  food or drink for longer than was necesary.  I was only booked in for one night and had expected to be discharged the day following my operation.  I was not advised of the need to stay another night until quite late that day.  There does appear to be poor communication between doctors and nursing staff.  And the patient!

All staff were very polite and professional during my two recent visits, especially the nurse  who took care of me making me feel comfortable prior to the MRI scan as i was a little anxious. Thank you

Didn't ask how I was if I needed any help getting up from the machine, if I needed any assistance ect. They didn't seem bothered, they didn't care about me. Everything was very abrupt very unfriendly just took the equipment off and rushed out from the room without saying anything of asking if I needed any assistance or had any questions or what to expect next. All they told me was how to leave the building. Think they were just interested in getting rid of me. Was really unprofessional, and was the worst MRI experience I have had at any hospital. The worst experience of any MRI department at any private hospital or NHS hospital. I have had better experiences at the MRI department in an NHS Hospital than the experience I had during my MRI appointment experience at the Cleveland Clinic.

Although I had every confidence with the treatment I received from the trainee [name removed] , on reflection an actual visit from the supervisor now and again would have been good rather than being left on my own while he went away to discuss things with the supervisor.

Although I knew what drugs I was being prescribed and why, it wasn't clear when they would be available and they seemed to take ages to arrive. The meals were good, but not enough for me. food was delivred at similar times each day so we know what to expect

Although I was grateful to receive the CBT sessions from Talking Therapies, I would have liked to been offered 1:1 counseling to address my on-going mental health issues/past issues.

Also, it was convenient to receive online remote sessions, but my preference would be in-person sessions, to get the most out of the sessions with better body language etc and also be without the technology glitches.

Although I was kept waiting, when I saw Mr Powell he listened to everything I told him and was very pleasant and thorough. He offered to retry to remove a loose long term grommet that was causing discomfort and managed for which I was very grateful, and he explained the next steps and proposed a follow  up appointment. That was all very good. He prescribed ear drops but unfortunately I was given the wrong prescription. Fortunately I read it straight away and questioned it and the matter was quickly resolved. I don’t wish to complain, but it accounts for the comment in my notes.

Although Tony was very kind I am not totally sure he fully understood my predicament. 
Having said that, he had instigated contact with another organisation who have offered assistance. 
My confidence levels are extremely low and embarking on new ‘projects’ is mortifying. 
I’ve now been prescribed some antidepressants and hope this will help me going forward

Although a new hospital and obviously there were some teaching problems, all staff were supper friendly, courteous and very efficient
