Although challenging at first, due to my condition, my paranoia, psychosis and anxiety were dealt with swiftly, enabling me to recover very quickly. All staff have always been good to me, because I treat them with the respect they offer me. It was also challenging in the beginning because I had strong feelings of persecution from my home town when I arrived. The patients were very anti-lgbt+a (of which I identify with).

Although concerns resulted in a positive verbal response (as in the above) initially,  a couple of times nothing actually was done at all, as if I hadn’t raised the concern at all.
Ie - yes we will look into that. Actually, no we won’t.

Although every member of staff was extremely polite I found it very superficial , almost robotic. I needed an ultrasound scan of my abdomen and could not be fitted in for three hours. I thought this was too long to wait so I left without having it. I did try make another appointment, which was convenient for me, while I was there but there did not appear to be any appointments at 12 or 1 pm for many weeks to come. In the end I went home. I felt like the staff thought I was a nuisance for not accepting the appointments that were offered. Once I got home I rang to make the appointment for an ultrasound,. The person who answered the phone said it was booked for 2.30 that day. I explained I had just been to the outpatients and that the appointment had been cancelled as I could not wait that long. The person said let me check . They rang me back and said I have checked with the medical secretary and you have to keep the appointment today . I explained again the appointment had been cancelled and I was now at home. 
In the end another appointment was made for many weeks to come as yet again no appointments  for 12 or 1 pm. I have never had so much trouble booking any appointment for an ultrasound at a place or time of that was convenient for me.
Although it was near the end of their working day no-one rushed me and all seemed very willing to be helpful.
Although my appointment was delayed by 45 minutes, I was warned about the delay shortly after I arrived.

Although my care, when placed with the department was exempory. I found the process  of accessing the correct help hugeing frustrating, and at times impacted my recovery. More training  needs to be given to front line booking Staff. To streamline unnessary delays to get patients the correct treatment.

An amazing service from start to finish. Medical Secretary brilliant had all my records transferred from NHS super quickly so I didn't have the stress  dealing  with it myself, something I am very grateful for at moment.  Reception and clinic staff all fantastic too. I saw Professor Murphy . He was absolutely amazing and a super nice Gentleman too and really listened to our concerns and made us feel more positive tha anyone else we have seen yet..  appointment  was to get a second  opinion and he didn't rush us, made sure we asked all questions,  gave honest sound  opinions , and made us feel on right track. I can honestly say I felt a lot lighter leaving the clinic than I have in several months. We also scheduled a further follow up a week later via telephone as was recommended.  Consultant understood we had to travel a long way to go to appointment and was a nice touch he mentioned telephone discussion next. I also felt for first time I have talked with various doctors, he knew exactly what nature of problem was even as extremely rare presentation and made me feel less isolated and scared.  Had a very calm , confident, reassuring manner,but you felt you were definitely talking with someone who is top of the game and the relief that gave us was priceless. His honest  clear opinions were good to hear and anyone with complicated colorectal issue ,I would recommend Professor Murphy completely.  A thoroughly nice man and fantastic surgeon with a kindness and human touch that cannot be learnt. Top marks! Do not hesitate to book an appointment if its what's needed. The whole clinic is top notch, very caring , calm environment with thoroughly nice people there. Thank you.
An amazing service, from the very start. Contact almost as soon as I was home form hospital. Professional, reliable and wonderful people. Could not fault it.
An amazing team of caregivers in a great hospital.

An amazing top level service from - I was going to say the minute I walked in but, actually, before I’d even got through the door as I was asked if I needed help up the few steps to the door. A nice greeting from the guy closest to the door who took me over to the receptionist who was great. Offered a cup of tea/coffee/water. Seen on time, nurses and consultant were lovely, very professional. Even when I left the building and was waiting for my cab a member of staff stood with me til my cab arrived and escorted me to the cab and opened the cab door for me. An excellent tip-top service. Everyone treated me (and others I observed) like royalty! I’ve been a client at many private clinics/hospitals but this clinic was definitely the best of the lot. Well done Cleveland Clinic. I couldn’t recommend you highly enough!

Dealt with very well staff were very helpful.
Appointment letter i received had all relevant information for contacting service if unable to attend appt etc. Full details of clinic location with map excellent
Appointment on time and very thorough and professional
Appointment on time at place of choice. Clear explanation of condition and of treatment plan.
Appointment on time, lovely member of staff who communicated clearly throughout.
Appointment on time. Caring and helpful staff.

Appointment system was pretty chaotic. I received at least 3 calls from different people after I had booked my video consultation who were unaware of the appointment having been made. Taking my patient information over the phone took time and resulted in my name being incorrectly recorded . Too many emails then received reminding me of appointment

Appointment was easy to book and pay for and consultation was carried out on time. Very respectful Consultant who spoke to me with compasion and understanding. I wish that I could afford to receive the treatment that I need with him at Cleveland Clinic and not useless NHS.

Appointment was well organised from the start.

Professor Knowles was very knowledgeable and he had an approachable manner, he listened and genuinely cared and wanted to help and he put our daughter who is just 18years old at ease. 

We came away feeling confident that there is now a plan in place and we are feeling more hopeful after struggling with her care in the NHS for over 2 and a half years and in hindsight we wished we had come a lot earlier! Thank you Prof Knowles.  

Please note we did not have any communication with nurses.
Appointments every week. Someone for E to talk to.

Appointments where not forwarded to my personal email.

I had to contact the physiotherapy department by telephone  
Unfortunately my call was not answered
Appreciate the care.

Appreciate the pressures on the NHS But getting through on the phone takes time and getting a face to face appointment even longer, usually anything up to 6 weeks. Once you get through, the medical staff and GP's are excellent.
Appreciate the time and effort staff are putting in.
Approachable, kind and empathetic

Approachable.
Kind friendly good discussion.
Appropriate questions.

Appropriate room i.e. one that provides proper privacy without another unrelated health professional and family can hear everything that is going on. A qualified Health Visitor to conduct the reviews.

Appts times and dates, information should be consistent across the board as this varied from person to person.  Appts felt very rushed at times.
Listen to the family as they have full insight into all issues without them feeling blame for being strong. 
Parking permits should be provided without complaining.
Full notes should be handed over to the main manager,  as he was unaware my husband had hearing difficulties after getting a bad ear infection from covid even though this was said 3 times and date if his hearing aid fitting was supplied.

Are steroid injections still done? Those were dismissed too

Arrival and check in went well and organised. Continuous checks on my identity were carried out. Nurse care was  personal and efficient. Physio was great and the organising in order of discharge was good.
Arrive at the time requested on a regular basts.
Arrive on time so patients are not left outside in the cold

Arrived at 630am as requested. Left waiting at the reception desk with no one there for 15 minutes, then showed to a seat and another 20 minutes before I was checked in. All very friendly but why ask me to come in so early which was not easy. Am
Arrived at the department early for an x-ray and CT scan, I was seen for both procedures not long after arriving. Excellent, professional, friendly staff
Arrived punctually very easy to talk to gave very specific information many ideas to impact quality of life.
Arrived very quick, lovely nurses. Very kind.

Arriving at A&E in my most distressed and despairing, confused state of mind, I felt immediately listened to and cared for. The nurse quickly told me about the UCT and I was sent to them within 10 minutes. No hanging around A&E. It was an amazing level of support. The Urgent Care Team basically saved my life. I had been trying to progress my GPs OOA community referral since 27/3 and by this time I was broken and afraid and desperate. My friend drove me to the Basildon, as a last resort, to expedite the referral. My thinking was very disturbed and my thoughts were frightening me a great deal. The team all tried hard to help me. But by the end of the day, the red tape got the better of all of us (on 15/3) and the nurses couldn’t progress my referral any further. But they made a plan for me that I could call them across Sunday if I needed to and they agreed I should return on Monday (17th) to meet Dr Menesh and hopefully make some more concrete decisions about my treatment. They encouraged me to call them as I couldn’t access the crisis team from surrey (as 111, option 2, doesn’t reach Basildon from surrey). The offer, to call UCT was genius and kept me feeling safe until Monday. I’d been waiting 3 wks since my referral was sent and my MH had been deteriorating by the day - I could feel that happening. Very anxious, seeing and hearing and thinking many unpleasant things. Scared. Suicidal.

As I arrived for my appointment, I got a phone call telling me it had been cancelled. My appointment was at 10.15am and the phone call was at 9.50am. The receptionist still thought I had the original appointment so there had been no communication at all.

They were disorganised and unaware of anything related to my appointment or what was to happen next.

As I had Rebeca Davey direct number I phoned her, and eventually got to see her at 11.40. As she was at the other hospital soit took quite a while for her to arrive.

I would not recommend your hospital to anyone or return.
As I felt as I’ve improved and gained my confidence when I felt I wasn’t going to go back to where I was before operation
As I have a language barrier I would like to request BHFT to employ more nurses with an Asian background who speak Urdu, Punjabi and Hindi. I struggle to communicate with them with broken words.
As I have no complaints there is nothing to explain. Everyone was very pleasant and chatty and answered any questions I had

As I left it was promised that I would the next scan appointment and expected bills on time, four days later, nothing has come through.

Also in the case of a surgery, tell me the likely cost please. James

As I mentioned physiotherapy will not fix the arthritis in my shoulder but for some reason, protocol I believe, I have to go. Unfortunately after the mess up at the doctors it’s now been over 3 months to get the ball rolling and being self employed I’ve lost many days of work and I can’t even lift my 2 year old daughter up.

As I mentioned, should be more sessions perhaps around 12 at least. 
As often when therapy starts to work,  it's almost end of sessions.
As I said above the medical staff were excellent.  The receptionist sadly were not. See below.
As I struggle with walking I would have preferred to have vaccine in car
As I suffer with very bad anxiety and panic attacks,I felt at ease and comfortable,and I'm grateful for that.

As a business owner and mentor for 40 years, I find your processes of communication are somewhat flawed. I.e. left hand doesn’t always know what the right hand is doing. 

Little things like basic knowledge of how to take blood pressure eg  One should never ask a patient questions whilst taking blood pressure as this increases blood pressure upon which wrong diagnosis can be given. Cuff shouldn’t be placed around the elbow etc. 

There appears to be no seamless, handover of patient information and questions answered. I’ve been asked four times the very same questions from four different nurses from both floors, once should be enough, recorded and handed over to nurses downstream. 

Bathroom 
Curious to know why toilet seats are not soft close to avoid noise. 

Bathroom lights only turn off after one hour therefore fully lit throughout the night as nurses coming in and out disturbing the bathroom sensor. One would expect the bathroom light to go off after 30 seconds of none use. 

The bed constantly inflates, deflates, makes a whirring noise, impossible to sleep. The bed was eventually switched off after I asked three separate nurses after which the bed continually beeped for approximately 30 minutes, all in all a bad night sleep. 

Would have been helpful. If there was a arm above the bed, so one could pull themselves up to go to the bathroom and back especially after hernia operations.



Not a big issue, but
Poor communication between nurses and kitchen, saying I should be Nil by Mouth which was incorrect, no one came to offer food evening meal or breakfast.

As a caregiver working at the Cleveland Clinic London.  It was good to experiience the process from a patients view. I now understand why people choose the Cleveland Clinic.

Mr Redfern was very professional,  friendly and easy to talk to. He knew that I was a little worried but he he made me feel at ease by explaining everything clearly. The rest of the staff the registration teams, nursing staff and housekeeping were also polite and professional too.

I will definitely recommend my family and friends to come to the Cleveland Clinic for their healthcare needs.

As a day case patient attending the Cleveland clinic for the first time for a cerebral angiogram, I was totally impressed with the care, respect and professionalism of all the staff. Their attention to detail which was provided in a caring and considerate manner at all times was exemplary. I will be recommending the clinic to all my friends and family and feel completely reassured that my forthcoming brain surgery on my aneurysm, will be provided to the highest level possible.
As a deaf person, please be deaf aware. Unfortunately. To keeps on reminding the nurses to remove their facemask, so I can lip-read.
As a group Julie was excellent in helping us to us our memory in enjoying ways it was a great experience.

As a homeless female currently in a tent, I feel it's great I am able to access for many needs of support from 'The Hop Centre'. They provide support, medical, hot drinks and refreshments also clothing when able to due to donations, staff at centre help and support to their best ability.

As a parent of a First Episode young male adult we had the most amazing support and communication from the CPN - Anthony Hunwick, assigned to my son for the duration of 3 years. An absolute asset to the Essex team, and there until the end of the 3 years with full support. Not only do I hold this view, but others involved in my son's care had nothing but excellent words to say about Anthony. Whatever the issue, and there were many, we always received attention and direction to help us through some difficult times. Most importantly a respectful bond was formed between my son and Anthony which continues beyond the 3 years through continuing extra curricular activities.

As a person who is a professional teacher, I am taught about emotional coaching of students under my care. I would suggest that this whole therapy company needs to change its approach and actually speak and give advice and DO THERPHY. Feels like the therpaist I spoke to was uneducated and just repeated "Yes... yes that is tough..."
As a practice as a whole nothing was wrong. My individual doctor however could do with an attitude check.
As a retired nurse I was so impressed by the care I was given by the caregivers. They were kind, attentive and reassuring. The overall experience was excellent. Thank you.

As a self payer, I was made to feel very anxious when a member of the admissions team arrived unannounced to say they had come to collect payment for eight additional nights. This was completely unexpected as not half an hour before,  my consultant had told me I would be going home in a ‘day or two’. My original package was for a four night stay and was only expecting to pay for possibly two additional nights.  When I queried this their blunt response was that it was what their manager had said. They returned at a later stage and took payment for four additional nights despite me explaining that I was  only expecting be staying for two more. This was clumsily handled with a complete disregard for the emotional impact this would have on a patient recovering from surgery. It doesn’t effect my overall rating but has soured my experience to some extent.

As a self-paying patient, when I was initially advised of the procedure I required, I was unaware what the procedure was, and being concerned about the cost, I called CCL directly.  I was put through to a female  who didn't have a clue what my procedure was and told me so!  She then asked colleagues around her who also didn't know but they guessed my interventional radiology imaging would probably cost similar to other imaging such as MRI or CT so would be approximately £825.  Unfortunately, this was way off the mark and when I received my Detailed Information, it was in fact £6,050!   Even when the Appointments Team telephoned me to arrange an admission date, they still didn't have a cost for the procedure.  Eventually, the Consultant's secretary chased this up and obtained the relevant package cost.

As a spouse of the patient I found the front desk very helpful and went way and beyond what I expected.
The nurses on 5th Floor were fantastic always a ready smile when I arrived and time to answer my questions.

As a weekly workshop, there was quite a lot to take in and didn't always get the opportunity to implement week to week. Perhaps slightly more spread out sessions would also work well particularly when working full time.
As above
As above - more tailored approach.

As above -training !!
As above try a reccument drive , give more regular appointments so service users can escape pain and uncomfort
As above!
As above, also when getting blood I have noticed in previous blood tests last month I had one incident where it took 10 attempts to get blood. Perhaps more experience there is needed
As above, felt extremely well looked after by the best there is in their field. Never felt worried and always felt like I was in the safest, best hands.

As above, it’s important to channel people correctly when they self-refer following previous treatments. The treatment I initially received wasn’t appropriate to my needs and this caused further distress and delay.

As above, knowing the limit on sessions at the beginning would have been helpful.

I think the gaps between sessions was a bit too long - 2-3 weeks would have been better.

As above, my wife suffered from anxiety after surgery. It became apparent that CCL is not so well geared up for psychiatrists to attend to patients. It took a few days for my wife to be seen by a psychiatrist, and the doctors on the ward were not prepared for this - didn't have the phone numbers etc. However, once the psych doctors were contacted, they were excellent. So my advice would be for the 4th floor to be more prepared for mental health issues, esp as they are dealing with neurology patients who may have very significant diagnoses.
A separate small point. Again re mental health, if someone has a mental health issue, it is important to let them rest and not ask them for hard tasks. For example, closer integration of all staff on the ward to ensure that a patient is not constantly being disturbed (for food, therapy, doctor visit, cleaning etc) would be helpful. Also, the ipad system of ordering food is very hard for someone to manage after surgery. A proper menu printed would be helpful.
As above.

As above. 
She also didn’t listen to my first call as I had to correct her in the second.
As above. All members of staff I encountered we very polite and helpful.

As above. I put my trust in your professionals. Who are very good. But maybe they need to ask for/ encourage feedback a lot more often as we all progress. The instructor did ask quite often. Perhaps not often enough and perhaps not encouraging an assessment of the specific exercise. Maybe it's me not communicating well enough, or not speaking my mind. But I think I and others probably need more prompting as to what we can say about each exercise in order to help ourselves and the instructor
As above. I’d expected some insightful help with an hour booked for a sports consultation and infact it was just a prescription for a presenting symptom
As above: on every visit to The Cleveland Clinic and Hospital I have found all the staff to be caring, efficient and very helpful in a most pleasant way.
As always Prof Murphy was excellent!

As always it was a pleasure to be at the Clinic. The staff are so attentive and pleasant without being in any way obsequious. 
Dr Jarman is a delight.

As always was good to have a consultation with Mr Mohammadi. He is the most caring and kind consultant you could ever meet. Always explains everything, never rushed and always answers any question.
As always, expert advice from Victoria. We know that we are in safe hands and always feel that she is working in our best interests.
As always, very polite, professional and friendly. I had been delayed by public transport and there were no issues when I arrived, seen straight away. Excellent!
As always, warm, considerate and efficient staff.

Maybe there could be a different approach for cases such as mine where I was not just grieving the loss of my husband but also the estrangement from my son, daughter in law and granddaughter- more a feeling of sadness and failure rather than thoughts which could impact on my safety.

As discussed in the sessions, some of the notes could be clearer in the handbook for those with poor memory or who missed parts of the session as there was great verbal descriptions of things in the sessions that are not reflected as clearly in written form.

As explained above, every single  member of staff I met was really nice and knowledgeable 

Many thanks!!!!

As far as home team are concerned they could not of been more helpful, they were outstanding, however the crisis team were the ultimate opposite. Ciris team were supposed to phone once a week, this never happened even in the first week, and I phoned several times and either got no no answer, if there was an answer I was told to hold on they would get someone for me to talk to but the phone was just left, nobody spoke to me, almost run out of medication and was just told to ring lol for emergency prescription, crises team were no help at all.

As far as my experience goes, Grangewaters ward and the whole of Basildon Mental Health Unit, is unfit for purpose. It does not keep patients safe and for patients with EUPD, they are completely discriminated against. You could see the difference in treatment and interactions with staff between patients with EUPD and those with other mental illnesses. Therefore I believe more training for staff needs to be done in personality disorders. Same can be said for eating disorders - they are MENTAL DISORDERS, not WEIGHT DISORDERS!

I am aware that mental health services in this country are severely underfunded and this is evident on the wards. Understaffed and over-worked staff were on every shift. Also i was told by BUPA that my anaesthetist wasn’t on their list contrary to what he told me. This all added stress to what was a difficult situation. One of the very helpful people at the reception was able to complete my medication details on the website as I provided her with all the instruction leaflets which come with medications.

As mobile phone reception where I live is poor I asked to be contacted via landline.  Despite this I was always phoned on the mobile. As much as I was in for a major surgery I enjoyed the experience as much as was possible due to the care of your staff. In particular the Nurse called Sofia & HCA called Grace. As parents we would love more regular support and guidance. Also for appointment options for working parents need more flexibility for very early or late appointments if possible.
As people who treat me put me at ease as bad anxity also if in pain make sure OK also get bad depression and it like therapy as they ask how am and open up abit some problems and they listen

As said above, I had a amazing experience with the clinicians and could of asked for a better experience as a mother with autism that didn't get diagnosed till 16 I am overjoyed that she got seen so quick and got the diagnosis to help her through life

As soon as we arrived, we were greeted with a smile. The doctor was awesome and made me feel so comfortable but also at ease. For the first time in a long time I feel calm and that my son has an advantage instead of a disadvantage. Everyone was lovely and also had a lot of questions answered.

As stated above CCL is full of great medical and support staff

CCL is without doubt the place to be for medical treatment generally but specifically for cardiac matters as experienced by myself

As stated earlier a series of classes to be able to get a better grasp of the exercises.

As stated. Excellent consultant, and nurses friendly and efficient

As the hospital did not refer me to the service I had to ring myself. The first call was efficient, the 2nd call took all my details and arranged for the therapist to on my. Sarah was so lovely and listened and advised me well. She helped me with bath/shower probs and comfortable chairs making life very much better.
As the husband and Carer, I was very impressed with all the care given to my wife during her stay at Millview Ward.

As there was no receptionist it wasn’t clear what to do on arrival. To be fair, the lady who rang me to make my appointment did tell me what to do but I forgot by the time the appointment came round. A big clear notice on the wall when you arrive  would really help.
As this was about a group exercise maybe get the group to say their names, so we know who we are with.
As usual, my brother has beef dropped by the NHS after 3 sessions . Absolutely disgusting that this happens year in year out. He gets to trust someone then off that person goes into the distance

As well as keeping me informed of timings as mentioned above, the food and food service was not reliable, often came late and was often cold. Some drinks never came at all. This is the key area where the Clinic needs to improve,- perhaps patients could order food on line and track it themselves to avoid pestering busy nurses. This may seem a minor issue but good service in all areas contributes greatly to the wellbeing and recovery of patients I think.

As with a previous visit it was an excellent experience. The healthcare professionals were kind and professional and I was also able to have access to the consultant during the process. The facilities were once again second to none, and the speed of follow ups is exceptional.
As with all stretched NHS services its a shame there is not more funding to reduce waiting times to access the service

As you can tell from my answers, I was very happy with all aspects of my care. There was a10 minute delay for my appointment and I wasn’t told the reason why but I was not at all concerned by this as I just assumed the previous appointment had overrun slightly.
All of your staff were very welcoming and your facilities were clean and comfortable.

As your records will show, my procedure was delayed for 7 hours as one item in the operation kit was missing. Given I had fasted  and not drunk water since the night before, this was quite material.   The other main implication of the Delay was, by the time I was post-op, the physios had left for the day so I mixed early physio and the ward did not know how to ice my operation site and they could not find the machine to inflate my leg cuffs to minimise dvt. I did not receive these treatments until the next day, many hours after my op.   Not what I would expect from a hospital of this quality and marred how brilliant the surgeon was.   Please could someone come back to me with their comments on this.

Ashton Booth , CBT Therapist, during all session was caring, patient, had a listening ear, punctual and helped me through a difficult time with good sound advice and overall was a credit to Essex Partnership Organisation (NHS Talking Therapies) - well done Ashton and thankyou.
Aside from wait times it was good. I was treated like a person.
Ask carefully (Which usually they do).
Ask fewer questions
Ask me questions and explain to me my weaknesses.

Ask more about (possibly unrelated) symptoms - such as other problems with throat, ears.
Probably mine - I should be better prepared.
Asked me more about what i need
Asked more questions about mental health not about physical health
Asking further questions about how I feel would be helpful - It make it a bit more personal.

Assessment in have environment rather than temporary care home. Remind patient that they are not to attempt standing without another carer present. Mum has since called trying to get out of her wheelchair and severely injured her leg and head and is currently unable to walk at all even with assistance.
Assessment was not rushed. Fully explained and made me feel comfortable in my own home. Feedback and materials about services excellent.
Assessment was very relaxed.
Assessor was clear about what would happen. Questions answered and she put me at ease.

At a minimum, all staff, including nursing staff, should be trained in the elementary basics of caring for patients with co-morbid mental health conditions (who will inevitably form a large percentage of their patients on a general medical ward). Consultants and ward doctors should receive more training both in general psychiatry and also separately to avoid bias, discrimination, and diagnostic overshadowing in their care of patients with mental health conditions.  I would particularly expect doctors who prescribe antidepressants on a regular basis to be aware of the fact that it is widely accepted as contra-indicated and high-risk/frequently very dangerous to prescribe these drugs in patients with bipolar disorder, itself a common illness that they will likely come across regularly with or without knowing it.  There should without exception be a 24/7 on-call liaison psychiatry service for any facility that cares for inpatients (ward doctors specialising in general medical specialties are not adequate for this purpose). It could be considered highly unsafe to operate without this in place.  There should be a 24/7 point of contact on every ward for external care professionals to be in touch with urgent recommendations for the treatment of co-morbid conditions of current inpatients. Likewise, your hospital staff should be informed of who to call urgently if the patient suffers an acute deterioration with respect to a pre-existing/co-morbid condition.
At a very basic level source the scans inadvance of appts so that consultants can conduct informed appta.
At ease and all explained everything
At first all seemed a little disconnected in terms of who to approach (GP/cardiology/ community support) but all felt into place after a few months.
At first it was difficult to reach Jason via the reception at the surgery which was vital for me when I was very unwell however this has now been resolved.
At first no, but after speaking to [name removed], overtime I became more relaxed and able to trust her
At first, I was told that, after assessment I couldn't be helped and then later 'something might be done in 6 months' not what one wishes to hear.
At home online and course facilitated by REAL people with lived experience and professionalism.

At least check on the person your visiting . I was in real bad paine 2 nurses .not one of them asked me how I was or checked anything . I was in bad paine . What's the point of being on a high risk patient list if the nurses who attend do nothing . Absolutely pathetic .
At least one of the rises seats didn't have a book I found sitting without proper back support very uncomfortable even with a cushion.
At least present moment we have all the information we need
At least pretend to care about the patient and the difficulty he/she is experiencing.

At one point a child ran into the test room whilst the lady was explaining to us and our daughter the process of the test. Which we are very understanding that there are other children with additional needs that can't be stopped going into a room. These things happen. 

We feel however other staff members accompanying this child, could be more aware of these issues arising and to avoid this potentially disturbing the test, the QB testing take part in a secluded part of the building where appropriate. Just to avoid potential distractions during the testing. 

Also, we have come away with no official diagnosis from a QB test, which is also understandable and I respect and advocate for an indepth assessment. 

Is there anyway a "working diagnosis" could be implemented if the QB testing comes back positive?

This is merely to be able to evidence further support the child in-between QB testing and formal diagnosis for schools & GPs to acknowledge and implement changes to best support them in their educational settings. 

Also I understand there is an approx 4 months waiting time between testing and clinical diagnosis, this is a fairly short time in real terms. 
In regards to a child struggling with the negative effects of a neurodevelopmental condition, this is an extremely long time, to endure symptoms that they have already experience for most of their life already. 

Is there any way to get a streamlined pathway set up for these children who present with a positive QB test? I think this would a valuable and cost effective way to get these children the right help, quickly and efficiently. Especially those not being seen until 10/11years old and facing time sensitive transitions for high school.

At the end of our session, I was given a sheet with about 6 new exercises to undertake twice a day.  Although we touched on some of them when I was being examined, I felt that more time needs to be given to explain and then watch whilst I went through the exercises. I know they are the way forward in managing my problem.   Whilst I appreciate that time allowed is very precious in terms of a patient consultation; having read through the exercises, I am not confident that I will be able to remember and do them correctly.
At the initial consultation we were treated with care. We received the diagnosis and the post-diagnosis support within two weeks of the initial consultation, this was excellent.
At the time, I could have used someone to talk to but I wasn't asked about that. I didn't know what resources were available and I've had to get help from my GP.

At the time, the support was perfect. However, we were told he may benefit from further support in the future but to await the milestones for speech to see how he developed. Unfortunately covid then came and the drop in/self referral access ceased. My son is still struggling with some sounds however because he is doing well in school otherwise, he is not a priority in them making a referral and is getting left behind.
At time people were helpful, but also I had a lot of people say things like “wont your family be disappointed”
At times I felt a little judged by the therapist which meant I couldn’t open up as much.
At times feels like there's no privacy at medication times, other patients stand close to the door and can hear what medication you're receiving.
At times, there were staff shortages. In the presence of vulnerable patients there should always have been a staff member within close contact in case of need. This was not always the case.
Atleast give me some other services that may be able to help rather than leaving me out in the cold with no one professional to give me any guidance
Attend to patients more quickly
Attendance of toilet - too often forgotten on toilets.
Attended to promptly in a most friendly and helpful way.

Attending a consultation can make one feel apprehensive, but everything about the management of my visit resulted in me feeling very calm and taken care of. Having welcomed me into his consultation room, the consultant immediately put me at ease by saying he felt he was in a position to help me. This set the tone for the rest of the consultation.
Attentative and personalised.

Attention from nurses was so supportive and attentive. During the night i felt safe and cared for. During the day nurses were often very busy, but went above and beyond to care for me. Unfortunately this professionalism and care did not carry over to the catering team and the pharmacy.

After being returned to my room post op, i had to request to be given some food as i had not eaten in 24 hours. Two members of the catering team arrived to take my order and my partner and i both commented on how terrible one of the staffs bedside manner was. She was very blunt and abrupt and as i was still under the influence of general i found her manner to be unusual. After an hour she returned to my room to ask how my meal was, but my meal had not arrived. I ordered a simple soup and apple juice.  Another 30mins went by and still no meal and no explanation. Without the help of my partner and the charge nurse, i have little faith that my meal would have ever arrived. My toilet broke so my room was moved and at 17:30 the same woman returned to my door to take my order as the physio was leaving. The physio invited her in, and she said, "Oh no, I'll come back she needs something special." No one returned for an hour and i was left feeling like i had done something wrong. Again, i had to put in multiple requests with the charge nurse to chase. At this point, head of catering craig came to my room to personally take my dinner order. I complained about the attitude and service and he assured me it wouldn't happen again. Another 2 hours passed and still no food. At 8pm the same lady returned to take my order and told me that ordering hours close at 7:30. My evening meal arrived at 9pm. This was extremely distressing, i felt disrepected, made to feel anxious about the care i could expect from the hospital and exhausted by the effort it took to get a meal.

On the last day, i waited for 6 hours to receive my medication from the pharmacy. The neurologist nurse Anders and doctor George both advised i should be staying another night, when i aksed about my insurance they retracted that decision as they did not want to make the phone call for me. This decision was made at 2pm, i was then left to wait until 6 pm for the pharmacy to bring me my medication and an additional 2 hours to be discharged. This left me feeling once again like there was no care or thought put into the experience of the patient. And above all a compelte lack of communication and desire to look after me.

Both the Clinic and surgeon told me I required a two night stay.  BUPA would only cover one night. 

I have a complex medical history and knew I was not ready to go home after only one night: very high pain levels in post-op recovery, the need for a PCA, an allergic reaction to one or more of the meds and a general feeling of being too unwell to go home resulted in a notable amount of time and stress securing an extended stay.

It was no-one’s fault; everyone was as helpful as possible. I made clear that I was happy to pay whatever additional cost necessary. Ultimately, the allergic reaction provided a reason for the Clinic to approach BUPA and the second night’s stay was approved. 

It seemed that BUPA’s coverage determined the length of care rather than the doctors and nurses assessing individual circumstances. I wonder if there is a better and more timely way to resolve similar situations going forward.

Also, I was given discharge instructions for the many meds but nothing relating to post-op expectations (adhesiolysis, appendectomy), wound care, what to expect re pain levels, limiting movement, returning to exercise, etc. I am still in a lot of pain and don’t know if that’s normal. Perhaps some of this was communicated verbally but, given the level of meds, I was not aware enough to take note.

However, the breakout group that S led, was given more time to talk and share. I felt that M should have stayed with us, asked how we all felt to check we were ok. I could see it was not easy for anyone to share their recovery journey, including myself. I felt abandoned and that upset me.

Also, our breakout group should have had more time to share and not cut off exactly on 3 minutes when I and the others were finishing a sentence talking about our recovery journey.

Compared to NHS care, everything went briskly and efficiently as if the care team fully appreciated that I just wanted to get back to my normal life as soon as possible. This was especially true of discharge, with no hanging around for meds and forms as there would be at an NHS hospital. There was a palpable feeling of energy. I also felt that the entire team, especially the surgeon and the anaesthetist, were at the top of their game and excellent at communication. The building, too, is exceptional.

Compared to a previous outpatient appointment, which was efficient and excellent, yesterday was not an altogether positive experience for me.  I appreciate that I was given an appointment so soon after it was requested.  I was not seen on time, I was told to be there by 11.10 for an 11.30 appointment but was seen quite a bit later.  I did not even mind the wait, although I was not informed how much longer it would be or what the holdup was.  The radiographer/nurse were polite but did not provide me with helpful information as to what I would experience.  I was given IV Buscopan.  Very shortly after I felt that my mouth was so dry that my throat closed and I could not swallow.  I stopped the process as not being able to swallow made me panic.  I asked for water.  I was given a couple of sips on the side of my mouth without moving and it was not sufficient and it spilt.  I was not given a straw or enabled to sip properly.  The most important thing I can say, and that I only became aware of after researching it after the procedure, is that Buscopan can cause a dry mouth.    If only the radiographer/nurse had mentioned this to me beforehand it would not have been so alarming when I couldn't swallow.  If they would have let me just sip some water properly it would have made the world of difference.  I have had an anaphylactic reaction to Asprin in the past and so this side affect was very unpleasant and I was concerned I was having an allergy.  The two inadequate sips made a difference.  A clear explanation is what I needed and a bit of water that I could sip properly.  When I changed and then left I was not told that I might have some side effects from the IV dye and what to expect.  I had nausea and quite a bad headache for many hours after.  Eventually I looked it up last night and I saw this is a common side effect.  Again, if I would have been told this, and to drink a good amount of water afterwards, I would not have been alarmed that something was not right.    With the ear plugs in and the headphones on top I could not hear the instructions properly either and so had an anxious time trying to make out what the voice was telling me to do.  It would have been very helpful if I would have been told beforehand that I would be told how to breathe etc and hold my breath. It was after a few 'hit and miss' that I think I finally worked it out.   I read all the notes sent to me on pdf beforehand.  Not one mentioned the side effects I could experience after and nobody told me about it on the day.   I am going to be having surgery soon and I am quite anxious about it after my experience yesterday.

Compared to treatment elsewhere this was top draw. I couldn’t fault it . They just missed 1 request for a cup of coffee.

David Brennan, my trauma therapist, has been an essential pillar of support in my journey towards healing and recovery. His expertise, empathy, and dedication have played a significant role in helping me navigate the challenges of my PTSD. I'd like to share some words about how he has positively impacted my life.

First and foremost, David Brennan has helped me regain a sense of confidence and self-assurance that I thought was forever lost. Trauma and PTSD had really affected my one's self-esteem and I felt quite powerless but through his guidance, I began to rebuild my self-worth. David created a safe and non-judgmental space where I could express my feelings and confront the past. His unwavering support made me feel validated and heard, which, in turn, boosted my confidence.

One of the most valuable aspects of his therapy was the array of tools he equipped me with to cope with my PTSD. Exposure therapy, in particular, was a turning point in my recovery. By gradually facing the situations and triggers that had previously paralyzed me with fear, I learned to manage my reactions and reduce the intensity of my symptoms. David's compassionate guidance during these exposures was instrumental in making them effective and empowering.

Additionally, David introduced me to cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which transformed the way I think and respond to traumatic memories and triggers. Through CBT, I acquired the skills to identify and challenge negative thought patterns that perpetuated my suffering. David taught me how to reframe my perspective, fostering a healthier and more positive mindset. This change in my thought patterns has been a cornerstone in my healing process.

In essence, David Brennan's compassionate and professional support has made an indelible impact on my life. His guidance, alongside the effective therapeutic techniques he employs, has allowed me to regain more control over my life, diminish the grip of trauma, and move towards a brighter, healthier future. I am deeply grateful for his expertise and unwavering commitment to my well-being, as he has been instrumental in helping me with my challenges of PTSD.

Different people from the service have said that BEDS sees an array of patients, from a range of backgrounds, but it didn’t seem like that has informed how treatment is approached. I understand the importance of a structured approach , but I definitely found the dietetics and FS less helpful because of the unique and difficult nature of my situation. I also recognise that it’s impossible to tailor treatment to every individual, but I think there’s no point recognising that people come from different ethnic backgrounds and socio-economic backgrounds if it doesn’t inform any aspect of the process. Coming from a single parent, working-class, asian household where mental health is a taboo subject, it is simply not possible for me to approach recovery in the same way as somebody from a white, middle-class household, so using the same ‘script’ with me as you would with them will not work, not because I don’t want to recover, but because logistically there are some things I can’t do. It also felt like there was a lack of empathy in regards to this; it isn’t particularly helpful to keep being told “you’ve turned 18, you’re an adult now, this is all your responsibility” when you’re already having to deal with recovery on your own, aside from support from your school. It isn’t particularly motivating and I think it’s overly harsh when people come to the service wanting to get better and are aware that it’s on them to do so. 

I also think there needs to be way more transparency about where you are on the waiting lists. There was no indication that FS would take 6 months to happen, and only after I’d raised how long I’d be waiting. I absolutely understand that the NHS is underfunded and these things take a while, but I think empathy and recognition of the fact that waiting is really hard is something that is really important. I can tell how committed everyone at the service is, and nothing is anybody’s ‘fault’ but with the number of BAME people with EDs rising, it’s important that cultural factors and also socio-economic factors have greater weighing and inform how you are approached more.

Also the thermometer in my room (I think 442 or 443) wasn't working, which was a real pain for nurses who had to come in and take my temperature every few hours.  Would be nice if there were some smart features enabled on the TVs (e.g. netflix, or casting, so people could cast from their phones to the tv).

Don't tell people with long standing health conditions to come back "once their health is more stable". Like I say my health isn't going to change any time soon so does that mean I should write therapy off because I'm not well enough? It's a terrible thing to say to someone who is already struggling so much.

Dont ask stupid questions like scales and stuff because it just confused me as I cant think for long periods without medication and tell people you are therapists not psychiatrists. Dr Cuming was excellent. She took the time to listen carefully to me, asked great questions, was an actual human person who seemed warm and caring whilst also being extremely professional. Dr Cuming was very informative and kind. She listened to me and explained everything I needed to know.

Dr D Edwards is an excellent professional, as well as being very attentive and supportive of the patient. He has provided excellent care and I do 100% recommend him to friends and family.

All in all, i do 100% recommnetd the Cleveland Clinic.

Dr Dawkins is excellent.  He takes the time to explain carefully and lucidly making sure we understand what he is telling us and then he listens really attentively to what we think.  
Staff working in reception and at the exit were helpful and friendly which makes for excellent first impressions and a feeling of being cared for.
Dr Dawkins knew all about my case and gave helpful analysis and recommendations.

Dr Dipesh Patel was not prepared in our last meeting, totally waste of time, I done my blood test over a month ago, and he said he didn’t have the blood result yet, and he promised in last session there will be board meeting to discuss my MRI scan, he said it happened but he didn’t have the note?! Such waste of time, waste of resource. I would expect some level of profession in private health case, it was very disappointing.

Dr Frances Humby is absolutely brilliant. The nursing staff in the 3rd floor are friendly and caring. However, the reception can be warm and noisy as there is no ambient sound and you can hear other patients info.

Dr Frances Humby was very thorough exploring all past my conditions, illnesses and symptoms in order to form an accurate conclusion for my current condition. She was very explanatory providing me with answers to every question asked and explaining the details of my symptoms. She was very approachable and very professional at all times which made me feel at ease as a patient. 
It's highly important for a patient to feel respected and be treated with dignity. Indeed, this has been the case during my visit to the clinic.

Dr H Rehan filled me with confidence. Pleasant manner and always helpful. Determined to find out  gut issue. 
Many thanks

Dr Haidry instilled immediate confidence that I was in good hands and took the time to explain and ensure that I understood my options. Next steps were clearly explained and support staff were friendly, professional and efficient.
Dr Haidry is fantastic.  Fills me with confidence and reassures me that he can help.  He has given me hope.
Dr Huda was approachable, patient and kind. I felt safe and cared for. He listened intently to what I had to say and seemed to understand intuitively.
Dr Imber was excellent. We did have issues with the zoom consultation and reverted to using our mobile phones instead
Dr John Hines is very good and attentive with full of expertise in his field.  The whole experience is very pleasant and tranqil.  Reception and all staff are marvellous

Dr Johnson was very accommodating and put me straight in for the procedure. Every other consultant I spoke to wanted to go through the whole process of scans etc again.   I asked to stay overnight as my insurance had authorised a stay and I was accommodated at short notice, looked after and cared for by the nursing staff.

Dr Jon Simmons is the trauma plastic surgeon. I will need to remove the bony overgrowth in my ankle joint to help ensure nothing negative happens to my ALT flap.

Dr Simmons was very warm and welcoming. He reviewed my ALT flap, and we discussed my previous care at Charing Cross under a couple of his colleagues. He was delighted to see how well the ALT flap had integrated naturally into my body and hear about the activities and lifestyle I led despite the injury profile.

He explained that my ALT flap was not at risk of dying during the procedure but would need to assist Nadeem (orthopaedic surgeon) for 20 mins in case complications arose.

Despite facing surgery to remove bony growth spurts in my ankle due to developing arthritis, I left the appointment feeling uplifted, as Jon expressed that he was thrilled to see how well things had turned out for me.

Dr Kash changed me life. I was in a serious sits with my torn MCL. Dr Kash took me In immediately for assessment and with his care and health plan, I avoided surgery and now cured. I could not be more grateful for him and his care. His is really a saviour. I cannot say enough about him. I have already recommended Dr Kash and your clinic to others.
Dr Kennan was excellent
Dr Krieger is so professional. He is so patient and explains everything. I trust him and he is very skilled. I have already recommended him to a few close friends.
Dr Krieger was very kind and explained everything! Great experience
Dr Lambiase was straightforward, unpretentious, clear and never patronising. The support staff were everything I could ask for.

Dr Langley did not listen to, nor take my evidence into consideration at all. Shut me down constantly and decided 40 mins of her with my son while masking was enough to deem her mislabelling him even though he met criteria on the ADOS for a Autism diagnosis.
Dr Lopez was extremely helpful, empathetic and worked collaboratively with me to devise a plan going forward.
Dr Losseff has provided great care, and has a great manner. I feel completely safe in his care, and his

Dr Losseff has treated me in the past and I have absolute faith in his expertise.  He listens avidly and explains things very clearly.  I feel very fortunate to be treated by him.  The front of house security team and reception staff were very compassionate and went out of their way to help me (I am on crutches).  The 4th floor reception team were slightly less so and I can only assume this was because there were many distractions in that area with phones ringing and patients waiting.  That small issue aside, I am delighted by the treatment I've received by the Cleveland Clinic team to date.
Dr Losseff is a consummate medical and neurological professional
Dr Losseff was fantastic - clear, understanding, helpful and supportive of what I wanted to do
Dr Losses who is the reason I visited the clinic is exceptional - probably the best operator in his field in the UK. He is compassionate, well informed and communicates very well
Dr Maniyar was extremely patient and kind and explained everything very well. Facilities were very clean and MRI scanner was top of the line.
Dr Mark Gillett is a very trustworthy and dedicated doctor who always looks out for his patients best interest. I cannot recommend him enough and I am grateful that he is my doctor.
Dr McCartney is so kind and professional she is a credit to the hospital.

Dr McCartney is so lovely. I am so appreciative that she takes my concerns seriously. I never feel rushed in our appointments and I feel she is both compassionate and thorough. I would not hesitate to recommend her to any friends or family who needed help with a gastro issue.
Dr Mokawem was very reassuring and professional. Overall the facilities were good.

Dr Mughal was amazing and really cared about my situation. The staff were also very kind and caring and relatable. The service is probably the best in London. It's nice that there's a human touch and just friendly smiley staff.

I gave my Blue Cross Blue Shield insurance information and am hoping that the care will be covered directly - as I was told it would be.  I guess you will bill me if I have a co-payment.

Dr. Maniyar is excellent. He was well prepared and had clearly refreshed himself on my details and case from my previous appointment, so we were able to launch straight into the appointment. Dr. Zarate Lopez is an incredible healthcare provider. She listened to me and explained everything thoroughly. Doing everything she could to better my health.

Dr. Zarate called me this morning and for some reason I missed the call. I have had to phone back twice too speak to Dr. Zarate's secretary. The receptionist explained that he had left messages for her. I have not heard back. Very disappointed.

Dr.Patel was amazing. Thirteen years, seeing countless doctors, he stands above the rest. I learned more about my condition in one hour than all the others together.I am so grateful to him.
I hope to see him again.
Due to associated  issues relating from one major issue. I was quite confused as to how to indentify what issue I was having therapy for.
Due to my hearing loss I have difficulties some time understanding different accent if someone speak fast

Due to past experience I asked the booking agent to email me the documents which was lucky because the documents I got on my email were not seen by me on my mychart booking, 

You need to match your written material with the verbal instructions. For example the written material said I was having an oral dye but I was given a dye through my veins. 

For my first appt I was referred to as Mr Johnnson

My second appt I was called Leila Johnson.

Neither is me and I had to work out they were looking for me.

Due to several serious misgivings and not having my calls emails and texts replied to in the critical few days after my surgery, my wound became infected and my recovery time has doubled. There is also a real risk that I will
Not recover as I would have if the after care had been provided as it should have been.
Having had my 2 week check up, my surgeon Tom quick is on complete agreement that the service has been shambolic and totally avoidable and that this may cause complications and impede recovery. The letter I have received acknowledges this and admits that the after care service was non existent and incredibly poor resulting in expense, pain, and anxiety around recovery.

Due to unfair bias i felt misjudged and stereo type and mis heard and i feel like if there was clear communication between particular staff and myself it would made my stayed in daisy ward more therapeutic experience as oppose to traumatic.
Duration of these exercises should be increased.

During ECG, nurse has troubles in getting the ECG machine and leads working properly.  It took about 10 mins for her to work out why the machine wasn’t functioning properly all the while I was left with my breast exposed and at no point was I offered a gown to cover… the experience was uncomfortable and undignified.  The nurse seemed unprepared, untrained and rather unprofessional.
During an intimate exam, several staff memebrs just walked into the room. I had no idea who they were ofr why they were there.
During change over make sure someone is around as I had to wait 1 hour for help as felt really unwell but thankfully Angela Mendoza took over
During my assessment, a man knocked on the door and picked through the window while I was there . At that time I didn’t wear my religious scarf , the man saw me . He should have knocked and waited .

During my consultation the phone of the consultant kept ringing (twice) as the secretary kept phoning in for what seemed to me as non emergency matters. I therefore found this entirely unacceptable if not ridiculous. Had the phone rang a third time I would have complained and made fuss about it. I do not even have insurance, I pay from my own pocket for the service received from Cleveland and this is NOT acceptable.

In addition I was sent to 40 Grosvenor place and not 33 and that resulted in me being late 30 minutes. This was however probably an honest mistake that I will overlook.

During my first stay for pancreatitis, I was told that I should have been admitted immediately to the hospital when I called in at 1am following my biopsy, rather the person on the end of the line told me to take some paracetamol and drink some tea, despite being in agonising pain. I was also told in my first few days there that pancreatitis usually dies down quite quickly and I'd be out of there in no time. Instead, I got much worse on days 4 and 5, throwing up all night, not eating for 48hrs, in the worst pain I've ever experienced in my life. Eventually I was taken downstairs for a CT scan which revealed a leak of pancreatic fluid, which was immediately operated on and after which I immediately felt a lot better. One wonders if this could have been identified quicker to save me the horrors of those 48 hours, which I can safely say, were the worst of my life. I could speak, move or do anything except moan in pain and I thought it would never end.

During my stay in the intensive care unit I was constantly monitored and pain medication was administered to me to minimise discomfort. I was always attended to and my family could visit me for long stretches of time.  When I was moved to the ward, the room was clean, bright and spacious. The nurses were highly qualified and came to my room any time I needed their help without delay. Excellent experience

During my stay in the intensive care unit I was constantly monitored and pain medication was administered to me to minimise discomfort. I was always attended to and my family could visit me for long stretches of time. When I was moved to the ward, the room was clean, bright and spacious. During my visit, any concerns I had were addressed to my satisfaction, the results of my scan were presented in a way that was easy to understand and the decisions regarding my future care were made jointly by myself and my Doctor.  I feel safe and secure in the knowledge that I’m receiving the best care possible.

During the MRI it would have been helpful to have more verbal information through the headphones e.g - we are starting now, there will be some noises, explaining why there were big pauses - just to add some reassurance.

During the MRI scan, there were around 10 minutes of silence that I was not expecting.  It would have been helpful to know that this was going to happen.  Also helpful to know for how long I would need to hold my breath.

During the echo, a doctor interrupted to ask her if she could accommodate another patient. Dr didn’t enter the room but I thought that was unprofessional- he should have asked the reception team instead

During the first week, I found the video slightly triggering, particularly of the woman with the thigh gap. I think it could be explained without images/videos or a trigger warning could have been helpful.

During the phone calls, I got the impression that the therapist was using a computer. Other times I wasn't sure he was listening, but this is understandable too, as I do talk a lot.

During three days, no-one made any attempt to tidy up the complex array of sheets, pillows and blankets on my bed. She listened thoroughly and validated my feelings without encouraging them to continue. She provided a safe environment where I felt free to talk about anything without consequence or judgement. I feel as though I am now able to face the world with the same issues but a new mind set, and would 100% feel able to ask for help again in the future should I feel I need it. Thankyou so much!
Electric doors as I’m in a large wheelchair had to have three staff members to hold doors open

Emily was fantastic! Just what I needed, right when I needed it. She allowed me to speak freely and get everything out that I needed too. I also felt very safe to speak openly. She was very compassionate and understanding and gave me great advice and a knowledge about my condition.

Emily was so good ar her job and her explanations and empathy were top class.The care and attention was second to none.My medication was arranged very speedily. I am feeling very well and I am very grateful  for your care.

She was very transparent in answering all my questions and concerns and took the time to discuss many options and possibilities with me,

All in all she is great at what she does and I'm so glad to have found her

Emma Hills, Macmillan Community Colorectal Nurse is amazing. She is in constant touch and I can drop her a text or email if I have any concerns. She keeps me updated with results from my bowel cancer surveillance tests and organises the next ones going forwards. Although we have never met face to face I feel like I know her and feel like she really looks after me. She's happy to answer any questions I may have and would always be my first port of call if I was worried.
Emma Hopley was very thorough and reliable and  took time to understand my child's needs.
Emma and Claudia were both brilliant for all 3 of us and we have come away from our appointment feeling listened to.
Emma and Steve were both excellent in helping me agree a termination settlement contract with my employer. I'm so grateful they were there to help guide me through this process.
Emma and Thereza are helpful and welcoming. They explained their observation and gave suggestions when asked. They were extremely patient with my son.

Emma was extremely understanding and I felt at ease with talking to her.

It is very patronizing to hear someone constantly do a loud "mmm" as if they understand constantly through a sentence or worse say "I see" when clearly they havn't a clue!
Employ staff that understand their role and the duty of care that is required with it!

Encourage participants to engage more together i did ONLINE COURSE - when you are alone most of the time experience depression SOME People want to hear and share others experiences etc  Apart from the tutors I just looked at SIX blank circles con line I know everyone doesn’t want to show themselves but encouragement would help. Erica my OT was very helpful and undersanding and help me reach my goal

Erica my therapist is a credit to your department.

Escorted me out (I was given directions but not escorted out) from basement
Eunice was very kind and patient with me took time to explain things to me.

Evaluate patience on a case by cases basis and be open minded to exploring solutions beyond the status quo of the script. 
Behavioral therapy is not a universal solution, it is a fragment of a puzzle which brings a larger picture and left alone like this does more damage than good.
Have more staff.
Have more professional psychiatrists on staff availability.
Do not resort to anti depressants or sleeping pills as an immediate reaction to the problem.
Acknowledge that the problem with Mental Health is a big one in this country and it needs a level of attention and care beyond passing the buck. I have more faith in private health care than the NHS, that is not an opinion which brings a united country together, faith in the system has been lost.

Lastly how is the gender identity relevant to the feedback form ? The only criteria requiring that information is that of segregation of priority,  demographics should not influence the right of a person yet it clearly is part of it.
Even better listening skills, a solution focused approach

Even though I pointed  out when booking the appt that my consultant would need to source my scans from my referring consultant this did not happen rendering the appt completely pointless. Meaning  I had to schedule a second appt which the Cleveland had the audacity to try and charge me for. Awful. Shelley in your customer experience for saved the day but the whole experience was very upsetting.

Even though my actual procedure was very scary everyone at the clinic are amazing! Helpful, polite, considerate & very friendly! They helped me get through it! 

The Cleveland clinic building is a beautiful building & I was lucky to see the view in the best room on the 5th floor - Buckingham palace & the food was lovely especially the Victoria sponge! 

I hope to never return as the amazing surgeons have fixed me but I would highly recommend the Cleveland clinic!

Even though the cap on 20 sessions felt big at the start, towards the end I felt like I had become comfortable enough to uncover some deep thoughts that I couldn’t then shake off, but as time was up I was unable to explore these.
Eventually became good but took too long. 3 different Physiatrists within a few weeks. Not good for patient care continuity.
Everthing was carried out efficiently, smoothly and in a friendly comforting manner.

Every SLT worker we’ve met has always treated us and Arthur with the upmost respect. They’ve all been extremely welcoming and very patient. They always bring the best out of Arthur which stuns me at times as on occasions he’ll do things or say something I didn’t know he could. It’s always a pleasure attending SLT sessions.
Every aspect of my treatment was delivered in a sympathetic and professional manner.
Every assistance was given
Every doctor and staff was 100%.
Every experience I have had with the surgery has been very good. I am always treated with respect and fully involved in my care and treatment.

Every individual is different, I know that your service is very overwhelmed but they got to treat every single person different for what they need. 
I was discharged when I was still needing care and brought back into the service later on. 
I witnessed patients drinking outside the hospital when they should of been in care.
Every member of staff (whatever their role) was kind, courteous, approachable, which all made me feel at ease and have confidence in my treatment.

Every member of staff I encountered was professional, friendly and attentive. 

The high quality of the environment (room, corridors and operating theatre) gave me a strong level of confidence in the safety and professionalism of the hospital in general, and in the procedure itself. 

The hospital had a very calm atmosphere. I felt very comfortable and supported throughout my whole stay.

Every member of staff I met during my stay were incredibly caring, kind, and professional. Everybody from the nurses and doctors (who I unsurprisingly had the most contact with) to the kitchen team and housekeepers were very nice and seemed intent on making me feel at home here.

Every member of staff from the front of house to my consultant were so kind and I didn't feel like a second rate citizen as I was being seen on the nhs. I was treated with the utmost respect.
The staff in the recovery of the cath lab namely Christine  and Christine were so kind as I was quite poorly and treated me so fondly wonderful overall care.
Every member of staff has been wonderful!
Every member of staff was kind and helpful
Every member of staff was kind, courteous and informative. They discussed my procedure in detail and answered all my questions. My care was second to none,
Every member of staff,  regardless of their role, was pleasant, caring, helpful and reassuring.

Every member of the team were very welcoming, friendly and made me feel at ease, I felt treated like a person rather than a number on a sheet of paper. Very professional staff that go that extra mile.

Every member of this team gave absolutely excellent service including the people our son spoke to on the phone when he was suicidal and the nurses who came in each day. They dealt with us as a family professionally and supportively in a very difficult time. We couldn’t have got through this experience without them. We were very impressed with the speed of seeing the psychiatrist and this was crucial in getting our son on to new medication to stabilise his mental health.
Every part of experience has been amazing! All the staff and facilities, as well as the speed and timeliness of service havd been excellent.
Every part of the experience put me at my ease, the clinic is state of the art, and very welcoming at the same time.
Every person I encountered behaved very professionally.

Every person from those who greeted me upon arrival to the nurses, doctors, porters, cleaners and everyone else were incredibly friendly, helpful, caring and gave exceptional service. I cannot speak highly enough about the care given. The hospital is well appointed with great facilities. Thank you!

Every single member of staff I met on my visit were just lovely- so polite and friendly and so helpful. The hospital is spotlessly clean and really nicely fitted out. I would have no hesitation in recommending both my consultant and the hospital in general to anyone.
Every single member of staff have been so kind and compassionate towards me and treated me with respect.

Every single member of staff on the 4th floor including the caters and cleaners were amazing, they were always polite and very helpful
They shown lots of empathy and always made sure I was ok.
The other really lovely and reassuring thing was all the staff got on with each other really well and worked as a team
I would definitely recommend a stay here.
Every single member of staff was courteous, helpful and professional and even those not dealing with me specifically, offered their assistance should I need it.  Excellent !
Every single person I came into contact with at the Cleveland was exceptional.
Every single person, from the staff at the door, reception to the Consultant himself acted impeccably and made me feel welcome and comfortable. Top notch service.

Every single staff member was compassionate and went overboard to help me. The whole team tried their best. I’m sorry there was so much bureaucracy to circumvent but I am relieved I found you. I am the lucky one.
Every single staff member was highly efficient, fully focussed and excellent at their job. Facilities were uniformly state of the art, and new.

Every staff member I interacted with was helpful, polite and respectful towards me. They really transform bad situations into much more manageable ones. But more than this, they make you feel like family for however long you stay.
Every stall had very experienced and friendly staff. There was lots of extremely useful information, which we will find very useful. Fantastic service, thank you.
Every step of the way I was treated well. Staff were courteous and helpful.

I would not be more grateful for the treatment I received.

Everyone was qualified and professional. But advice wasn’t always joined up between the various visiting staff and notes were not always made. I had to tell nurses that I needed medication to be crushed or liquid form, whereas I was given a whole bag of pills to take home. This was eventually changed to liquid form.  There was frequent low blood pressure readings but never any follow up on this with doctors so I was allowed to worry about this. There was a lack of clarity about when I could come off Nil by Mouth - some said I could, then was told I couldn’t. But staff changeovers seemed to complicate matters - not joined up. There were also some abnormal blood test results relating to clotting. I’ve no idea if there came through before the surgery (only taken 10 mins before). But seemed not to have been studied before being operated on? Also the subsequent blood tests showed some abnormal results - but no comment made on these - just leaving me to worry about them.

Everything was going pretty well until your receptionist decided to tell me, as if I was working for him, that he had to go to the toilet and as I was the only person sitting in the waiting area, he said if I see someone walking in to tell them to sit down and that he would be right back. The problem was that he was not polite to me and he spoke to me as if I had to do it for him. The reason I was waiting by the way is because he called the wrong number for the ultrasound so he didn't go through and hence I was waiting despite of me being there earlier. I heard him calling for someone else that had an MRI to make sure he was taken in ( even though he was already taken in by one of the nurses and probably he missed it) but he didn't do the same for me.  My appointment for the ultrasound was rushed and the result was not explained to me clearly.
