Being able to go and see Anna once a week has made me feel much better about myself and I could not be happier with the care and treatment she provided for me. 

Anna is an absolute credit to Therapy For You and the service they provide for people.

Thank You Soo Much Anna
I saw Dr Matthews and Destiny. They were both equally caring and understanding. I felt safe and unjudged

I saw Dr Nathalie Phillips for a pain I have been experiencing. My experience was so positive with her. I felt heard and understood and I felt she went very out of her way to help me with my problem. The staff and clinic (and hospital) was top quality. I’ve been in london for about 11 years and I’ve never experienced such amazing care and attention before. I highly recommend both the doc and this hospital/out patient clinic. I will continue to come here (if need be) and would recommend this place to anyone!

I saw Dr Tom Quick and as always, the care I received was second to none. The receptionists are always welcoming and helpful when checking in and booking further appointments. Dr Quick listened to what I had to say and was very supportive. He also explained things in a way that was easy to understand, despite the complexity of the issues.

I saw Emily 
And she helped me with everything we spoke about and listened and made lots of helpful suggestions.
I actually have terrible mental since having covid
I have not felt listened to in all this time.
This is first time I feel someone was actually listening. 
So was very pleased with the service.
I saw JJ for my POA. He’s very engaging and warm, knowledgeable about everything from meds to blood work etc. very kind, happy and smiling.

I saw Mr Tahmassebi who's a top rate surgeon. As importantly he takes the time to deliver the information in a way that's understandable to someone who isn't a doctor specialised in this field. He's also very warm and friendly and genuinely has the patient's best interest at heart. That shouldn't be taken for granted.
I saw Mr [name removed]. He is amazing, he understood my pain and I am looking forward to our journey to help relieve my pain!

I saw Prof Tom Quick
It was an excellent experience. 
The staff were all wonderful. 
the building is spotless and very comfortable.

I saw Rebecca Davey, she was amazing. She really listened to my complicated list of issues and explained what was happening. Organised a treatment plan which she immediately put into action and arrange follow up visits to asses the findings. She was very warm and put me at ease straight away.

I saw an excellent Consultant who discussed everything relevant to my medical problem. He was friendy, approachable and very thorough. He organised  my necessary investigations at the best and most convenient location.
I had blood tests at Grosvenor Place : the staff were welcoming and professional. My tests were carried out before my appointed time so I did not have to wait. The whole episode went smoothly and I left rather impressed by the actual building and the staff within it.

I saw someone called Mamie in the early hours of the 31/08/23. She took the time to understand what had brought me to seeing AMHT. She listened to every concern that I had and tried to do everything she could to get me the help I need. I find it hard sometimes to trust professionals due to past experience but I felt like I could be honest with her about what has been going on in my life to cause the way I felt.
I saw someone from the Oxford area while under your team and she wasn't sure how to help me, promised me a phone call, promised to set up an appointment but didn't get back to me.

I sensed quite early on that the therapist may have been thinking I wasn’t ill enough to need help. 

I would have like more emphasis on talking and less on the deluge of psychology models that were sent to me.
I should be talking to a psychologist for therapy
I should have been given a little more warning on some paperwork to bring to the appointment.

I should have been given the above information before the urodynamics procedure and after it, I should have been given the option of taking preventative antibiotics or, at least, have been given full information about how to detect signs of a UTI and what to do / who to contact.  I emailed the doctor's private secretary (as indicated on my summary letter) to ask what to do on Thursday night, but she was away and no-one checked her email and got back to me until Monday, by which time I was very unwell and in extreme discomfort with no idea what to do.  Once the nurse became involved, I did eventually get the care I needed, but I think the whole situation could have been avoided with clearer after-care information.  This should include clear instructions in terms of who to contact if you have a problem following the investigation, what to do if you do get a UTI and what foods and drinks to avoid.  Unfortunately, I wasn't told about the latter until the day I finally started antibiotics and I had been eating and drinking all the things that make the symptoms worse!

I should have brought cream so feet could be moisturised 

I didn't mention this at appt.
I should have got support earlier
I should see my cpn more regularly. But my care worker is amazing
I sometimes found the appointments short and then they ran over and I got in trouble.

I spent 10 days at the Cleveland Clinichospital
 During that time I always felt safe and in good hands. All members of staff, from consultants to cleaning staff were always very polite and efficient. It made a very worrying time for me as pleasant as it could possibly have been.

I spent 2 weeks at Cleveland clinic and was very satisfied with my inpatient experience. Everyone was very welcoming and treated me as a real person rather than a number on a system. 

I would like to say special thanks to Chris (patient experience manager), nurses Angela and Harriet, assistants Stefania and Billy. They helped me a lot and made me feel so welcomed and appreciated!

I spent a total of 16 days and nights in the Cleveland Clinic across 2 stays in September. The first stay of 9 days was with pancreatitis and pancreatic fluid leak following an endoscopy ultrasound biopsy. The second stay was 7 days following a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy operation. Across both stays, which involved periods in the ICU, ACU and 5th floor, I was treated fantastically well by all the nurses, doctors and other members of staff. I can't thank them enough, particularly all the nurses who looked after me in the ICU, ACU and 5th floor. They're incredible. I wish I could name them all but I can't remember all their names.

I spent an hour in the waiting area(6.45 to 7.45 pm)
During this period the three receptionists had continuous noisy conversations which is not a calming atmosphere prior to a serious consultation.The eight empty dirty cups remained uncollected giving the area a sad neglected appearance.

I spoke to Jason Rogers at Mill Road Surgery and received exceptional care. I came regarding my struggles with OCD and he dealt with subject matter that was incredibly difficult for me to talk about, impeccably. I never once felt judged, and I was treated with the utmost compassion and kindness. I have been struggling with this for my whole adult life and to be able to talk specifically about my OCD in such a safe space was such a needed experience. Thank you so much, Jason.

I spoke with Aderonke Adebayo after being referred to her by my GP. She’s been compassionate, understanding and very easy to talk to and I can’t thank her enough for the help she’s given me. I was struggling with my mental health but I can now see the light at the end of the tunnel thanks to her efforts. I really appreciate all she’s done for me.

I stayed in ICU for 6 days after mitral and tricuspid valve repair, I could not have wished for a more caring service than I received. Both the surgical and nursing teams kept me advised of my progress at all times.

I stayed in one of the decompression rooms, which turns out to be quite noisy with alarm bells always going on when doors are opened. Also the flaps in the ventilation grate make an inconsistent noise which disturbs sleep.
The doors also proved to be really difficult for kitchen staff carrying  trays in and out of the room.
All the nursing staff are wonderfully caring and encouraging, but I felt that overall they were all young and inexperienced in a new work environment for the whole team as it only opened 6 months ago. I missed like a 'Matriarc', a mother figure leading her team. Compared to King Edward VII where I have had procedures before,  it was a more business like experience. 
And as an observation, it is striking that all the nursing/cleaning/reception staff are predominantly foreign, which sometimes causes a bit of a barrier in language, even if it is ever so subtle, to understand or be understood, but to be honest, that could have been aggravated by the masks! Their genuine care helps you through the days though and my thanks goes to them all! Too many names pop into my head, but I would feel bad if I'd left someone out accidentally so I won't mention anyone in particular.
I still do believe that although the therapy sessions were very helpful, I personally feel mine ended to soon for how I am
I still feel I could do with one more course of treatment.

I still feel that my daughter has neurodivergent traits 

I feel that early intervention will help repair and prevent the damage that can come from something that is so misunderstood.

I can almost guarantee if I pay privately for a diagnosis, there is definitely something.

I am not qualified to tell whether it be adhd or autism. But I am as a parent almost certain she is neurodivergent and providing her half sister is, and I suspect her father too aswell as my mother. I am almost certain I see huge reason for this.

Also the fact that I have been on extended holidays with friends who have neuro typical children - it has become hugely obvious and very sad to see on extended periods of close knit time. 

It is obvious to see Leas struggles and challenges. It has also been mentioned to me by a senco support worker who happens to be Leas best friends mum

I still had a flare up .....and i was asked to stop and contact the team again. That's a good approach. But I would like to have got reassessed and seen why certain exercise were difficult than others.
I still haven’t received a follow up note on the tests that I am suppose to get to try to help with my amenorrhea
I still miss more hands on approach.
I still simply cannot understand why I must check in so many times to get to my appointment. I’ve been coming here aince

I suffer with recurrent suicidal thoughts. I was told on my last session I wasn't going to kill myself because I would have done it by now. This was completely inappropriate, cruel and unhelpful. I was left feeling like I was a failure. I am now even more distressed and anxious. I am now sure that I will kill myself at some point but nobody cares.
I think 8 weeks is a bit to short  of time

I think CIOT would be more helpful if they were able to offer a longer time frame of sessions. At the minute, my care is changing quickly and I am worried about not having any support. I am happy that I have a check-in phone called booked.

I think I can only reiterate that whilst family may live a long way away they may still be very important to the patient and vice versa. In our case it has been really important to be able to be involved as much as we can be.

I think I had to start straight away and intensive therapy, because I have been struggling for a very long time. I did speak to another lady, that I didn’t feel cared much and I don’t think it helped me. I wish I didn’t waste that much time.
I think I learn a lot. Very personal to myself. Easy to understand.
I think I need deeper counselling but that isnt a criticism of Talking therapies.
I think I need surgery

I think I should have stayed in one more night and had discharge notes and perhaps some of the blood thinners and gout medication perhaps should have been continued also different pain relief as cocodamol doesn't  work and just leaves me constipated which because of lack of appetite gives me severe stomach pains and discomfort.

I think I was worrying about time and so felt that I didn't manage to ask all the questions I wanted to - maybe being really clear as to how much time we have with the specialists so that we can make ourselves comfortable.

I think I would have liked to have learnt more coping mechanisms and to have had more sessions and more intensive sessions. Even though I've been discharged my depression and anxiety scores have actually Risen from what they were when I started so I'm not actually in any better position than I was before.
I think I would like this session on regular basis or choose more than one session.  It would be good to have a list of foods that would be good for diabetics that are available on the supermarkets
I think Longer treatment up until my therapy was properly starting would’ve been great. However, I do understand it’s short term treatment.

I think Podiatry should go back to Wallet was before the pandemic as there are lots of us who can’t reach our feet I need help. I hope you consider this even if we have to pay £10 every time we came for treatment. Many thanks.
I think a cookery class
I think an email follow up between sessions just to prompt following the exercises or if any issues would be great to keep us all on track.

I think as I have said above I was happy with the overall way I was treated but I haven’t really gained too much from the time as my situation is very difficult to unwind and Perhaps more advice would have been helpful. I want to thank my therapist for I recognise she was very kind and sympathetic but I still don’t really know how to go forward other than what I am doing to put a more positive spin on my life.
I think at the end let us know that the nurse won’t be seeing me anymore, I felt I was left in limbo.

I think communication ahead of getting to the clinic really needs improvement. I tried to get in touch with the right people to book the test and appointment for over a week via email and phone (I called every day). All I managed to achieve is to finally get through to the general bookings line to book an appointment with my preferred cardiologist, but not the tests.

The tests were only booked when I emailed my cardiologist directly.

I would have appreciated a return call or at least an email back before my cardiologist established a new line of communication between myself and the admin staff. I think that this aspect is not yet up to standard and hope it will improve going forward
I think extra help was needed as I had a mental health issue and felt threatened by others. He needed to be taken to hospital for the mental health.
I think group therapy would be good .
I think have better communication with patients who are left waiting

I think having the garden view has help my mental health, after arriving from the JR which was very busy, I would like to say I have found Didcot to be very relaxing and calm.
The staff have been very good, must of the staff have been very friendly and supportive with me.
The food I would like to say has been general good, the meat has always been very tasty.
The domestic staff are very lovely and I think they over clean

I think i would of carried on for at least another couple of weeks with the physio looking and watching my progress, other than that happy  as their is a slight improvement on my balance and walking with the help and support and guidance.

I think if there would be anything , it would probably be to speak to her more often. I know that’s not possible as there’s a lot of people to fit into the week, but it would be nice as sometimes I forget to say some things and I need to wait until the next week.

I think it may be a bit better if the therapist in this first assessment maybe didn’t give too much personal advice! I appreciate that they are trying to help but I think the therapist telling myself about her husband leaving her etc did somewhat make my anxieties a little worse. 

This topic was definitely valid but I think giving direct advice without much information did increase my anxiety
I think it maybe good to meet at a central place to meet up for appointments.
I think it should be more informative tell customers to what they can do next ir try to solve their issue
I think it would be a good idea to discuss with the patient at the beginning what kind of help they need, because we are all different and not all the exercices are going to work with everyone.

I think it would be appropriate for staff treating post partum people to have training in breastfeeding as I do not think it’s appropriate to suggest giving up breastfeeding. It would at least be better to ask more around breastfeeding first to get an understanding of how important it is to the individual. Also if someone wants to give up breastfeeding they most likely will therefore the fact they breastfeed is a sign they want to

I think it would be good if everyone was offered a 1-2-1 or 1-2-2 session at the end of the programme to discuss the challenges they are facing and how to continue their journey. As weight is a touchy subject and a lot of us have huge shame around our weight, it is hard to be totally open in a group setting. A single session to consolidate where you aren't in a group setting could make a big difference to people I suspect.

I think it would be good to check at the start of treatment if people have a support network and how they might manage the feelings that are brought up by discussing traumatic experience.  A common result of trauma is that people can be isolated or in difficult circumstances and working through trauma can be very stressful and some people might need support with that. Also maybe say ahead of time or at the start of treatment that sometimes the clients appointment time might be changed because this can be difficult for people who are neurodivergent or who need stability to feel safe, or who have been punished by having things taken away.
I think it would be handy to have a clock in reception to see the time.

I think it would have been easier to have less homework and to focus on less but more concentrated therapies. I found the information helpful but trying to remember it all and do the homework would be difficult especially when life is busy with kids, work etc. Too much crammed in.

I think maybe more visits a week as my leg is very wet. I think this would help me out a lot as I can feel the dressings becoming very heavy. Visits are increased however then cancelled as there are not enough nurses. It would also help if nurses kept up with there stores as a lot of time the time we run out of dressings. It would also help if I could have a time of when the nurses are visiting (AM/PM).

I think maybe once the therapy has been given there could be an opportunity (if so required ) to meet with others who have been through similar experiences and trauma. I believe this could lead to more confidence in individuals and it would also be good as a networking tool. I understand the complexities of this so introducing maybe a couple of group meets may be a starting point (if people wish to take part)
I think more allocated time would have been nice.
I think more assessment of my trauma would be great, we also have only an hour to address all the issues, which I think is too short for me personally.

I think more of your care staff need training and understanding of mental health and neurodiversity. It felt like they were working from old models and it felt like they didn't understand neurodiversity even compared to myself and they're qualified. 

The staff was giving me toxic positive feedback "Just try to think positively, try not to focus on your negatives" - It doesn't actually help people in distress and just makes it worse.

They need to learn new ways of dealing with people not their old models and ways of thinking.

I think more time could have been taken at the outset to assess my needs. It would appear that the expectation on staff is to make an immediate decision on the appropriate treatment, which may not always be reasonable. I think it would have been beneficial to have a more detailed assessment. 

I went with the suggestion and the treatment, as you are the experts and I trust that this will be right. Whilst I do have anxiety and self esteem issues and the treatment was beneficial and I cannot fault the professional consultant that gave that treatment, I am now seeking alternative treatment to address the main issue that I sought your assistance. 

Neither do I think any blame should be placed on the consultant who took the initial call as they will be under pressure to make a decision. 

Having said all of this, when I accessed the service a few years ago, it was very challenging to get through the initial stages with a long wait time to start. I am aware that there is probably high demand at the moment and there may be limited resources. I think you may not have the balance right yet to meet the needs of individuals whilst keeping the wait times down.

I think my experience was unusual given the unfortunate circumstances with my therapist, and would otherwise say that everyone I came across and supported me was exceptional. 

Greater clarity around my chosen therapy would have aided my expectations as I was expecting a slightly different experience (as noted above).
I think my specialist nurse Karen at the Leigh Community Heart Failure Clinic was amazing, thorough, patient kind, a good listener and a good professional.

I think my time so far is good and it help in some way  but still early days as I’ve only been here for 24 hour food not do bad and the people have been  nice so far and very friendly  to me  in my stay so far

I think my time so far is good and it help in some way but still early days as I’ve only been here for 24 hour food not do bad and the people have been nice so far and very friendly to me in my stay so far

I think perhaps a one to one catch up in the middle of the course. I felt that at this time I was becoming a bit low and delving into difficult and challenging emotions which could have helped talking it through. Although this may just have been because of the break for half term, I’m not sure.
I think probably one course is not enough as Diabetics need on going updated infomation and should attend courses yearly or 2 yearly like Eye tests and everthing else to do with thid condition
I think service I received today was very good the girl I spoke to and her colleague were very friendly and very put me at Very at ease
I think sessions could have continued over a longer period of time as I feel they was ended quite abruptly when I could have done with that little bit of support.
I think some employment options could have been presented to me
I think somethings could have been explained more.

I think that it is important that male members of staff do not refer to their colleagues as 'the girls'. In this case 'the girls' were an eminent cardiologist and a skilled specialist Nurse. In the current climate of opinion this loose expression sounds patronizing and misogynistic, and will cause offence to some patients.

I think that it would be better to tailor the time between visits to the age of the patient.  I am 82 and walk with a rollator.  Last year I spent two months in bed with ulcers on my leg caused by the effects of earlier surgery.  When I eventually was able to walk around I was virtually unable to walk.  I began to walk around the house every day to strengthen my legs.  To begin with I could only manage three laps.  Now I can do eight laps but that has taken nine months so it seems to me that two weeks between visits is too short to expect to see much improvement in a person of my age.

I think that it would have been better to have group sessions to make the accommodation have a community feel and to also help others there have a better understanding of what they need to move forward and equip them with the tools needed to not make the home a permanent position for them.

I think that it would have helped me if i was provided with greater explanation of the treatment i was about to receive so that i felt more involved and understood the reasons why i was being asked to do things. 
The catering was a bit hit and miss. The first evening meal was very good but the roast chicken lunch the nect day was dry and tough whilst the potatoes were undercooked. My choice for the evening meal the second day was not available but the alternative was good. My breakfast the next day did not arrive so i had to chase it up and received it at 10.15am. I was not offered lunch on the last day.
I think that more of this type of session would benefit me.

I think that people should be advised of the  terrific noise that  is incurred whilst 
being scanned.I found it hard not to activate the cessation of the scan but knew if I did the whole procedure would be a waste of time.

I think that the responses provided  are too broad in the questionnaires and there should be another category ie ‘sometimes or occasionally’ between ‘not at all’ and ‘several times’ as some of my responses would have been ‘sometimes’ but I had to answer ‘several times’.
I think that the service (Talking Therapies) is a little hit and miss depending very much on the individual therapist. This one, [name removed], was very good, very kind and empathetic.

I think that when I’m depressed it would be good for CMHT to check in with me weekly. CBT is time limited. When I’m depressed it sometimes hard to get through. There are often issues with the phone lines.
I think that you could email with cancellations those in the list to fill your cancelled slots

I think the  physio was poor. In my case it consisted of asking  if I understood the log roll and a walk around the corridors and stair evaluation. More info could be given on the physio sheet. I looked up what not to do on the internet and I think it was John Hopkins which gave illustrations on how to bend , go to the loo etc.More practical tips needed. Eg how to get into the car, LONDON taxi. 
I have been doing exercises before the op and would have liked the opportunity to explore what exercise schedule I should adopt in the following weeks.

In addition no written info on when to remove surgical stockings

I also think more discussion should be had about pain  and paracetamol . My back is stiff and aches but that is normal after an op. If you feel that you modify your activities. However if drugged up yoiu may not feel the ache and over extend oneself.

I think the appointment center should priority over patients paying for their service, when we are expected to have a call then this should be followed through.  We are not NHS patients. Having private medical care, as patients' priority should be given to those with medical needs and paying for the service. 

Thanks!
I think the carers are sincere and careful and attention.
I think the content of the course was exactly right. Zoom meetings can be a bit of a mare with people having tech issues but everything was running smoothly very quickly.

I think the healthcare professionals are used to the procedures everyday but not the patients. They should be more kind and try to be in the patients shoes, understanding that it is a very uncomfortable moment to have a IUD implanted, for example. 
They should remember that it is not everybody that feel ok to answer intimate questions in front of others. A different way to collect information should be provided (paper form, tablet, or send the question by email previously the appointment).
Some garment should be provided to the patient when they ask to have the clothes off. Again some patients will feel uncomfortable to be naked in front of strangers.
Finally, they must provided the treatment leaflet according to the treatment provided. Patients can get confused and also report adverse event to the wrong company.
I think the homework could have been more engaging.
I think the instructions with regard to the change in Lithium dosage should have been clearer. Also I should have checked verbally with the consultant.

I think the main consultation could have been longer in explaining how the procedure was being carried out. 
Was very great full for Doctor to see me after surgery at my request even if it was for 2 minutes 

Excellent care.
I think the nurse was kind and considerate

I think the nursing staff were outstanding on the 5th Floor, they all worked as a team, were kind, caring, considerate, helpful, particularly Emma and Erin totally amazing. From the nursing team to catering staff and the porter Babs they were all 1st class, I could not have received better care. The best hospital that I have ever had surgery in. It was also my birthday on the day of my surgery and a couple of days later the chef made me a birthday cake which was amazing and and a great example of making the experience for me as a patient exceptional.

I think the online for at can make it difficult to engage - whilst it's understandable why online is the most effective way to deliver the group, perhaps more break out rooms so that there's a smaller group for discussion.

I think the online portal system could be improved. I got an onslaught of 12 emails the day before my apt. I opened one which asked questions which had already been answered weeks before, but there was not way to continue the questionnaire without ticking a box which wasn't relevant for me. It's nice to have the results all in one place, but I prefer to have emails of the dr. also in order to contact them directly.

I think the only thing I could say is try and offer more options at the start. I was offered a mentor and SilverCloud, or group sessions. I don’t feel like either of these would appeal to some people so could stop them getting help. So offering these in the first instance would be fine but be good to know further options depending on what issues came to light (like what happened with me!).
I think the only thing that would have improved my sessions would be coping strategies to deal with my ongoing anxiety.
I think the patients sensitivity should be taken into consideration when delivering health care.
I think the reason I never got to the end of the modules was because they in themselves were making me overthink everything about me , but saying that it did help me so I thank you for that

I think the risk of bleeding after colonoscopy should be explained clearly to the patients after the procedure. Other than that, I think the team was excellent and did their best to take care of me. They were all kind and professional.
I think the sessions were good and there isn't anything that could been done better.
I think the staff on this ward are amazing, they have been so helpful for me when I've needed to talk. I feel safe here.
I think the talk at the end was very basic but understand it needs to cater for a wide experience of exercise.
I think the time given is very limited because there is a lot to talk about.I’m going through a lot and need someone to talk to always.

I think the timescales for the programmes should be extended as children who are  especially like my daughter who struggle to verbalise and open up need that longer time than 12 weeks. My daughters second therapist was very text book with her approach and we felt was run of a script rather then the help myself and my daughter was asking for.
I think there could have been more understanding for someone losing their independence.
I think there is more need to acknowledge the mental health with pain. And the impact of taking pain medication. How you feel about yourself changes. But I’ve not finished all the course yet.
I think there is perhaps some room for improvement in the provision made for the care and understanding of general medical patients with co-morbid psychiatric difficulties.
I think this is a broad subject and maybe having a longer session to help explore ideas in depth would be beneficial, or to point participants in the right direction.
I think this is a fantastic clinic with caring expert care. Thank you very much.
I think this process has given me lots of ideas and understanding to why I have been feeling the way i have, [name removed] has allowed me to express all my emotions without judgement.

I think to get the benefit off this courses across all patients who need this information maybe these classes should be offered in different languages as well. I came home and talked about what I learned with my parents and there friends who are diabetic and the response was overwhelming.
I think to understand FND better and to give appropriate advice and treatment. I am getting progressively woke and I think they didn't understand, this apparent by their final report.
I think when paperwork from hospital you are notified straight away not 5 days later.
I think when someone is suffering with depression Never ask are they thinking to take their own lives. Because it’s not a good question and they might getting started to think about it like me.
I think with the massage there should be assisted stretches to improve the movement to make the movement extended.
I think you can probably get the idea from my above answer.
I think you could be check me every week to see how I was doing

I think you should have regular counselling / psychotherapy specifically for people with issues such as Asperger's by people who really understand these conditions. There is no regular support at all for adults with these difficulties.

I think you they could explained why to me. I had to ask { } to find my clothes for me. I was very close with them.
I hope I do not what to go for any think at the moment. I hope you will do things better { }.
I thoroughly enjoyed all aspects of this course. Trainers were excellent. Open/honest approach. Relatable.
I thought I'd have someone who cared, not someone who would talk to me the way [name removed] did.
I thought it was delivered very well, sensitively and with respect. It couldn't be improved Thank you : )
I thought overall excellent, greeting and check in were exceptional.  nursing very good and consultant excellent
I thought that the care that I received at the Cleveland Clinic was exceptional and could not have been improved.

I thought that the welcome from the moment I set foot inside the building until I left was exemplary, including all medical and non medical staff.

I have been to many private London clinics and hospitals and I can honestly say that so far the feeling of care was the best that I have received.
I just hope it will be maintained and not just because it’s recently opened.

I will certainly recommend the Cleveland Clinic and wouldn’t hesitate to return should I ever need to.
I thought that these sessions would be done face to face. Got told that after 1 session that the rest would be over the phone.

I thought the administrator spoke a little out of turn (as she divulged information that was non conclusive, and not quite factual…so it left me a little confused and anxious before my treatment).  Still very nice and pleasant, but maybe leave all discussions regarding health care to the professionals. 

But the actual nurse and her trainee were absolutely excellent.  Thanks again.
I thought the cardiac rehab course was excellent and actually made enjoyable

I thought the care I received from AAU, to the 5th floor and then to ICU could really not be better. If anything went wrong it was sorted I was always kept informed and for someone who is not easy to impress I could not be more happy with my service and treatment. Angela on the 5th floor is a credit to you as are all the nurse and care assistants I have dealt with over the 6 days which although I have been in a lot of pain and discomfort just made things so much easier

I thought the care and service that I got was outstanding  and friendly.
I was impressed with your premises both at Grosvenor Place and Portland Place.  I chose to see the expert on my knee damage and was 100 % satisfied.  My specialist was Mr Dinish Nathwani and the Physio he sent me to was excellent too as were your MRI specialists.  Thank you.
I thought the care was efficient , and all staff did everything they could to explain things and make my stay as comfortable as possible

I thought the care was exceptional . I had every confidence in my Consultant Mr N Mushtaq. He provided me with all the information I needed to decide this was the appropriate time for surgery and listened carefully to tailor the surgery to what we both felt I needed . He showed a compassion that made me confident he would do the best he could whatever he found and that he takes a pride on what he dies . This is important  las a patient when you feel anxious about an elective procedure .
  The anaesthetist inspired confidence and provided a good post op analgesic block , which I was pre warned about so not alarmed . 
The whole of the nursing team were caring compassionate , prompt to respond (with an attitude that nothing was too much trouble) and everything was done with a smile .
 The physiotherapist and Sean the CNS provided great encouragement . 
In my opinion the whole team is a team to be proud of.
The environment is calm,  and extremely clean . Apart from the ability to part close my blinds I have no other suggestions on how it could have been improved . The food was very good with a good choice . 
This whole approach makes surgery and the recovery  much less daunting . Thank you !
I thought the care was second to none.  The only thing I would improve on is informing the patient on the medication on timings especially if there is multiple medications.
I thought the facilities and staff were excellent

I thought the facilities were good.  The downstairs reception, staff and the admission staff with super polite and attentive   the care staff were excellent in delivering Care to me during my stay. they were very supportive and kind and explained everything to me.   I did find when staff came into the room. They knocked briefly, but then just carried on walking in rather than ask if it was okay and wait. This meant on a couple of occasions I was caught off guard getting changed. I found this a little difficult, especially with the male members of staff.  There was a little bit of a breakdown of communication between the male physiotherapist who arrived in my room. The nurse had pulled out my covers and was about to take my dressing to replace them with a lighter dressing. She left briefly to get something. then the physiotherapist knocked briefly and walked in He asked me what was going on. I found I had to explain I was waiting for my dressings to be changed I thought perhaps he should’ve been in communication with the nurse before he came into the room. I also felt a little bit uncomfortable as I was not in a position of complete modesty. and was caught off guard.

I thought the general standard of food was good and the service staff were extremely polite and helpful in trying to find suitable choices for me. However, I think you need to make more provision for patients feeling the effects of pain relief medication on appetite (nausea/sickness etc). More choice of soups/yoghurts/very light meals in small portions (you can't eat the same chicken soup every day). I wasted a lot of food because I could only eat a few mouthfuls at a time. 

The advice on nutrition was at odds with some of the advice from nursing staff and I felt it was sometimes a bit patronising, although I appreciate that the person giving it had my best interests at heart. 

Physios were very helpful, but didn't always liaise with nursing staff about what was going on medically. On one occasion got me up at the wrong time and made me very sick from over exertion. Once I realised that it was important to balance getting up and about with physical limitations, I felt able to suggest rescheduling sessions if I felt they were at the wrong time..

I thought the initial talk about smoking was a bit strange as we were not asked if we smoked, but having listened to the talk I realised that if we had been asked the question it could have been embarrassing for some people and it also dealt with passive smoking which can be a problem, so no, there was nothing that could have been better.
I thought the service was professional and helpful.
I thought the staff were amazing and friendly, however it took me multiple days to receive a drop-in appointment.
I thought the toilet facilities could be better/cleaner. I did not receive any information about costs, but I did not ask!
I thought the whole service was courteous and efficient and I found Dr Gomez exemplary in the degree of his care and the clarity of his advice.
I thought there might have been more insights about what jobs I may be suitable for and also what jobs are available. The practical side of things
I thought they did a good job and are friendly.
I thought they were appropriate questions.
I thought they would have admitted me but surprised they did not. Went to bed every night thinking she was going to die

I took another appointment to get some information and perhaps the hospital outcome statistics could be published with a UK benchmark would go a long way in more confidence in Cleveland Clinic. For example I need an ascending aorta surgery and Professor Wendler was kind to give me the data but there has to be a way to make it more accessible to would be patients.

I took my Daughter, after referral from 111. My daughter lives in Cardiff, having been at uni there and stayed there. She has been battling with mental health but it is getting harder to keep her safe.  She has harmed herself, took too many tablets, used alcohol etc to stop voices in head etc and goes to a and e in Cardiff, gets seen and sent home again. Therefore I brought her home to look after her till better. However today, please excuse if spelt wrong,  Dr Masood spent time talking to us but was unable to treat my daughter, Katie, as she is still registered in Cardiff.  But Dr spent time to explain the reason and also the help that could be offered back in Cardiff or if Katie re-registered with Drs in Benfleet. I was so grateful for the amazing time spent explaining everything but am left dumbfounded by the system and that despite the help needed, as you are not registered in the area, but in Cardiff, further treatment could not be offered in more detail unless re-register, and even then it could still take time for systems to take registration back. I totally understand the explanation and that it is not Drs fault but this is unbelievable how these decisions are made and how an unsafe individual can be left in limbo whilst away from home. In saying that, huge thanks to Dr for kindness and time spent explaining everything and different options that may be useful going forward.

I took my extremely anxious son to the vaccination centre (riverwalk Bury st Edmunds) Nurse Louise was so kind, patient, calm and professional. She gave him time and empathy and he had his vaccination with no stress at all. This will make coming back for his second dose much easier. I am very grateful to everyone working at the centre on Saturday, it was very well organised.
I took some time to get started.
I trust the doctor
I trust the professionality of the doctor. I could make all my questions and get an answer. For one particular question the doctor did not want to give his opinion.
I understand everyone is busy but waiting times I think need to be addressed.
I understand it may not be possible but a set time and day/days each week.

I understand the job is stressful but not every person is the same. I am an active person who has been impacted by chronic back pain. This has impacted my life and I need help to get back on track. 
In this appointment a bit of empathy would have helped.
I have never complained before but this appointment was an awful experience,

I understand the policy that restricts treatment to those that are in the UK however, I believe there should be some flexibility in this with options to allow for holidays or family emergencies so as not to interrupt the flow of therapy and/or delay it, especially when all sessions are on-line. Just based on what I know, I would suggest someone review the average length of the period of therapy and evaluate what might be a realistic allowance. Maybe there are reasons why this won't work but they were never well-explained or seemed sensible to me.
I understood most of what they were telling me and they gave good advice.
I understood most things that was said in the class. It was also entertaining as well as educational.
I understood the advice perfectly faith was calm and collected and gave me logical tip on how to manage expectations.
I understood the experience and the lady helped me.
I understood what was going on

I underwent a triple bypass surgery at the Cleveland Clinic in July 2023. My case was far from straight forward - I wouldn't have made it through a life changing procedure without the skills and support of Mr. Baghai and his team at the Cleveland Clinic The Consultants and Doctors have a tremendous reputation for their world-class skills and experience (rightly so) but I really want take the opportunity to highlight the care and support I received from the nursing staff at the Cleveland Clinic.  • Jezel C set the tone for my positive experience with the nursing staff on the day of my angiogram on 29th June.  • Straight after the bypass surgery on 12th July I was amazed how Ruth, Von, & Avril looked after me in the ICU. I may have given the ICU nurses a hard time ;) while I was sedated, you guys were outstanding professionals. • My stay on the 5th floor recovery ward lasted around 2 weeks and it was incredible how comfortable the nursing staff made and my family feel. I felt like I was among friends and family rather than a hospital environment. Cassandra, Jenny, Victoria, Damien, Ela, Carmen, Rosa, Aris, Mackenzie (and Mackenzie American roommate whose name I now forget) blurred the lines between professionalism and going over and above to look after me.  • The care I received from Cassandra was super special – almost there by my bedside before I called for help, the most gentle and caring hands. Thank you Cass, you’re like my little daughter now. • And Jenny – thank you for arranging an air blower in the middle of the night. • The Health care assistants - Naomi, Frank, Riya – thank you for looking after me with such kindness. • Fellows/Doctors/Specialist Nurses – Helen Thompson, Joseph Okaphor, Artur Kowalczyk, Eric Jackson – your professionalism and care will always be remembered.  • I was super impressed by the structured preparation Jessica Bivand, Shola, Simone (phlebotomy  Cleveland’s Outpatient) provided – really helped build my confidence. I’m sure I’ve inadvertently forgotten to mention a few names for which I apologise.  A large part of my recovery is down to the care I received at the Cleveland Clinic. You guys are great at your jobs and making a difference to people’s lives, probably more than you realise, keep up the great work.

I very much appreciated the care and compassion from Dr Farrell. She was patient, helpful, and methodical in her advice. I cannot imagine going to anyone else, if I have to see a neurologist again! She made me feel supported and important.   I also saw a doctor who conducted my nerve conduction test and I can't remember his name. But he was excellent. He was patient, friendly, and calm when I probably was highly anxious during the procedure and far too chatty. I am grateful for his kindness and also his feedback during the procedure. He could not have been more attentive.

I very much hope the follow up to my consultation results in prompt action as my knee pain had been considerably worse since the appointment on Tuesday . I would appreciate hearing personally what is happening.

I visited Dr Nathan on Saturday 8th October. During my stay I was looked after by Tahir and Andrea (healthcare assistants) who provided exceptional care and attention. They both went out of their way to try and find a slot for a scan and throughout my time they communicated clearly, effectively and were extremely professional.

I subsequently had a scan which was the first one available at 8am 10th October. There was a short delay but this was explained by reception. The radiologist Dr Papadopoulou was through with her findings and communicated throughout the scan which I appreciated. 

Having previously attended HCA London bridge the week before for a consultation and scan I noticed a clear disparity in the quality of care and service and this is largely down to the staff that I saw (Dr Nathan, Dr Papadopoulou and special mention to healthcare assistants Tahir and Andrea)

I visited Holly Wheelchair Service today (14/11/23) because I have been struggling with my current wheelchair (which was causing me physical pain) and which had become difficult for my carers and hospital staff to handle, which caused me significant guilt and reticence in terms of asking to use it (which in effect meant that I wasn't able to go out on the rare occasions on which I was well enough) and had become a somewhat intractable situation, particularly as my health and mobility has unfortunately continued to deteriorate and I needed help. 

The service over all was fantastic! I discussed my concerns with Penny via a telephone appointment who was compassionate, knowledgeable and most importantly listened to me and clearly wanted to help as much as possible and I then received an in person appointment within 2 months, which I feel is perfectly reasonable, given the current climate of relentless pressure on our NHS. I attended the appointment today and was surprised and frankly thrilled with the staff I met and how much these selfless and dedicated people wanted to help me. 

Firstly there was a slight delay, but for the first time ever in terms of potential delays, it wasn't a bad one! It was because they had taken the time to fully read my notes and they understood that I was immunocompromised and taking immunosuppressant medications and therefore wore a mask and David the Engineer for my appointment was hearing impaired and lip reads. So rather than cause any discomfort or awkwardness for me or just as importantly for him, they tried first to find ways to work around this, which was an unusual level of consideration Anywhere in todays society and refreshing to boot, I can't tell you how rare it is to experience that level of thoughtfulness from people.

This engendered me with trust and I felt completely safe and happy (on my own recognisance of course) to help my wheelchair engineer too help me, by removing my mask and I have to say, he blew me away. David was confident, reassuring, knowledgeable, personably kind, likeable and technically expert in his field. 

David communicated clearly, got down to the crux of the issues quickly and had me in a more appropriate and much more comfortable wheelchair very promptly, which he then set about proficiently adjusting to accommodate my physical condition. He made sure my footplates where correctly adjusted to accommodate for one leg being longer than the other due to spinal issues and installed my head rest (minutely to perfection) which I've never quite had right before, to account for the way my body is positioned and my need for head support as I become fatigued. 

For the first time ever I was truly comfortable in a chair which helped my self esteem issues about needing one in the first place and my posture was much healthier as well. I felt more secure and well positioned and the chair was much better for my duty carer to push and move around which made her happier as well. 

The chair did need some slight amendments however and both David and the Manager (who was also charming, polite, kind and helpful) sought to find a sensible solution within the constraints of the guidelines for us which they did achieve. 

I went home with a huge smile on my face and a much more comfortable attendant controlled wheelchair to use (I'm not able to operate a self propelled one), while a similar one with alterations is ordered / fabricated. I have a feeling my carers might be taking me out more (much to their chagrin) and it means less time bed or chair bound and most importantly, less pain. 

David really shone today in terms of clinicians and experts I've met during my deteriorating health and he must absolutely make his colleagues and peers, as well as his family proud I'm sure, because he certainly made me proud of Holly Wheelchair Service and the NHS today. He has a level of technical expertise and confidence seldom found in any field.

The support and kindness of the Manager as well, was so appreciated. I woke up today with extremely low blood pressure, unwell with the tail end of an infection and significant pain and therefore dreaded any appointment, but to my surprise I genuinely enjoyed my time at the service and left smiling and grateful for what we do have in terms of Healthcare Provision and for the first time in awhile not just melancholic about what we have lost. 

Thank You so much especially to David and indeed all the Staff and management at Holly Wheelchairs. Your jobs are clearly extremely difficult, but you do them so very well and it made a bigger difference to my wellbeing today, more than just the excellent chair alone. Apologies if this praise seems excessive or may be embarrassing to read, but I'm not one to keep my feelings quiet and it's how both I and my carer felt. In one word (unusually for me: Impressed) make it two words: Grateful. Thank You.

I visited the hospital for my check up appointment. 
The trains were all delayed, cancelled or too busy to get on. So although we should have been 50 minutes early, we were about 5 minutes late. I had been able to contact the hospital and warn them we would be late. This was easily done and not an issue. 
It was lovely to see so many familiar faces. Visiting the hospital is a bit like coming home now, everyone is so friendly, happy and welcoming.

I visited the minor injuries unit after a referral via 111. 

When I arrived the nurse at reception was very kind and lovely. She welcomed me and was approachable . 

The nurse who was responsible for my treatment however, seemed indifferent about my situation. He did offer options for treatment and it was clear that I was nervous and worried but he didn’t offer any words of reassurance. Instead i got “up to you” and “it depends”  as a response for every question I asked. I understand  medical professionals may not have all the answers but I didn’t feel comforted or at ease.

He asked me if had cleaned my wound and I informed him I had only cleaned with a damp cotton pad however, I’m  concerned he didn’t offer to clean my wound himself given how deep it was. 

I just got the feeling he wanted me out asap.
I waited 30mins for an X-ray. I was left alone in the reception area with no-one around to give me any information.
I waited a long time to park even though I came early have been warned about the parking problems here.

I waited an hour after my appointment for a blood test.  The nurses were wonderful kind and skilful but we shouldn’t be waiting anywhere that long in a hospital that charges what you do for care. Especially for something as quick as taking bloods.

My actual pre op was on time and great again. Disappointing that this then happened.
I waited close to 4 months for this appointment and I was wrongly referred to treat a chest pain that I did not receive support . I still waiting to know what will happen
I waited over 24 hours or a phone call back from GP when I was told it would be within 2 hours!!
I want 2 times a month to be checked my health and about my pain .
I want to highlight 3 nurses who were professional attentive and warm: Thomas, Marie and Stephanie. Giselle arrived later but was good too

I want to make a complaint about my check out process. The nurse who did my discharge was exceptional and couldn’t be faulted, extremely intelligent, kind and empathetic. However, the Porter that came to collect me was quite frankly frightening. He seemed extremely angry, agitated, and frustrated. He was very rough, and I initially thought he was playing a joke, as he came  out with  the wheelchair at such a speed, slammed the footplates down, almost onto my feet, and then manhandled my feet onto the foot plates, very roughly indeed. I then asked him to stop that behaviour together with the nurse and asked him to calm down. The nurse kindly push the wheelchair as I think she felt worried that he was going to do that job and he took the baggage. I was feeling extremely vulnerable having just had a full knee replacement on the Monday.  I noticed going through a doorway, the bags fell over, and he roughly stacked them up again, and carried on, pushing them down to the street . When I got the bags out of the car, I noticed that the leather strap was broken on my Louis Vuitton hand luggage. I don’t mean to be causing any trouble for this gentleman. But if he was going to behave in this way with a truly vulnerable person, It would frankly be very worrying. I would be happy for you to contact me directly to discuss this.

I want you to know that I hold consultant Georgina Russell in very high regard. She’s the one who really put two and two together and organised the appropriate tests etc to find out what has been going on with me for years.

I wanted a safety plan. I waited a long time.
A different room would be ideal
I have claustrophobia

I wanted to express my gratitude for the exceptional care I received during my recent stay at your hospital. From the moment I arrived until my discharge, every member of your team demonstrated unwavering professionalism, compassion, and expertise.

The level of attentiveness and dedication shown by the nurses, doctors, and support staff was wonderful. Their kindness and willingness to go above and beyond made a significant difference 

The facility's cleanliness was evident throughout my stay, contributing to an environment conducive to healing and recovery.

Thank you once again for your exceptional service. I am truly grateful for the outstanding care provided by the Cleveland Hospital.
I wanted to get the help and needed more time to express my feeling

I wanted to provide some detailed feedback regarding my recent ultrasound appointment at your facility on February 27th.
Upon my arrival at 8:10 am for an 8:30 am appointment, I found the reception area on the 2nd floor of Portland Place to be adequately staffed, with three individuals behind the desk, all wearing black shirts. Among them, Anna stood out as she was attentive and helpful throughout my visit. Her assistance during the scan was particularly appreciated.
However, I observed that the other two male staff members were engaged in casual conversations about TV shows, current news events, and miscellaneous topics, such as discussing the merits of different types of beards. They were also browsing through videos on their computer and mobile phones. One of the males, the Filipino gentleman, and the South Asian with a beard and glasses seemed to be particularly engrossed in their conversation, frequently bursting into laughter as they joked with each other. 
Their laughter and jokes seemed more suited to a social gathering rather than a professional healthcare environment. While their behavior did not significantly impact my experience since I was the only patient present at the time, I felt it important to bring to your attention as it may affect the professionalism perceived by other patients, especially during busier periods.
I understand that a relaxed atmosphere can sometimes contribute to a comfortable environment for patients, but maintaining a balance between friendliness and professionalism is crucial, especially in a healthcare setting.
Overall, I appreciate the service provided by Anna and the attention to my needs during the appointment. However, I believe addressing the behavior of the other staff members could enhance the overall patient experience at your facility.
Thank you for considering my feedback, and I look forward to seeing improvements in the future.
I wanted to see people on line not just blank circles. More encouragement from Tutors for participation from clients
I wanted to thank Lola and the psychology team. I know they are here when I need to talk to sometimes, and it is nice having someone to talk with.

I wanted to write a review to reflect the views of a close relative who lives in a different country from the patient who has been assisted by the social worker and team atArden Memory & Dementia Sevice South Warks.
I live in New Zealand and my sister who lives in Warwickshire became unwell in 2020. As her condition was dementia it has progressed over the three years and she has needed quite a lot of assistance during the various phases of her illness.
The local social worker has been excellent in working with my sister and in keeping us informed regularly as to what care/support has been offered. We established a really good link via email so we have been able to seek clarification and get help in understanding the processes and the options This has been through difficult times with Covid restrictions and my sisters developing difficulties. Of course we have been anxious so it has been so helpful to have this link.
The information she has provided has kept us up to date and helped us enormously.

I was 7minutes late to an appointment once due to technical difficulties joining the call, the therapist was quite upset by this and advised that we have a strict schedule to stick to and discussions and topic points to adhere to, this I understand, however the way in which she went about explaining this was abrupt and I felt very upset by the way she had treated me. There must be some flexibility in these sessions, especially if we are going through topics of a sensitive nature.

I was Aisle to get an appointment fairly quickly. My back issue was { }pected I was fairly a little anxious about { } initially. Physio (Steve) explained more or less what had happened, listened to my worries and ideas me gave me exercises could manage, explained their purpose clearly, gave encouragement was realistic.

I was a day patient on level 1 day unit. From the moment I walked in the stress and worry I’d the procedure went away with the expert planning organisation and the care I received. The compassion and support from all staff is commendable. The anaesthetics team on the day were excellent as were the nursing team on the wars and in theatre.

I was a little in the dark about what was required of me pre-op -  i.e. whether I needed to be nil by mouth and for how many hours and what that meant exactly. Otherwise, the care that I received at the hospital was excellent.

I was a very nervous patient having never had previous surgery (bar tonsils as a child) and the whole team made me more comfortable. Facilities were excellent, food choice and quality was exemplary. You also looked after my wife really well and communicated straight away with her.
I was able to ask questions and feel good that I could asset myself and feel independent I was offered thanks to Dr. Topiwala. Separate time to talk privately.
I was able to ask questions when necessary and the physiotherapist was very knowledgeable about my condition.
I was able to be open and honest.

I was able to book an appointment with my consultant very promptly.  My consultant explained everything to me really well, he talked me through the detail of a scan report I had at another hospital and explained how he would take it forward.  He filled me with confidence -  whatever the outcome I know that he will have explored all options available to me. You were able to download scans from a different hospital from a disc as I waited.  Overall a great, helpful and professional service. Thank you!
I was able to get a GP appointment on the same day, the GP was thorough and communicated clearly and followed up with me very promptly after an ultra sound scan

I was absolutely amazed that I had any aftercare as it was it was more team I expected.
The care was perfect fitted to my needs, kind and considerate.
I was absolutely blown away by my experience at The Cleveland Clinic. I felt so looked after and cared for and staff was super friendly and did anything they could to make sure I was comfortable.

I was admitted on the 18th which was too late for the initial procedure which was scheduled for 3pm but my flight was delayed. I ordered food at 6.30.  Did not receive it until nearly 9pm!!!  The procedure was rescheduled for 8am 19th. NBM.  At 10am told was cancelled because no Anaesthetist could be found!  A hospital of your calibre having no available Anaesthetic professionals available…. What a joke! Told it was rescheduled 6pm.. quick lunch then NBM
Finally after not eating or more importantly drinking I was taken down at 7.30pm totally dehydrated!!! What’s complete fiasco!

I was admitted to have an angiogram with the expectation of having a stent fitted. In the event the clinician decided that a stent was not needed.
I was advised that this was good news and I should continue to control my angina with medication and exercise.
I was a little shocked and surprised by this and on reflection I would have welcomed a more detailed explanation behind the decision and support in coming to terms with it. I should have taken the initiative but was a bit below par recovering from the procedure.

I was admitted very unexpectedly after coming for heart tests. I ended up having to have a pacemaker fitted. It was a rather shocking few days but the doctors , nurses and hospital staff were excellent. My only criticism was the food. The portions were enormous and all courses were served together. For example , I ordered soup, a main meal and ice cream Everything was served together and by the time you finished the starter and main meal the ice cream would be melted.
I was advised that there would be. 15 min delay to my consultation but in practice it was a lot longer and there was no contact to explain this.
I was always dealt with compassionately and professionally

I was always treated with respect and consideration and received excellent advice which helped to give me confidence to go outdoors and live more normal life. I am very grateful for the help I was given since leaving hospital thank you.
I was always treated with total respect and kindness and also respect for my injuries.

I was asked repeatedly to give the same information about my health by different members of staff, beginning with the pre-op assessment at 24 Portland Place on 2 August and continuing into the Grosvenor Clinic on 4 August.  There seemed to be a lack of communication between the different departments, despite advanced technology. 

Not all staff seemed to have mastered the technology with which the hospital is so well equipped.

The room means of controlling the temperature of the air-conditioning where I was located was poorly designed.  It gave patient and staff inadequate control.  This is a defect that has been reported by staff to no avail.

It would be good to give the patient a small bedside table for personal belongings, such as phone and reading matter.

It would be better if the blinds on the window could be partially opened and closed instead of only fully open or closed.

I was asked to be at the Clinic at 7am, it was over 6 hours before I was taken for surgery, with no explanation. I was left to assume someone’s need was greater than mine, which I accept unreservedly. What was disappointing was that  I was told not to unpack as I was moving rooms to the other side. My room was not reading in the six hours before surgery so I was unable to unpack. On this occasion  my husband had to leave as I was taken for surgery, so nothing was unpacked. 
This was unlike my previous visits.

I was asked to come in early for my MRI scan, I arrived at 6.30, checked in at the main reception and then went down to the basement. I didn't see a single staff member for an hour, I went back to the main reception who didn't know what to do and couldn't get through to Imaging. I also called your number and the lady, whilst helpful, also couldn't get through to Imaging. It was a complete waste of my time and I should have just come at my original appointment time of 7.30. I was then called to ask where I was, and promptly picked up when I told them I had been there the whole time. Apparently the main reception had never checked me in despite me going to them twice, and the MRI staff hadn't bothered to check reception. For a private healthcare service this is unacceptable.

I was asked to wear a mask when my appointment was made and then had to sit in the waiting room filled with people not wearing a mask. 
Not good.
I was at all times treated with care and respect and received excellent advice from the the orthopaedic doctor I saw - Dr Batty.

I was at the Outpatients Department for the removal of staples from my wound. The Clinic environment was comfortable , bright and airy.  Everything was very smoothly dealt with. My appointment with Dr Christine Howis was timely.  She removed the staples very skillfully and changed the dressing.  She also gave advice re medication. I experienced no pain. Mr Rajaratnam popped in to view the wound and to give follow-up advice.
I was away for 10 days within my allotted time so feel I missed out on my time.

I was booked to have blood tests and an MRI.
When I arrived there appeared to be no record of the blood test booking.
At reception I was told I could have the bloods after the MRI.
I contested that (because you cannot) but I was told that I could and would be given tests after MRI.
When I had MRI I asked the radiologists and was told in terms (as I knew to be the case and had contended earlier) that I could not have blood tests after the MRI as the MRI had involved the injection of substances into my blood stream.

I was called by two separate nurses one from Portland Place one from Grosvenor Place each giving slightly different advice on bowel preparation. And they didn’t seem to be aware of each other. Also they decided to send me a new prep medicine in the post which would not have arrived in time.

So this led to unnecessary confusion and slight stress before the colonoscopy.
I was cared for in a very caring and professional way
I was cared for very well, I've improved very well.
I was carefully listened to by the Medical Staff.

I was certainly treated with respect and felt listened to but I would have liked a bit more feedback to how I cope with the difficult situation I am in. I realise there is no easy answers but I would have liked some feedback and advice. My situation is complex I realise that and not easy for any therapist but it would have been helpful to get a little more feedback.

I was checked in immediately and then greeted with a friendly smile. I did not have to wait. I was told exactly how to stand and assisted toget into the correct position. The whole service was completed very quickly and pleasantly and the XRays were conveyed to my surgeon immediately. They were reported on very quickly too.
I was completely satisfied with every aspect of my treatment and care.

I was confused when given drugs for pain relief on discharge. I was told that I could use paracetamol and ibuprofen if I had them at home, but the clinical team thought I might need co-dydramol or tramadol, as my surgery was slightly more extensive than anticipated. I started taking these the day after discharge. On discharge, I had been told to drink lots of fluids, to minimise the risk of constipation. Despite doing this, I had developed constipation. I had been told that someone would phone me the day after discharge to check on my progress, but no-one did. Two days after discharge I was still concerned about my constipation, so I phoned the day care desk, and go advised to discontinue tramadol, and continue with paracetamol and ibuprofen. Doing this, combined with using a laxative, cleared my constipation in a couple of days. I think it would have been better to have been given paracetamol and ibuprofen, in addition to tramadol, and told only to use tramadol as a last resort.
I was contacted soon after discharge from RBH and visited by physiotherapist soon after assessed with care and explained about my stroke I felt looked after with care and compassion.
I was dealt with professionally and cordially by the consultant and staff. That gave me confidence that the service I was receiving was of very high quality.

I was desperate for the loo when I arrived so it was the first thing I did. After that, I found out I should give a urine sample! It would have been good to know that before hand. Luckily I keep well hydrated so needed to go again before I left.

I was diagnosed with Stage 1 lung cancer and had a lobectomy at the Cleveland Clinic. I stayed in the ICU and the 5th floor ward.  This has been a major life event for me but the Cleveland Clinic and all its medical and support staff were extraordinary in supporting me through this. I always felt well informed and confident of the expertise of your team, and importantly I was treated with respect and compassion throughout.  The outstanding experience was a combination of: - First class specialists and surgeons - not only were they at the top of their game in terms of their specialisms but also they were compassionate, accessible (my surgeon has been on text message with me pre- and post-op, and visited once or twice every day when I was hospitalised), always patient with questions and provided clear explanations - Competent and compassionate nursing and support teams who generally communicated well across functions - Outstanding facilities (a hospital that looks more like a hotel!) and advanced equipment / technology supporting the care staff and processes
I was disappointed that I did not receive as much physiotherapist as l believe lt would to help my Parkinson’s.

I was disappointed that having had a pre-assessment call booked for 0815 no-one called and I had to call three times to be able to get through to someone.  On the first occasion I was put through to the department but no-one answered.  On the second occasion the switchboard operator had not heard of Endoscopy, when she eventually found it, she explained she was in another building.  As a patient, I am not interested where she is I just want my call dealt with quickly and efficiently.   Unfortunately I then had to make a third call as she said she said she couldn't transfer me and needed to give me the number.

The lavatory in the cubicle could have been cleaner and there was lavatory paper on the floor; I was the first appointment of the day.

After the procedure I was offered tea and a sandwich which was very welcome after not eating for so long but, unfortunately, the egg sandwich was so stale I couldn't eat it.  I assume it was left over from the day before.

Just as an aside on this survey I have answered that the call bell was always answered but I didn't actually use it so an "not applicable" option would be sensible.

I was disappointed with the outcome of my consultation, and believed it had done more harm than good. I didn’t have any confidence in the diagnosis  and future management of the health problem offered. The Consultant seemed didn’t pose enough questions and seemed eager to terminate the consultation. I didn’t feel as though he was very interested in my case.

I was discharged home from hospital with no medication and discharge summary. I was anxious about the whole thing. The community matron reassured me and followed up with the ward and GP until I received my medications. She also followed up to see me at home,;
I was discharged to CMHT and have unfortunately been left without support.
I was discharged too soon
I was distrought when I arrived to my assessment but left with a feeling that there is light at the end of the tunnel

I was due to have two procedures one after the other and it was agreed a few days before my attendance that the order would switched.  However, a system generated message was sent to me 9 minutes after checking in on the day changing the time of one of the procedures (but not the other).  This just added to the stress and anxiety I was feeling before the procedures - was the whole day going to be pushed back?
The liver procedure (which in the end was not required) would have required a 6 hour post procedure stay in the hospital - this was never communicated to me until I met the consultant on the day.
I was expecting a good service but I was surprised how friendly and relaxes they all made me feel
I was extremely grateful to be fitted in without an appointment. Gail and Sarah K were friendly and professional
I was extremely impressed by Professor Jamie Murphy and his nurses.

I was extremely impressed with the facilities, equipment, staff, and overall experience. I've already recommended Cleveland Clinic and my specific Dr (Dr Samaan) to a friend and plan to continue to do so in the future. So happy I've found a place like this!

I was extremely well looked after by the caregivers, from healthcare assistants to nurses. My surgeon and anaesthetist’s teams took great care of me, and the channels of communication always felt open to me.
I was feeling nervous, I was put at ease me process was explained clearly and concisely.
I was feeling overwhelmed, was bale to talk to HTT about my options.
I was feeling the urge to harm myself and others and felt I should of been admitted for few days instead of at home.
I was feeling very emotional and the lady was so kind and wished me a good day with a smile … just what I needed
I was forgotten left waiting for blood test. In the end the doctor that was seeing me had to take my blood himself.
I was given advance information about my care before my appointment.

I was given an appointment that evening and was seen shortly after the appointment time. The doctor understood the problem and was very helpful, providing me with some remedial medication to use immediately. Very helpful and considerate. Regards Jake.
I was given an estimate, which I believed was for all my treatment at the clinic. This was paid in full prior to my visit. Was not informed the Lab tests were extra.
I was given as much help as possible to my understanding and got all questions answered.
I was given comprehensive information on how to exercise to improve my mobility. This worked ever so well.

I was given food and a drink after coming round from the sedative but reacted to this food and felt very faint and was sick.  I could not locate the call button beside my bed and had to shout for assistance which came very quickly and they brought me round and stabilised my blood pressure.
I was given some useful information, namely that Id be entitled to the jab based on the fact that Im a care worker.I didnt know that.I came here because Im diabetic.
I was given such kind attention to detail in my personal care.

I was given the Feedback number so I could comment on the display board that shows when next in line for a blood test.
