Despite me chasing it up, they never came back with it and despite two phone calls today still no-one is calling me back.  Not only is it frustrating but could be very dangerous for some patients on vital medication.
My second issue was with the ordering of food.  Patients should be given a menu to digest and choose rather than read off an Ipad by the person taking the order who also wants an instant answer.  I wasn't given half the options that were available - I didn't even know I could order a sandwich!  It also took three hours to get a cup of tea.

The nurses and care workers on the 4th floor were excellent and I felt completely looked after and safe in their care. Nothing was too much for them and they were incredibly keen to help me at all times and to ensure I was pain free and comfortable at all times. I can not praise them enough.
The nurses and doctors were friendly informative and shows patience better with patient and carer.
The nurses and health care personnel were extremely helpful, friendly and caring
The nurses and radiographer were extremely patient even though I was scared. I am grateful for their care.
The nurses and support workers are very helpful and caring.
The nurses and the Professor were excellent. The check in staff were NOT - see below.
The nurses are brilliant.
The nurses are very kind.

The nurses are very nice and friendly 
I have been discharged today and will miss them visiting
The nurses explained the situation and did the injections calmly and softly
The nurses have all been very good to me [name removed] ehave been brilliant to me after 7yrs of pain my ulcer is almost healed
The nurses have been excellent in keeping my spirits up at this difficult time.

The nurses have been very kind to me, I think everyone is so wonderful.
I enjoyed the activities especially when the lady came in to sing with us, she had a lovely voice.
The girls work really hard to keep the wards clean.
The nurses in the clinic were really nice and understanding. It was such a calm atmosphere. It was a pleasant surprise that they had free parking too.
The nurses listened and were caring and compassionate.
The nurses made me feel incredibly comfortable.

The nurses service is very excellent

 In particular, nurse Dina Echeverry cares about the cleanliness of the patient in terms of swimming, eating, changing clothes and arranging the room, all at a time when the patient needs very excellent care
The nurses should know better about freestyle libre apps

The nurses treated me better than I have ever been treated in my life, very caring. The surgeon visited me every day after the surgery and answered all my questions. 

overall better service than a 5* hotel.
The nurses treated me with kindness and respect. However, I was unable to tolerate the pain level from the BP cuff on my leg, so test had to be abandoned
The nurses treated me with such kindness.
The nurses was so helpful and took their time with me. They provided me with CRHTT contact details and also other services that may be beneficial to me.
The nurses we saw were kind, calm compassionate and ever so stalled. (Anne and Tina). Thank you. :)
The nurses went over and above to ensure that I had all of the support and Information I needed.

The nurses were amazing & my main consultant is fabulous but there are a few areas that I think could be improved. When I started bleeding post-op, I didn’t feel the team listened properly to how bad it was & so were very slow to respond. I feel I lost a lot of blood before the blood tests were done & then it felt a bit like panic mode (15 doctors & nurses in my room whilst they got the transfusions sorted). Everyone was absolutely lovely & caring but I think it could have been managed quicker. It also took a while to explain the management plan to me (stopping the bleeding vs protecting the bowel anastomosis) which helped a lot once explained. There is not great communication between the medical team & the catering team for a colorectal ward given how important diet is. The choices also felt very limited for post-bowel surgery until I was told I could essentially order what I wanted (but not until it been trying to transition off nil by mouth & clear fluids for a few days I.e. this should be clear up front). Finally, it would be SO helpful to be able to open a window!! I know it sounds minor but I’ve been in the hospital 3 times now & have always had issues with the room being too hot or too cold. I understand it’s hard to have fully opening windows but being able to open them partly to have some fresh air would make a huge difference. I suffer from migraines & headaches which were awful after the blood transfusions & I do think they would have improved much faster with fresh air.
The nurses were attentive, deligent and kind. The hygeine levels on Sahara A&B wardss are exemplary.

The nurses were brilliant, but I  wasn't so happy with the  Specialist I saw. At the end of the appointment  I  wasn't sure if I was going to have a blood test then and there I had to go back to the nurses  and they had to sort it out. I  was told I  would  Receive a letter  regarding the next stage I still haven't received anything  yet I'm  feeling  a bit  anxious. 
I would be very grateful  if this could be sorted ASAP please, thank you.
The nurses were charming informative and caring.
The nurses were fantastic and provided top notch care. They were not only very professional and well trained, but empathetic as well.

The nurses were fantastic and provided top notch care. They were not only very professional and well trained, but empathetic as well. the caterer who served the food did so at a regular time each day whihc was good
The nurses were great. The front desk are very organised, it was a good experience overall. Such friendly nurses.
The nurses were informative and helpful.
The nurses were knowledgeable, reasurring and kind. They also had  good sense of humour and took their time discussing any issues I had.
The nurses were lovely
The nurses were lovely, friendly and kind. Receptionist was polite.

The nurses were very good and caring   One came to my room to help me as I was being sick. I didn't get a chance to ring the bell!  Professor Hakim was so nice with a smile on his face. He made sure that I was comfortable .

I would come back again. I have already recommended the Hospital and one of my friends has just had a treatment with Professor Hakim and they are also happy.

Thank you all for your help.

Samantha
The nurses were very interested in my wellbeing and overall health also.
The nurses were very kind and helpful.
The nurses were very knowledgeable, helpful and kind. They reacted quickly when needed and took time to ensure my sons wound had fully healed before discharging him from their care

The nurses were very nice and some HCA staff too. However some of the HCA staff was not so pleasant. 2-3 women were a Bit dismissive and moody types on the Saturday morning. One lost her patience with me because I couldn’t understand what she wanted me to do about the temperature check. Another was a bit rough coming into the room telling me I was to leave to go to the theatre.
Other than this group of three HCA, everyone was fantastic.
The nurses were very professional as always.
The nurses who treated me were very very polite and respectful.
The nurses work at a smiley face.
The nurses, the hospital, the food, everything was amazing. I could not fault it.
The nurses/specialist was extremely knowledgeable, helpful and polite.
The nursing and care staff were very attentive and pleasant at all times.

The nursing and catering staff and physio staff could have been much more organised
and attentive
The nursing care received was exceptional

The nursing care was particularly attentive and kind.  I was only in for a CT scan and so it was easily communicated and managed.  The hospital facilities are remarkable - clean, built for purpose and brand new.  Not difficult to be reassured and comfortable.
The nursing provided by Katie and Isla was exceptional.  They were both attentive, patient and considerate.  I felt very comfortable during my stay as a result.
The nursing staff and doctors were all very good. I felt that my care and comfort were their priority.
The nursing staff both in the theatre and on the “ward” were totally first class. Explained procedures clear and precisely; felt in excellent hands.
The nursing staff were all great. Particular thanks to Lauren who was excellent.

The nursing staff were attentive and understanding, even or especially when Meade was adjitated and , on occasions, aggressive, they remained patient and gentle. A bit more face to face contact with some of the specialist consultants (in Meade,s case Neurologists) would have been helpful.
The nursing staff were excellent & very compasionate.
The nursing staff were friendly  efficient and helpful.
The nursing staff were very helpful, patient and very easy to talk to.
The nursing team especially was very nice.

The nursing team was pristine and gave good explanations when needed. 
One nurse used the opportunity to teach another about my vac drain. As a physician, I don't think the opportunity was used in the best way possible. The teaching nurse should have used the SOP to give the receiving nurse the most up-to-date information on how the clinic/hospital does the care, not only try to remember by hart, which led to some confusion on the instructions.

The nursing team, both in ITU and on the 5th Floor, were extremely dedicated and attentive. It was especially notable that one always felt foremost a 'person' rather than a 'patient' throughout the experience.
The nursing was excellent. The housekeeping/ catering service was poor
The occupational therapist was very understanding and kind and listened to all the questions that me and my mum had.

The one area that I felt could have been better was how my pain was managed. There appears to still be a possibly unconscious behaviour / attitude  ( sometimes it seemed fearful) approach to giving meds that have been prescribed. There is no need for a nurse to say they don’t want me to get addicted or to even feel it is their responsibility to help wean me off ( especially if there is no weaning protocol). During my stay I constantly wondered what the culture on pain and management was in the hospital as it often felt like possible addiction was placed above the patient’s pain experience. I was often hesitant to express my pain and felt no patient should feel that way.
The one hour wait whilst soaking wet from heavy rain outside wasn’t the best experience.

The one issue I keep encountering is that the treatment ‘runs out’ before it’s done everything I need it to do. Some significant improvements are made but I end up having to come back for more treatment because the number of sessions I get aren’t sufficient to address all the issues. It’s really frustrating.

The one thing I'm not so happy about is not the fault of Holly Wheelchair service or any of the staff that so excellently and competently provide it, but rather the lack of appropriate options & provision for severely disabled and mobility impaired people. I have extremely impaired mobility and can awkwardly move less than 5ft on a very good day and perhaps 2-3ft on an average day or 0ft having to crawl along the floor like a slug on a bad health day and struggle more and more to rise from my chair, using two walking sticks and have lost everything to my deteriorating health, except my life which will surely follow at some point in the near future. A decade of constant prescribing of Antibiotics due to a severe immune/dermatological condition (only relatively recently diagnosed) alongside endocrine and hormonal disorders and other conditions have damaged my nerves, wasted my muscles by being bed bound with infection, damaged my spine and caused reactive arthritis which inflames and stiffens joints all over my body during infections (which are constant and recurring). I have heart disease causing very low blood pressure which is untreatable and means my balance is very poor and I fall regularly. I also have had asthma from childhood which makes it hard to breath. Add dizziness, to balance, to pain, to breathlessness, to muscle wasting, to fatigue, to wasted muscle and flared up nerves together and what do you get? Someone who has had to crawl around the floor at times and has embarrassingly on occasion messed themselves when no one is available to help me and I can't make it to the toilet quickly enough...… and yet I still apparently don't "quite" meet the "requirements" or "rules" for an electric wheelchair to be prescribed, despite my original GP referral (made many years ago now) indicating that one was necessary, even back then before I reached this low of health and despite efforts from my social worker to help me as well. It almost feels like it's a punishment to keep pushing myself and to make the efforts even when it's like wading through a concrete morass of pain or that you are penalised for being honest about my extremely limited mobility and makes you think, just give up at times. Disabled and chronically unwell people (for the most part) want to and WILL help themselves! Wherever possible, we are all used to struggle to our own varying degrees, but we need to be given the tools to help us do so and conversely outdated thinking, cynicism and incredibly myopic decision making in terms of guidelines are counter productive to that end in my own personal opinion and in the opinion of many people in the disabled and chronically unwell diaspora. I can't tell you how depressing and dispiriting it is to lose your personal agency to help yourself even when you want to. I've been hospitalised for infections requiring surgical intervention at Addenbrookes hospital in Cambridge under the care of multiple specialty's 2 times so far in 2023 and during every single stay the hardest part has not been the illness or confusion or pain or malaise or worry about outcomes, death and the future, but rather it's been feeling trapped and not being able to help myself. Relying on over worked and short staffed nurses and HCA's to help me wash and mobilise despite the fact that each ward I've been on has completely adapted shower and bathroom facilities mere feet away is a deliciously crisp and saccharine apple of irony, given that I can't properly use them if I can't get to them and despite the fact that it's extremely unhealthy for the disabled to have rely on other people in this way unless we absolutely have to. Many in the disabled community I know through family, friendships or support groups feel attacked by cynical politicians, the poverty endemic amongst the long term chronically sick and a failure for wider society to help or think of others and yet even if you want to help yourself you can't. You're stuck with an attendant controlled wheelchair in a world of social and health care with an extreme shortage of attendants. I can't even leave the ward to buy a coffee or a newspaper or take a mental health break from the poor suffering people and the never ending beeping machines, chirping away incessantly and presaging my own inevitable demise. This extreme paucity of electric wheelchair precision is counter productive in so many different and offensive ways. I have fainted from low blood pressure, screamed in pain or lost balance completely multiple times trying to mobilise impossible (for me) distances whilst hospitalised and at home on crutches, frames or sticks and have had to have been (humiliatingly) scraped of the floor like a dropped pancake by overwhelmed staff on each and every occasion occasion. No one deserves to end up with a pulled over bookcase on there head, the books are supposed to enter the head via reading not assimilation through blunt force. During the periods in between hospitalisation I am suffering repeat infections and trying desperately to avoid hospital, my groin and backside is covered in abscesses and inflammatory nodules where my immune system attacks me over and over again that can make standing or sitting agonising and the complete loss of agency and independence I suffer, in not being able to access my community or my human rights is an affront to my dignity and I am surely far from the worst affected patient due to these policy's. I have to use a Bi-Level ventilator with Oxygen during sleep to maintain my airway when unconscious and am now suffering from severe antibiotic resistance. During my last admission doctors made it clear to me that the main condition from which I suffer has no cures and I have failed on every available pharmacological treatment which no longer work for me and that this was threatening my life and spelled out my future (or lack) of future clearly and yet be musingly, I still don't quite qualify for an electric chair which I can control myself. Perhaps I should stop my carers from washing or shaving me and start lying on forms instead of the floor to get the right equipment to live better with? Cynicism begats cynical behaviour after all. Who knows maybe if lose my dignity and stop presenting as well as I possibly can I will regain some dignity by being able to go to a shop or go out for fresh air ALONE for once. What a Faustian mess. I wonder who at a CCG or the new partially privatised American style ICBs or whatever panel of disconnected and politicised physicians involved, (who are usually entirely disassociated from the consequences of said decisions) make these inappropriate and severe rationing guidelines for basic equipment needed for the fundamental human right not to be trapped or the right to a family or personal life when your disability prevents you from having one due to a basic piece of equipment being missing when clearly and reasonably needed. How much money does it actually save our funding starved, inflation hit NHS when patients, who denied this provision of self controlled mobility and personal agency, fall and break brittle bones, lose the mental will to keep fighting, suffer bed or sofa sores due to being unable to move around or have heart attacks and strokes trying to do the near impossible? How much does surgery, intensive care and rehabilitation cost for a chronically unwell person with comorbidities who's broken a hip or suffered a premature MI or stroke? Quite a bit more by the tens of thousands than a basic piece of equipment that's been more widely available since the 1950s which most second world countries are somehow able to provide. To qualify this and to be constructive and fair, just as we cannot blame the excellent clinicians, engineers and staff of the wheelchair services for these guidelines (who whilst too professional to express it are (I would imagine) at times frustrated themselves by them, also we cannot (completely) blame the wider NHS as none of us have control over political funding decisions (other than our votes). However to scrimp and try to save in one area such as electric wheelchair provisions not only comes at a cost of personal dignity, agency and worsening outcomes but the cost of the repercussions of these decisions in the long term. It's short sighted and a great shame. Please give the Wheelchair services FULL not opaque or borderline decision making ability in terms of what they provide. They ARE EXPERTS in their fields and know what is needed, who needs it and that total paralysis should not be the only qualifier for the ability to control your own life and movement, they are more than capable of assessing who has genuine needs. More personally speaking I am still extremely hopeful that the Holly Wheelchair service will be able to work with me and my caregivers by requesting any further necessary medical evidence or agency they may require, in order to help me access an electric chair and take back control of my own life at some point in the near future and that those making decisions should be those at the coalface and not the site office in future. If you read this and share my frustration or parts of them then Thank You for your decency and public service and I hope you are well. If you read this part as a decision maker or policy mandarin, then do better. Because one day it might be you on the floor with more in your trousers than a pair of legs, Thank You for your valuable time. Many Kind Regards and With Respect, your patient, MA.

The one thing that was a bit disorganised was the checkout and communication around medications. Both today and Friday when I was in were similar. The dr, nurses and pharmacists didn’t seem to be on the same page about what was getting prescribed, and it took a number of hours each time to get it sorted. Everyone was polite and apologetic, but it seems like there was a bit of communication issues both time. As a patient, I also wasn’t told how long I would be waiting to checkout. Today I was told I was ready to be discharged around 11… but it’s now 2pm and I’m still waiting on medication.

The one thing which I thought would have  been helpful, would have been to have a toolkit app.

During my recovery, [name removed] game me various tools to use throughout our consultations.  These tools were useful but trying to utilise them when they in amongst your email list made it more convoluted to use.

If the tools were in an app, it would be easy to find when you need instantly, on the go, provide a tracker and potentially report back to the therapist the outcomes to help with sessions and the conversations therein.

The flow of sessions would be more seamless.

The one to one physio session I had was not good. Hardly 10 mins of session and I was given appointment after 4 weeks. Despite my request as i was in urgent need of physio, I was not listened too.
I even told [name removed] @ upton to give my name for 4 weeks shoulder session but it was not given. 
My one month got wasted and I had to personally visit and give my name again.
Group classes were much better than one on one. R
The one to one sessions mid course were good. Maybe these should be a regular thing?
The one-to-one descriptions and discussion plus the tailored strength/balance plan.
The online system is a little flaky at times and there could do with more reading and study material

The only area for me that could have been a little better is written information about after care at home. I hadn't fully understood the healing process or how to take care of myself in terms of exercise and how to build up strength again. I did receive very good physio therapy during my stay but didn't fully understand what had been done, the reason for the health issue or the potential issues in future.
However, the consultant did give me most of the information before and after the procedure, I didn't fully understand that although the general pain and numbness would be gone, I will not be able to fully live life as I used to.
The only bad thing was the wait time, but I know that as a service you are very over-stretched so I understood why, and I was just happy to be seen and listened to..

The only confusing thing was the computer generated print outs of the various costs of blood tests and an MRI I requested. The pancreatic cancer marker tests was confusingly incorrectly named and this computer generated print out also contained fake AI wording, something like ‘I look forward to talking to you again’.  Luckily the nurses at Cleveland Clinic were brilliant in explaining this very confusing computer generated data which was simply just meant to show prices of blood tests and call them by their correct names.

The only criticism I have of your service is that I didn't get access to David until 6 or so months after I really, really needed his help.
By the time I got access to the help I needed, I had largely negotiated my difficulties.
Happily for me, the outcome was good. That was partially down to my own fortitude, but mainly lots of luck. I would hate for others to be confronted with the difficulties I faced, and not to have the same amount of fortune.

This is all a bit cryptic, but basically the crux is this: the very nature of one's situation is sometimes the thing preventing a person from opening up during the asssessment interview. I know that your resources are stretched, and that you're doing your best in making difficult decicions. Please continue to listen carefully to the people reaching out.
And finally, thank you.
The only disappointment is that I noticed another patient who came in after me was called in earlier than me, but I understand.
The only down point is getting appointments, which can take ages.

The only down side was the time it took to be spoken to.  The actual service was very good but you may claim it is a lack of resources to get someone to speak to me.  The support from Maria was excellent, clear and she did what she said she would do.  But it took months before she was free and engaged with me.  When Paul called me after I complained about the delays - he was helpful but maybe follow up calls while waiting might have eased my stress about the delay.

The only issue I felt could be improved is the waiting period, nevertheless, I do understand the different pressures you are facing, that being said, some people are literally so broken and at the end of themselves. Please be mindful that I am not blaming Talking Therapies but the system itself.
The only negative is very long waiting times. Great stuff though.

The only negative was a student said  to me that "you've done so well with your life and now your life being wasteful" - she taken aback by that and felt that maybe students need to know how to speak to patients with suicidal thoughts - but fortunately the comment didn't affect her but it may have affected another person - other than that the service was very good.

The only negative was on arrival where the front desk was manned by two pleasant

but incredibly scruffy individuals. Unimpressive but out of character with the rest of the 

visit

The only one poor thing was when I arrived at reception on the ground floor it took a long time sitting around before I could check in and be taken up to my room. It seemed to have taken around 10 mins per person in front of me.
The only problem I had was finding the building I had to attend. Otherwise everything was excellent.

The only problem I had was that I times I felt that the nursing staff was not properly coordinating with other medical staff. My surgical procedure was delayed and no one came to give me updates on the status of when I would start. Also, no one clearly knew when I would be discharged to go home and I also had to be asking as to what the plan was.

The only problem I have now is that I should have asked for medication or  a higher fibre diet for bowel movement earlier. I was asked if I had been to the toilet but no medications were offered. Me personally, can manage with a high fibre diet to correct this so maybe a high fibre cereal (All Bran, Bran Flakes, prunes) could be on the menu post op. On day 6 of my procedure I am sort of ok now but should have started this earlier.

I will know for next time!!
The only problem is the wait for treament.

The only problem pts wife has had is that she sent an email to DNs and they were  not answered.  Once when DNs came out and she felt that these two DNs did not communicate with her and the surgery very well.    From the time when she makes a request to visit and the actual time when they visit is too long.   There were two examples one was to change a catheter and she just wanted DN to show her and explain things but DN took too long to visit.  Unbeknown to pt and pts wife, GP has asked for DN to visit to take bloods and sometimes when DNs have come round and they are out - her husband uses a wheelchair but he is not housebound in the fact that pt is taken out.

The only reason why I didn't write very good was because I had to wait for a while checking in because despite giving my BUPA authorisation code at my previous visit,  I was down as Self Funding.
I had returned for a post operative appointment to remove dressings and assess wounds which was already covered.
That said the ladies dealing with the issue were delightful.
The only sad matter is that it is such a long waiting list :-(
The only snag was that I have a £500 deductible with BUPA and they were unable to tell me to whom I should pay this amount they did however give me the contact details of the Accounts Department.

The only suggestion I have is that up at the entrance the reception team needs to make patients aware that the WiFi connections need to be set properly for the venue; being across the street from Buckingham Palace makes the connections a little difficult if the WiFi isn't set for the hospital.

The only suggestion I’d make is the release of test results. Although it’s great you are keen to share these with the patient as soon as they come in I think it would be far better that they are sent/given to the consultant to check and present to the patient, rather than them arriving (as one set did) on a Saturday evening. Although in my case the news was positive, a different result could prove very difficult for a patient to interpret and could come to conclusions that need a care giver’s interpretation.

The only thing I could see that may improve the experience is to inform your patient that there are no reception facilities when the appointment is made. There is ample signage to this effect when you get there but if you are used to checking in the wait is a source of anxious moments.
The only thing I could think of that would be better was if I could come here more regularly to receive their specialist treatment and care.

The only thing I didn't like was that I felt that they discharged me quite quickly, I felt suicidal afterwards for a week and felt alone. 
It felt like I was abandoned in the middle of the road to my recovery - Crisis team were my only support and hope I had at the time but I lost that. 
I felt I needed one week extra support.
The only thing I would improve on is informing the patient on the medication on timings especially if there is multiple medications

The only thing I would say is that from the start no one checked how bad/good my movement was in various areas so there is never knowledge for the physio to go by other than what the patient has to describe. 
Also whilst most exercises in leaflets/books are well illustrated, some might need a bit of demonstration.
Way back at the start I queried on after the first 4 weeks and found I’d been doing it incorrectly. Perhaps physio should ask the patient if they understand them all,  particularly an older person who may have come across these exercises for the very first time in their lives. Perhaps you shouldn’t assume we know what we are doing. It could hinder improvement.

The only thing I would say is that the instructions for the pre-prep drink that was sent to me for a two day preparation before the scan did not come with instructions about how to time taking the drink over the two days.  There were no instructions about when or how to take the drink.  I called the radiology department and spoke to a nurse but it would be helpful to have more clear instructions including with the prep drink when it arrives

The only thing I would suggest for improvement is outside of the physical therapists control.  I found it really strange that information isn't available to the therapists on what exercises are prescribed by the other physical therapists within the NHS.  I also find it frustrating that for multiple musculoskeletal issues that I have to see different therapists.  This has ended up with me having over 30 different exercises prescribed which really isn't doable.
The only thing I’d say could be improved is to let me know the price of my procedures even though I’m covered by insurance - I’m care anything were to go wrong.

The only thing [name removed]e would say is that the amount of time for the visit is short.  He gets a phone call now and then from DNs saying not coming anymore and [name removed] feels about isolated when this happens as [name removed] who is his Dads carer needs DNs to help him with wound care/dressing legs.   If its possible, that DNs could not put a timeframe on the visits.  Apart from that, the actual service is excellent.  He realises that DNs not being able to spend as much time as they could is a shame but he realises that this is a funding situation with the NHS.
The only thing is that I would now like to have some balance exercises.
The only thing is the time of waiting, too long.

The only thing that I can think of, and I’m really having to think hard on this question, would be the length of the sessions, sometimes, when my anxiety got the better of me, I found that an hour would not be enough to bring my anxiety down, although we would do exercises to bring my anxiety levels down at the end of the sessions where my anxiety got worse, and they did work, my anxiety would go back up later on.

The only thing that I did bit feel comfortable with is the repeated questions/ worded in different ways that always led to are you depressed or suicidal.

It felt like the only right or acceptable answer is yes I am.

Problem with that is I do not believe I am suffering from depression and I don't feel suicidal.. so the repeated questions made me uncomfortable.
The only thing that I think that could be better would be more sessions rather than the amount I had with my therapist apart from that I found it a well organized process

The only thing that concerns us both is that my husband was asked exactly the questions as previously and we are not entirely convinced that the outcome was true 
He is different at home and asks the same questions repeatedly which is very frustrating for me

The only thing that could be improved upon is how to get hold of the primary care team through the GP service.  The care navigators at my practice didn't seem to know what I was asking when I asked them to help me get in touch with Emily between our scheduled appointments.  It meant I had to wait until the next appointment when I felt I needed to speak to Emily urgently.  Maybe better information for local practice would be helpful.

The only thing that could be improved was the time it often took fir my husband to he let back onto the ward when he left. One occasion he was stood at the door ringing the bell for over 5 minutes. Maybe the system used could be looked into.

The only thing that could have been communicated better was the time of my surgery prior to my arrival as I needed to arrive at 7am and was asked to fast from both food and drink, however upon arriving my op was not scheduled initially until 2:40pm. Baring in mind the surgery would be up to 2 hours and then potential another hour in recovery which is a long time to go without food or drink, however the team were able to move my surgery to a few hours earlier which I was super grateful for!
The only thing that could have done better was to give me a lot of advice about the way that my father treated me very aggressively way and he sort of given me the shake because he scared me.
The only thing that could improve is more of the same. There just needs to be more of this service. At least double what you already offer.
The only thing that could of been better would be to have received this service sooner. I have only just been referred by my gp 10 months post accident.

The only thing that doesn't make sunrise is that after 6 weeks the referral is closed despite my husband having PSP and who will need additional equipment fairly soon I imagine it means the GP having to spend more time on admin re- referring again.

The only thing that is annoying is when you phone up for appointment and it goes to the answer machine and you have to wait for a callback latter that day or the next day …… if you miss the call back or it not that Convenient to answer you don’t have to go through it all again and hopefully someone will answer the phone

The only thing that might be useful but she recognises that this might be difficult is that sometimes when she would like to pass on a mesage to DN team.  Communication could improve  [name removed] is not there with her mum when DNs visit - would like better communication.
The only thing was I couldn't understand about stopping all my pills I could have done with an explanation but everyone was so busy they didn't realise how ignorant I eas
The only thing was asking about DNR.

The only thing was that it took me awhile to pass a bowel movement, and I think this may have been due to the anaesthetic. Would have been great to have understood that a little more as had a terrible stomach ache and really bad diarrhoea the day after (although may have not been related)

The only thing you could do better is allow me to have my care coordinator’s number. I have psychological needs and these aren't being met. I have been forwarded for therapy for 4 years running and have yet to see a therapist. I need the therapy because of CPTSD. It would keep me from being sectioned for no reason. I have an incorrect diagnosis of bipolar. I need this removed and I need therapy.
The openness of the facilitators. It gave permission to share and consider our own experiences. Considering the future & post trauma growth.
The opportunity for more sessions would be great but that's not your fault, that's decades of government underfunding for you.
The opportunity for on going lower limb classes would be good,  even on a paid for option

The options in the questionnaires are not sensitive enough to show clear differences every week. I don't have the questionnaire in front of me to give exact examples but from memory, I found there wasn't an option for me to say how I was feeling.  It only gave something like "often" or "nearly always".  If you are interested, I could give exact example if you re-send me the health anxiety questionnaire
The organisation of the course was poor. The staff on the phone could not give any information about what this course entails and the letter had no information on what the course was for either.
The organisation of the with should have been more regular - difficult seeing that home visits are subject to availability of therapists and their higher priorities elsewhere.
The original letter , should make it clear what I’m coming for , as I’ve had 2/3 appointments recently .

The original letter of referral was from 'Mental Health Team', really upset my mother-in-law and she wouldn't have rung to book an appointment if we hadn't persuaded her. Please could it be clearer that it is for the Memory Clinic.
The overall care was excellent, the nursing staff, health care team, porters, anesthetist, and consultant were awesome.

The overall experience as an inpatient at the hospital was impeccable. The team of nurses were very kind and caring. I can tell they were passionate about their work. I want to especially thank nurse Wilma S, at the DDSI on the 5th floor, who provided top class care and for her kindness. I also want to thank the nurses during the night shift.  I have forgotten their names as I was too weak and tired during the 12 hours after the surgery. The facilities at Cleveland clinic hospital were fantastic and very clean. A truly 5 star experience and care provided by the staff.
The overall experience has been great. Learning was made very fun and she has been very patient and understanding with my daughter.

The overall experience seemed to go well. The less the 5 star ratings were ever so slightly lower because as a send parent, I feel it's important to be present to some degree when your child is with someone else (professional or otherwise). Naturally (and understandably) for their assessment, the parent is not to be in the room but this still none the less feels unusual/uncomfortable (I say quietly outside the room without my son knowing I was there)

I gave a less the 5 star rating for location, less so because of the literal location, but more so because zoom has the potential to present some difficulties for those not used to it/who don't normally engage with it (that being said, it did not end up affecting my son's diagnosis and hom being at home, in his comfort zone om sure helped)

I would like to say that the the whole clinical team were super organized with their calls/emails/messages about the upcoming assessments and questionnaires. They were also very helpful, kind and compassionate when I called with questions.

[name removed] was also wonderful during our parent chat. She made a point of asking first about all the wonderful things to do with my son, which she said she does with every parent as it helps to start on a positive. She was attentive, compassionate and thorough.

My only complaint would be that [name removed] was asked is he had a boyfriend or girlfriend and I felt that wasn't a necessary topic for an 11 year old, and perhaps a different question could have been asked instead.

But overall, the experience seemed to go well and we were really grateful for everyone providing us with the opportunity to get the assessment done so quickly and smoothly and get it processed in good time too.
The overall experience was very good the appointment was on time and the cardiologist explained everything very well and planned the next steps
The overall kindness of the staff, from my mum and family.

The overall level of service and support from nurses and doctors was excellent. The facilities and accommodation at the clinic were also very impressive which helped to make a very comfortable stay and uneventful treatment.

The overall problem is that there is no clear explanation of what to expect from the service following diagnosis. It turns out to be very little is available, carers can be left in the dark. Individuals within the service are all very helpful but there is no capacity for them to do regular follow-ups.

The overall service was excellent however the finance dept and registration had their wires crossed. I got a call from the finance dept asking if I had seen and agreed to the payment terms. My operation was covered by my insurance company and I had to call the registration dept to confirm that indeed that was on my file. 

The staff were absolutely excellent- Michael who was one of the nurses had brilliant bedside manner. I had a slipped disc and was in a lot of pain- he was really great at knowing how to help me out of the bed. The front of house staff were also excellent as I couldn't get out of the cab and they rushed over to me with a wheelchair. 

Thanks you for a fantastic experience- they are pushing the boundaries for hospital care in the UK!
The overall service was very efficient, support was given without being asked for at all stages.

The pain team are wonderful people, both the clinical staff and admin team. Charlotte and Britt have helped me on a number of occasions to reschedule my appointments, and have been very understanding and kind. Dr Dan and Debbie gave great explanations about my injections and this care was arranged seamlessly with Harlow hospital. Debbie, Kasia and Lisa have also given me great medication advice, exercise advice and general pain management education. I really could not more highly recommend this service, which means too that their manager Maggie, who I did not get to meet, is doing a super job too. My thanks and best wishes to them all.

The patient application provides all the info needed but it is a bit “ choppy”.It would be improved if there was a summary description outlining all tests, timings and locations.This simple tool would be easy to follow and understand.
The pen and paper test was at the end of a long assessment, so I was tired and didn't do well.
The people
The people I had spoken to were all lovely. They treated me with dignity and respect.
The people I spoke to were very informative.

The people are all excellent, very high level of care
More training needed for nurses and support staff eg the catering staff that elderly patients may not hear at all well, so in those situations it's important to speak very clearly and slowly and very loudly!
there are certain practical issues at are annoying and could be better (given that the standard you are reaching for is perfection)
- the lack of a telephone in the room is problematic when you have an elderly patient as they do not all use mobile phones and the 4G reception is very poor.  Therefore if you do not have a smartphone and understand how to use wifi you are cut off from the outside world.  Patents do not want to summon a nurse whenever they want to make a phone call and I'm not sure if the nurse could help anyway
- giving patents the option of having a landline phone on an extension no they can give to their family would be great
- the dangling emergency calls across the bathroom get in the way of someone who is trying to walk with difficulty
- the toilet roll pieces are ridiculously small and you end up having to use very many pieces at a time
- paper towel dispense in bathroom wasn't working

The people are all excellent, very high level of care More training needed for nurses and support staff eg the catering staff that elderly patients may not hear at all well, so in those situations it's important to speak very clearly and slowly and very loudly! Paper towel dispense in bathroom wasn't working

The people are great and empathetic. Your ground floor waiting area is great particularly as it provides almost everything one needs while waiting to be attended to. And the place is sparkling clean. I was attended to by Mr Toma. He was very thorough in discussing my health issue in a very interactive manner.
The people doing the talk were super lovely and informative, answering all the questions thoroughly
The people helped me understand what the jab was about
The people should be more caring. feel like im just a number
The people were very helpful and ensured my safety. I often faint and panick and even the thought but they helped me very much and got me over the injections.
The people were very kind and gentle.
The people where very kind and made me feel safe and not nervous
The people who were teaching me were adaptive to how I learnt best.
The people within the dept. talking to each other more as the referral seemed to go astray, which in turn led to part of the chair getting broken as there was extra delay.

The person I saw was excellent ,explained fully and I have a better understanding of my pain . Most helpful with my further treatment. I don't think that this would have been as effective as a remote appointment
The person I spoke to seemed like she knew exactly what to say.

The person I spoke to was kind, patient and very understanding. When I would say things she'd listen carefully and if I was having difficulties trying to remember or say something she would wait and not press me, letting me get to it in my own time and at my own pace.
The person I talked to was very nice and professional, but there is too much paperwork made me feel overwhelmed.
The person could of spoken in a more caring way.
The person giving me the vaccine was very kind and explained everything perfectly
The person leading the meeting took his time to gather the right information. Listened whenever I wanted to elaborate my answer.

The person on the phone did not give me confidence that she knew what she was doing. Seemed like it was her first day. Her communication was vague and off hand. I was really disappointed as I have previously dealt directly with a secretary at the London Clinic and received a much more reassuring dialogue
The person taking blood was excellent. Painless and she was confident. The team at The other hospital near Hyde park corner (done a month or so ago) were not so skillful.
The person undertaking the assessment was extremely nice and very kind.
The person was sweet but they didnt understood what my issues were, a language barrier.
The person wasn't interested in helping me. When the session finished I asked when do I come back he was like go speak to the receptionist. Which I thought was extremely rude.
The person who came to see my husband was very professional and helpful.

The person who contacted me by phone last Friday 25th Aug to triage me was absolutely fantastic. Kind and caring and listened yo all my responses. Sadly, this was lacking in the actual consultation...I was patronised, questioned and made to feel extremely uncomfortable. Everyone has off days but I felt totally distraught after the consultation and am dreading the follow up. I will try to cancel it as I already have a panic feeling .
The person who did my blood test was kind, supportive and thoughtful. She communicated in a timely fashion and went the extra mile to help me.

The person who did my scan rushed me. A mri scanner was broken - but the guy who did it - showed no empathy or compassion. For example - he could’ve explained the process. I was nervous - a bit scared to go into the mri machine. He didn’t put me at ease. When he put me into the machine head first  I asked him to take me out - and go in legs first. I apologised profusely for this. He had a look of frustration and just bundled me into the machine. When I was in the machine I did know he could talk to me thru a speaker / microphone. Music was put in half way of the first scan.  He did little to reassure me. If you have no love for your job - change job.  Please train this member of staff on the basics of patent care.
The person who gave my vaccination was very kind and reassuring

The phlebotomist in my opinion seemed inexperienced and botched a few tries including a collapsed vein. Having had enough cannulas and given lots of blood locations and angles were unusual to say the least. This procedure took far too long 45 + mins and consequently everything else proceeding was rushed and delayed the op by 15 mins nb you could see she was in a dilema and i had lost trust and suggested reverting to Vicky the nurse to take the blood;  no problem first time quick and painless. 
Having got in early to enable these procedures this was a disappointment and created the wrong pre op mindset and tension.

The phlebotomist was running about half an hour late and did not bother to provide an explanation or care about the inconvenience she was causing. She didn’t seem equipped to conduct the tests either and had to keep asking colleagues. Overall it seemed like an amateur was at work rather than being in professional hands at a reputable hospital. In my experience the NHS is much more professional in this regard.

The phone call I had with a nurse previously told me that I had to report in case he did it to someone else, I know that’s what everyone thinks but it’s not easy, could people be asked to not to jump to reporting?
The phone operates need a bit more training as sometimes it like robotic. The questions are so prepared. Does not mean I don’t respect them. A more human touch please.
The physio I saw Rob was very helpful and patient. Answered all my questions. Polite and The physio I saw Rob was very helpful and patient. Answered all my questions. Polite and caring..
The physio did not suggest any new exercises but repeated ones given by another physios at RBH.
The physio lady was very clear and helpful in her explanations.
The physio should have been given access to my medical information, then we could have had more time on the reason why I am in pain with sciatica.

The physio was brilliant we could not work out what was going with my shoulder but she kept trying and trying, clearly very knowledgeable. now been referred for further help. Very nice and supportive and understanding.

The physio was lovely and listened and gave lots of suggestions but my shoulder pain is still there and doesn’t seem to have got any better. I had to wait for pain relief to be administered several times
The physio was very thorough and knowledgeable.  Friendly and explained everything clearly.

The physio was young and my experience of the NHS over the years has shown that they don't often think out of the box or think how they word their questions and statements. His first statement was that I had bn having physio on my neck in Jan 2021 and had not replied to a letter asking me to make an appt. 1. I have not attended Wexham physio, inly a local unit. 2. My neck is permanently painful.  I would not have let anyone near it. 3 . Jan 2021 we were in lockdown.

The physiotherapist and the physio assistant were friendly, efficient and approachable. My condition is a long term recovery from a fractured hip their input put me on a path to greater mobility, which increases continuously. After very little input from physiotherapists while hospitalised this experience was a life-line.
The physiotherapist did not come often enough

The physiotherapist explained what she wanted me to do in response to my problems i.e. poor balance and inability to get back on my feet after falling down.   I was able to get up again using her advice. My balance has improved but it is very slow.

The physiotherapist, Jessica Bivand, was totally reassuring and supportive in providing great advice regarding my post-operative care. Totally understanding and informative. Cannot thank the Care Staff at the Cleveland Clinic enough. They were all very helpful and couldn't go out of their way enough to support me. Thank you all very much. Tony Marchant.

The place is clean 
People that work in the place very friendly and welcoming
The place is depressive. Doctors provide less information through the day and have to keep asking for time to be seen again and again.
The place was clean. The appointments were timely. The professionals were respectful, open, interested.

The podiatrist was very thorough and gave a good and clear assessment of my condition and the appropriate treatment. Her manner was very pleasant and I felt that I was listened to. She gave me practical advice concerning suitable shoes and stretches to improve my leg muscle tightness issues.

The podiatrists can read and understand the case notes before I enter the room rather than ask me everytime. Excuses include "We don't have enough time" or "the font is too small" or "there's an A4 page of information, it's too much".
Really? What happened to patient care?.
The porter who took me from reception and to my room on the 5th floor, wasn’t sure of where to go.

The practitioner Neil was professional, kind, thorough and incredibly knowledgeable. I was given good information on how to self refer to physio if i need it. The place was clean. I witnessed the other patients being treated with respect and compassion too. A lovely place to go if you need this service.
The practitioner could have listened, but they literally ignored my concerns.
The practitioners that attended my appointments acted with great professionalism, sensitivity and knowledge. They kept me informed at end stage of the appointment.
The procedure went very well. The care staff were always available. I was discharge the following day, without any problems.

The process and care was very efficient, compassionate, informative and friendly.  Everyone was so attentive to ensure that we felt we had all the information we needed and we had plenty of time to discuss the procedure with all members of the care team. 
 We left the pre-op assessment feeling very confident and re-assured about the procedure and our decision to come to CCL.
The process at the clinic are excellent and very professional. I would have no hesitation to recommend to a friend.
The process from referral to diagnosis took too long-see above.
The process from the very beginning was smooth, polite and efficient. I've had surgery and the aftercare and follow up has been superb.
The process is quick and staff gave all the information

The process of booking and joining the online session was simple and extremely convenient.

Vivian Lee the Dietitian was compassionate, knowledgeable, caring and kind. I felt very confident and reassured after my appointment.
The professional friendly service of Dr Rehan Haidry is exceptional, intelligent and caring.

The professional manner and level of attention that all those I came in contact with during my stay, right from the Surgeon (Dr Mohammadi), the consultant (Dr Cropley), Clinical Nurse Specialist (Stephanie), Nurses - (Nile, Katrina, Eve and others whose names I am unable to recollect), gave me was marvellous. So also was the handling at the CTscan. I remain ever grateful for their contributions towards managing my health.

The professional supprt received from Siobhan and Lois has been fantastic. 
They were patient and kind and spent time learning about the children to support their learning needs in development not just for their behaviour and well being but it allows us to understand and help children regulate their emotions and not become overwhelmed in different environments. 
Service provided by the professional team is not 'good' they are great and invaluable!
Thank you :)
The professional trainers expertise and caring attitude. Meeting others who shared their recovery journey.
The professionalism , friendly staff and lovely room.

The professionalism at the Hospital was second to none. The facilities were amazing the people who work there we even better. Very proud of being able to of gone to an amazing Hospital. Well done to all concerned.
The professionals ie Doctors and Nurses were exemplary.
The professionals were really welcoming and supportive. Made us feel very at ease. I would definitely recommend to other people who require support.
The programme is good. We have tried to engage. Trying to maintain it long term may be difficult without support from Rise.
The programme should include more sessions and most should be in person.

The programme was on point and was able to tackle all the issues on diabetes and how we can handle them and call on a doctor if necessary. 
They also gave us opportunities for questions and answers which addressed most of our challenges as diabetics.
The promised email receipt never arrived.
The psychiatrist wanted me admitted the bed manager refused saying it was Bristol responsibility. We we left waiting in the car park for an hour or there abouts without being told anything
The psychologist was very clear of speech she often offered to repeat information. She listened to myl suggestions.
The quality of care and cleanliness of the environment were excellent, as were the medical machinery which were very up to date.
The quality of care and support was superb and made me feel safe during a very stressful time. I am very grateful to all the staff for this.

The quality of the HCAs varies drastically,  from excellent, organised and efficient to poor , especially the agency staff, who were sometimes unhelpful and acted like they didn't care, i was surprised at the poor quality of some of the staff who made me feel like i was a pain ringing the bell and i openly heard them moaning on occasions, i must stress this was a small number that spoilt it for the large majority who were excellent

The quality of the Nursing team and medical staff was excellent, including the high level of care I received from the ICU team where I was for one night/day.

The environment of the hospital was very clean, spacious and appealing. The quality of the food was very good too.

The experience was a transparent one, by being kept informed and with nurses who listened to my concerns and questions openly.

The quality started at reception and thought
The full evaluation and consultancy ! 

The data Sytems seemed first class on each visit! 

Everyone knew their role and was very friendly helpful and efficient ! 

5star treatment no question !

All the equipment was new and first class
The que outside

The questionnaire asks the number of days you experience certain mental health problems but there needs to be an option to choose that falls between ‘one day’ and ‘several days’, for example ‘2-3 days’.
The questionnaire for some pop arts are with only 4 options and not enough to input accurate information
The queue outside

The radiographer, after having already cancelled my first appointment at short notice, was 20 minutes late arriving to the hospital for the second appointment for which he didn’t apologise. He conducted the scan for about 2 minutes which seemed carelessly quick. He declared I had a disease with no conception of how inappropriate his tone and manner were given the seriousness of this information. It did not seem appropriate to have a male receptionist/attendant and male radiographer only present in the treatment room. The radiographer made a comment about having the male attendant put paper down down my top due to the gel he would be using in the scan which I was not comfortable with. The phlebotomist was chewing gum the entire time he took my bloods and asked me what the samples were for because he didn’t know. The whole experience felt careless and unprofessional.
The radiographers were very efficient & attentive, explained everything clearly and I had no issues at all

The radiologist who carried out my two CT scans was especially kind and equal to the most skilled I have come across in a history of around ten previous scans elsewhere.  My consultant, Dr Wu, is a superb doctor, the best I can imagine.

The radiology CT scanner staff were both extremely nice and told me exactly when I could breathe in, breathe out, and when to hold my breath.

The female echocardiogram radiologist was also very nice and very thorough. She, too, was very specific in telling me when to breathe out, breath in, and when to hold my breath. That was good.

But towards the end of the procedure, she called in a male colleague to take some further readings. He was also polite but I was discomforted by the fact that he told me on at least three separate occasions to breathe right out and hold it. I had no idea how long I should have held empty lungs because he never told me to breath in at all.

He did not tell me when I could breathe in so I gradually ran out of breath which was extremely tiring. He should give clearer instructions. 

This might sound amusing, but it wasn't.

I came out completely exhausted.

The radiology department should have read my notes to know the requirements so that the appropriate scanner was availiable. There shoud be adequate padding, for example a small foam pad or somesuch, to protect pressure points. I am 147lbs and only 5'4" tall, so it is not possible that I'm the largest or most difficult shape/size of patient that they have dealt with.

In view of all the mix ups, delays and subsequent difficulties, in addition to the fact I was in tears and distressed, there should have been a dedicated nurse to see me through the whole process.
The rapport and their ease/honesty when presenting.

The rapport developed with the various teams has been second to none. This is my third major operation, and I feel that this has been the most emotionally and physically taxing at the age of 29. The team have been amazing and I feel that whenever I’ve needed anything I’ve been supported rapidly m.
The reason for the whole process was made clear and I felt comfortable and safe throughout.
The reason is staff were excellent in communicating with regards to my medication and treatment.

The reception at 24 Portland Place does not have space for privacy, there is a lot of noise around that makes all patients who arrive at the Clinic raise their voices and it is difficult to hear the receptionist.
I had paid the total amount for my test and when I arrived at the Clinic the payment was not reflected in my record.
The website does not allow much modification and I had to sign an incomplete document in the Clinic since the receptionist did not hear what I was saying or he wanted to attend the next one on the line.
Except for the nurse and the technician who performed the MRI, the other people at the Clinic at 24 Portland Place were not very friendly to me.
The reception procedure was a little unclear but the consultation and assessment were excellent and on time.

The reception staff and the doctor who did my CPET were all excellent-competent and empathetic.

I think it would have been helpful to have sent clear information about the test before. I personally knew what to expect but others would not have
The reception staff could have been more pleasant with the patients !
The reception staff should be more friendly.
The reception staff were pleasant and welcoming

The reception staff were very friendly and helpful. The healthcare provider, Dr. Manji was exceptionally kind and thorough and communicated clearly with us regarding the diagnosis and next steps. We were very satisfied and impressed with the level of care provided.
The reception team and Nurses show exceptional compassion, regardless of the individual circumstances.

The reception, support, communication, professionalism and treatment was exceptional.
Every member of the team new exactly their part.
The receptionist and staff were so kind and they explained everything with no judgement and I felt comfortable.

The receptionist at the main help desk was very unhelpful and didn’t know the other department staff just her own staff Which was a shame because they were meant to be there to help people. I felt that this was going back to a 1970s experience where staff really didn’t care they were just there for the money or the convenience my own personal experience dealing with my clinician was excellent

The receptionist called me ‘darlin’ repeatedly and whilst it’s ok I personally didn’t particularly find it professional.  I was also sent to the first floor by mistake and receptionist there  kindly went back to reception to check for me.  I should have been directed to third floor.  In the Grand scheme  of things it was fine but as you have asked if things could be handled better I would say that my experience with the reception could be improved
The receptionist could be a little bit nicer over the phone.

The receptionist didn’t understand the needs of my ASD sim and I had to repeat myself several times in insisting in the end the my request was heard. Her response was well everyone has to wait. My son because of his disability cannot wait. The current wait today was 40 minutes. We had to wait last time and he had remembered this. This was a negative experience and meant that today he didn’t want to come. He was aggressive with me leaving the house. It’s important all disabilities are accommodated even the invisible ones. More training required and instant acknowledgment that yes your son will be seen at his appointment time.

The receptionist should have been told that I needed to have a full bladder for ultrasound and I should be reminded and clinic informed when bladder is full so that they can do scan. 
Unfortunately, while waiting, and just after my allocated appointment time, I went and emptied bladder so had to drink more water and wait again

The receptionist that checked me in had a very strong smell of BO, which was very unpleasant. As my procedure was later in the afternoon, I was not able to order food and was chasing to order breakfast the next morning as it had been more that 24 hours since the last time I ate. The dispensing of my medicine to take home took so long, I was supposed to have checked out between 11am-12noon, but this way I was only able to check out at about 4pm. This should have been more swift, as I was being collected and ended up standing in Rushhour traffic for 1.5 hours ontop of the 40min drive home. The bathroom had loads of water stains on the sink and toilet and did not seem that clean. There were loads of paint damage on the walls in room 201. I found the sink far too low for me to brush my teeth and face properly, as I could not bend over after my surgery, The staff were amazing I saw two doctors (never with a nurse), the anaesthetist, a dietitian and numerous nurses during my brief stay. As well as many support staff who were super lovely, caring and amazing!
The receptionist was most unhelpful and difficult showing no empathy
The receptionist was not aware that there was a Lower Limb Clinic on site
The receptionist was very friendly and helpful.
The receptionist, nurse and doctor were really sweet and kind. Felt comfortable.

The receptionists should contact a colleague or put a sigh up (Be right back) if they want to do something personal like using the toilet. It is not of the clients concern what your personnel is doing as long as they provide excellent service.
The records weren't really up to date and I've had to wait a very long time for the hearing test.

The referral was very difficult.  I was sent a text message via my phone - asking me to book the appointment.  But, I was told I couldn't do this on my phone.  So I had to forward the text message to my email address.  I only have an ipad and so was not able to complete the form electronically.  I printed the form off and completed it.  I was then told to scan it and forward it, in an email.  I don't have a scanner at home, so I took a picture of the referral form and attached that to the email.  I then got a reply saying they could not accept my referral in this way - it had to be scanned.  I replied that I do not have a scanner - and was then told it was fine and my referral had been received.  I am fairly computer literate - I'm not sure an older person or someone not used to technology would have worked their way through this system. 

I was then offered a two hour group exercise course - on my phone.  I explained I work in a school with very limited signal - I would not be able to spend two hours, on my phone, trying to engage in a group exercise class.  Plus, up till then, no one had explained what was wrong with my knee and I did not feel comfortable discussing this in front of strangers over the phone. Reluctantly I was given the face to face appointment.

I am very grateful for those, and the physiotherapist I saw was lovely and very helpful.  I just feel the process of getting there was overly complicated and someone less determined or capable would have given up.

Thank you for the opportunity to feed back to you

The referring surgeon really listened and investigated my case. I needed urgent surgery and it was all arranged perfectly and quickly. Your MYCHART App works very efficiently.
      I have been treated in other 5star hospitals but felt the Cleveland to be a cut above. Great facilities and staff that were motivated and made me feel very safe and cared for. Whenever I needed anything I was listened to which for a patient is so important.
The report delivered by Dr Boyle was excellent.
The reservation process seems to have a lot of internal problems. I was asked to change my appointment time with short notice with no reason explained to me.
The resources shared (for instance book references, websites, YouTube videos) + how welcoming and safe it felt was great.
The responses to questions are quite limiting, I wanted to give an in-between response such as occasionally or sometimes.
The right treatment and care should be given to the patient
The room I was seen in was overheated and my appointment was 10 mins late. The clinicsian assumed my spouse was a man and repeated this even once told I am married to a woman .

The room both for this appointent and at normal appointments in dellword is over crowded, has no walls agains which one can easily and naturally do/ demonstrate an exercise - one has to gently mimic things as there is no wall to press against. Physios, need to make a space into a practise area.  (However if one want to check or demonstrate soething to a patient it is not impossible). 

The physio should observe and assess the exercises at the start and have a base line and then should re assess after a period of practise so we are abith aware of the changes - not just one of use and she can she where improvement has been made and more could or not be expected.

The physio needed to assess why my arm was sore at visit 2 before doing manipulation rather than jumping into it.  I had talked of a heavy arm in visit 1, but she said she hadn't noticed the problem in visit 1. However we never discussed further either in visit 1 or visit 2 before doing the manipuation. 

The physio needs training in the use of participative practices - she asks questions which I answer. If she had drawn a time line with me ( as I did on returning home) and noted events and dates we could have identified the issue together on visit 2 , no analysis of the sore arm/ shoulder/ kneck was done till it got worse resulting in visit 3. Even then she did a time line - on her computer for herself, she did not share it or check it with me, and  either key questions were ommitted or key understanding that she would not have had access to was left unidentifed. If she had made it more participative and drawn line on paper and noted dates and activities I could have told her that I had hardly used my arms for 3 weeks and on return took up routine exercise and  the new physio exercises and unplanned manipulation . 

The physio: 
- needs training in simple participative techniques e.g time line and probably other similar such things 
- needs simple tools like paper and pen, or pain chart high = low  etc to use in a participative exporation of patient issue, 
-she needs training and practice in how to evidence her opinions by providing proof  through observation and measures, and detailed questions  rather than relying on subjective chat and talk, and her idea of what is wrong all be it based on long experience.
- she needs to be less hasty and  to ask more questions before forming her judgements e.g. she needs to ask more details on the yoga or bike set up,  or  observe the person on the bike before deciding to advise us on new expensive, inconvenient and inappropriate ways to change our lives and activities

I have been given an appointment with a physio which is 26th June.  I had explained to Shiela my current physio, that  I would be away for 2 months from 1st July.   I would have hoped this would have been passed on and asn appointment made for neared to my previously booked appointment of the 6th June.  I understand the NHS is tight on resources and everyone is busy - however, an appointment on 26th June is a waste of everyones time and NHS resources.  Is there not some other appropriate person who can do it at an earlier stage and who can then give me appropriate support.  Or is this just a way to loose me in the system and bury the case.......
The room was cold but this is understandable given the need for ventilation

The room with the MRI was freezing - it could have been warmer. I would have liked to have kept my socks on - seeing as it was my head only.
The radiographer never came back to fetch the paper which needed signature - I had to go to reception after waiting for 20 minutes.
The radiographer forgot to put the radio station on during the MRI.
The room, nurses and doctor were all fantastic and I was made to feel as comfortable as I could have been (while having a camera stuck up my rear).
The scans should have been available in time for my appointment.

The security/welcome staff at the entrance were very professional and helpful.  I was most impressed by the strict observance of Covid rules. It made me feel being in a safe environment.  The clinic sparkled with cleanliness.  The consultant was most knowledgeable and attentive and explained everything very well.  I am very grateful to him for his time and help.
The self assessment form was the only thing I struggled with - the wording I felt was abit difficult to understand but [name removed] helped me go through it during sessions
The service I experience I was treated with dignity and respect.

The service I experienced was great. In particular I would like to call out nurse Angie Maitland who was incredibly kind and engaging. She helped make me feel calm and was really personable. Emma (night nurse) and Mirela (following morning) were also good.
The service I have received has been exceptional. I have been treated with upmost respect. Amazing and has done an amazing job of helping me recover.
The service I receive from Mrs. Lyn Mason is outstanding she is kind caring and professional. She goes above and beyond want she needs to do.
The service I received was excellent.

The service I received was excellent. She supported both myself and other family members while we were going through a very difficult time following my husband's diagnosis. She got me through some very tough times and I can't thank her enough. I cannot fault the service I received, I am so grateful.
The service I received was very good, the Practitioners that attended to me were very welcoming, nice and understanding.

The service and care I was given was outstanding. From the doctors to the nurses to the catering to the cleaners everyone was lovely.  Two days was not enough.  I would have been happy to stay a week or so!!!!
The service and care was great
The service and care was professional, courteous and informed at all levels.
The service and how quick things got done.

The service from every staff member was excellent and empathetic. I felt that they couldn’t do enough for me and made me as comfortable as possible given that I’m an envious person. Chrystelle (nurse - was amazing) Daniel lee (physio) and Ahmed were also excellent, making me feel at ease during every stage.  Also I visited Portland place for my pre-op and I thought that shoal was super helpful, kind and caring. Exactly what I needed.

The service from our Pallative Nurses, in particular, Helen Sanders, was second to none.  My sisters and I wanted to look after our mum at home but without Helen and her team we would have been outbof our depth.  They gave us so much of their time and gave us confidence to help mum and they always responded to our call for help extremely promptly.  They gave us reassurance as well as administering drugs to make mum comfortable.  Helen really was our angel.

The service from the clinical staff is very good.  However, the reception area (downstairs in the lobby) is always a little chaotic and the people are not very friendly.  The reception team on the 1st floor was much better.
The service has been amazing for my daughter. Very supportive in terms of what they can offer. They have really listened to my daughters views and respected her wishes. Thank you.
The service has been very good it just takes a long time to be seen.
The service has improved and children are being seen a lot quicker when they have been referred, but a few children are also signed off on some occasions too soon from Speech and Language.
The service is always excellent and the staff professional and kind.
The service is chronically underfunded.
The service is excellent, easy to make contact, easy to get to appointments (Saffron Wolden Hospital) very pleasant, friendly and knowledgeable staff.
The service is fantastic. Always going above and beyond to keep me safe and help me recover.
The service is generally good but waiting times need to improve.
The service is generally very good but waiting times need to improve.
The service is professional, complete facilities and clean. We’re treated with respect and dignity.
The service is very high standard, from the beginning till the end. I feel the doctor listened and cared about me.
