This previous lack of communication and documentation of the service meant when I was verbally informed of a consolidation period of therapy, around Easter time. I was told I should contact the service again in September. When I made contact with the service just prior to September, I was informed I was meant to make contact a couple of months earlier and the file had been closed. The file was reopened and I was provided with an appointment in a couple of months. However this impacted my childs care significantly, it meant a prolonged period without therapy and a wait to get an appointment. This resulted in 6 months without treatment, which is a long time for a 2-3 year olds development. 

I don't believe its in a childs interest to rely on a concerned parent to initiate further therapy. A parent may not fully appreciate its importance or may not have the capacity to engage or be fully involved in the best interests of their child. I think its the service who should ensure continuity of care. Possibly providing a follow up appointment following a consolidation period prior to 'closing' a file, effectively discharging a child who needs further treatment. 

Its clear the service requires additional funding to meet the current demand, especially after COVID pandemic. The first 2 years of my childs life was isolated at home with a mother who had postnatal depression. Im not the only parent and child who was significantly impacted by the pandemic. That's why services such as SALT should be funded adequately. The impact of speech and language difficulty in early years clearly shows a life long negative association. I plan to follow up with letters to the service, commissioning bodies and to my MP.

This review is specifically in response to the renal ultrasound I had at Cleveland, Grosvenor Place on 31st May 2023; this review does not in any way reflect any other care I have received, which has been caring and compassionate.

Owing to symptoms of constant nausea and intermittent vomiting for nine months, plus dull pain in lower left back and left stomach, prior to attending Cleveland, London, I had in February and March 2023 a number of investigative procedures, namely on 10th February a Bravo Endoscopy; on 22nd February an Oesophagael Manomentry; on 17th March a Chest CT and on 20th March an Upright Barium Swallow.

I had my first consultant led appointment at Cleveland, London on 5th April, followed by on 19th April an Ultrasound Doppler Aorta (including duplex); on 24th May an MRI abdomen MRCP; on 31st May a Renal Ultrasound and finally on 1st June a Nuclear Medicine Solid Gastric Emptying Study.

My Renal Ultrasound appointment on 31st May was at 08.20hrs and I was asked to arrive at 08.05hrs to prepare me for the scan. As requested, I had drunk one litre of still water at 07.15hrs, i.e. one hour before the scan time.

I arrived at the reception area just before 08.00hrs but it was not until 08.25 that a young male nurse, who was pleasant but looked a little flustered, came to take me to the scanning room at which time I was beginning to feel a little uncomfortable following the amount of water I had taken.

I have had a number of previous renal scans taking a good half hour or more, so knew what to expect, but this scan was nothing like previous scans, as it was perfunctory! The nurse prepared me for the scan, i.e. exposing my stomach and I gave the nurse a report of my previous scan, itemising a number of renal cysts and an angiolipoma from a year earlier, as I thought this might be useful..Just after 08.30 a young male dressed in scrubs entered the scanning room; I assumed he was the doctor/radiologist to do the scan. I looked at him and said hello, good morning. As  he scowled at me and did not reply I thought he had obviously got out of bed the wrong side or someone had upset him - by now the nurse was visably trembling.

The 'Medic' went to the scanning machine and lifted a probe; he then said "I am a consultant and my name is Dr. Tam". He did not look at me, in fact he did not look me in the eyes once during the exceedingly short scan.He looked at the report, I had brought with me, for about ten seconds; he was obviously not interested in my previous report, nor was he interested in me. The scanning procedure was over in less than ten minutes at end of which he said "there's nothing here" and walked away from me. I called him back as I felt hurt that he had not bothered to speak to me for a few minutes. I asked him what he thought my problem may be. He responded by saying "I have no idea, it may be your stomach or something else". He walked away from me again and I called him back again by asking, as I had had issues with kidney cysts for a number of years, "should I have any monitoring?". He shrugged his shoulders and said "That's entirely up to you"; he left the room; he simply didn't care. I regard the cost (£714.00) of this procedure of a  less than ten minute scan with no medical dialogue, as obscene. By now the nurse looked so embarrassed, I thought he was going to burst into tears. I wasn't embarrassed, I was appalled with the doctor's cursory attitude.
This seems to be the way that all treatments are going- (rather depressing) we have to ( are expected) to accept that ie this is not my choice.

This service is outstanding, from my initial contact through to my first session was flawless, timely, professional and reassuring.
My therapist Maddy King is an absolutely outstanding practitioner. I was made to feel confident, comfortable and that each session was progressive. Maddy was able to quickly adapt strategies to suit me personally with enough empathy to be genuinely caring and outstanding practice to give me the opportunity to make rapid, and more importantly sustained progress. I feel much more confident in the future and being able to address and deal with situations with the tools and techniques that I have being taught. Thank you so much, from me and my loved ones!

This was my first visit to the Cleveland Clinic London, and the all experience was incredible. I am myself a health care provider working in a another private hospital and I was impressed with the professionalism and advanced technology provided by your organization

This was my first visit to the Cleveland Clinic for an annual medical.  I had expected that the results would be sent to me, either by letter or email.  When, after a week, these did not arrive, it occurred to me that perhaps that the results had been placed online in 'MyChart'.   On checking this is where everything was.  Not a problem but it might be helpful to be clear about informing people what to expect.

This was my first visit to the Cleveland Clinic.  The friendly and kind, polite welcome at the front door was followed by considerate care from all staff members. It was very impressive and most welcome too.
My doctor, Dr Pattle was very welcoming and helpful. So keen to find answers to my problems.
The whole experience of the Cleveland Clinic was positive, very considerate and made one feel most welcome.
Well done!

This was my second operation at this hospital. My first experience was outstanding but this visit wasn't as good.

On arrival there was a new/inexperienced HCA or nurse. He seemed unsure and wasn't able to find the right words to describe a cuff to take blood pressure. Later the nurse informed me that he was a new member of bank staff. I was very relieved when this bank staff member finished their shift as I didn't feel confident in their abilities to check my vitals.

Later in the day after my surgery, I asked a nurse/HCA (unsure which) if I could have an anti-emetic as I felt nauseous, this member of staff was confused by my request and didn't know what an anti-emetic was. I found this worrying as I'd expect staff working with patients out of surgery to know what an anti-emetic is since nausea is common following surgery.

The overnight nurse however was fantastic and I felt I was in safe hands with her. She was also bank staff but very experienced.

The next day, I was asked by a nurse what time I'd like discharge and I said mid-afternoon. I was then asked by another nurse who informed me that discharge should be at 11am.

From 1200 onwards, I had to repeatedly use the call button to either request meds, drinks and for updates on my discharge and was eventually discharged at 7pm. I was told that I needed to be seen by both pharmacy and a doctor. In the end I didn't see a doctor and was given my discharge papers by a nurse and handed by medications by pharmacy. Due to insistence on staff that I would be discharged soon, I had not ordered dinner and so left the hospital extremely tired and without a meal arriving home at 10pm.

It seemed like there was a lot of mis-communication on this visit and inexperienced staff.

This was my second visit with Vivien Allen and she was very kind and professional with my child.  My 1st visit she said that she will call me in a couple of months to see how my child was doing. 
I was very impressed that she did a follow up and asked me to come with my daughter after asking a few questions. Vivien did not rush us and took her time with my daughter.
I think she is very good
This was my sixth visit, and each time the levels of care, information, and service have always been excellent.
This was one of the best experiences of NHS care I've had.

This was one of the most poorly organised examples of private health care I have experienced. Here is the schedule:
1. Fri 21 Oct - My cardiologist's assistant tells me she has booked a CT Cardio Angiogram at Cleveland Clinic for the coming Mon 24 Oct, and that the clinic would be calling me to arrange the exact time. No one from the clinic calls.
2. Mon 24 Oct - Around 10am, I call my cardiologist to confirm that no one from Cleveland has been in touch. They chase Cleveland clinic, and a lady called "Katie" eventually calls me. We agree a time, but she tells me that because I have had a cup of tea that morning (unsurprising since I have been given zero notice or instructions about the procedure), she will need to confirm that it is still ok. Katie never calls back. She also doesn't tell me the address where the procedure will take place, nor does she bother sending me an email to confirm. She has also not provided me with a return phone number, so I again have to ask my cardiologist's assistant to chase. Eventually, someone (not Katie) calls from Cleveland to tell me that the procedure will be at Portland Place. He seems utterly confused when I ask him why I havent received a confirmation email, but eventually he sends one to me.
3. Mon 24 Oct - I arrive at Cleveland Clinic, and at check in, am cheerily greeted by the aforementioned Katie who says she was the one who spoke to me earlier. She still has absolutely no sense of awareness of the fact that she provided me with no information at all about my appointment, and has no sense of shame about her inadequate performance.
4. Mon 24 Oct - The quality of care I receive is slapdash, amateurish and verging on the insulting. The radiologist and assistant who performed my angiogram seemed to be doing this for the first time. They were uncertain, unhelpful, and left me in physically uncomfortable positions for extended periods of time. On completion, there was zero after care - the radiologist was extremely unhelpful with where I should go next. Bearing in mind what I had just been through, I should have some assistance. There was absolutely none. There was no one to show me back to the changing room, and when I found it, there were used gowns strewn on the chairs in the room. I complained at reception, but I doubt very much that any action was taken, so I am writing this all down now.
This was simply a brief visit to be tested for Covid, MRSA and Candida before admission to hospital. It was handled in a kind and efficient way.

This was such a relief. I was treated as a person, was listened to, had things explained to me and reassured.

But here it is… in Central London… who knew.  In particular, I would like to give my heartfelt gratitude to Dr. Colin Hart. Just exceptional.   I am very grateful for the care and attention.

To me this is not acceptable, especially as I have recently had mobility problems and could not stand for 5 minutes let alone 30 minutes. Also you are unable to book an appointment in advance, why? If people don’t turn up for their appointments they should pay a fine. Once you have the appointment every thing is great, staff, doctors, nurses and paramedics all do a great job.

Two issues:
1. I attended a scan in the morning of 4 November.  I waited until a 3pm appointment with Dr Kwan.  When I saw him he noticed that the scan was incomplete and an MRA had been done but not an MRI.  I therefore had to return the following week to do the MRI.  This was an unnecessary waste of time and cost.

2. I was then fitted with a zio-heart monitor and scheduled a call for 9 December to review the findings of the monitor.  The impact of that was that I did not hear the results of the scans for over a month.  The all I heard from the Cleveland was from Dr Kwan's medical secretary by email that there were some findings which Dr Kwan would discuss in December.  This delay was unnecessarily stressful.

Unfortunately I tested positive for Covid-19 the day before my original date for surgery, Thursday August 4. I was completely asymptomatic so was shocked to receive this result.

I was given conflicting information by the Admissions team when trying to rebook my procedure. Initially I was told that I would only have to wait 2 weeks before I could have surgery. So I asked to be added to Ms Murphy's list on Thursday August 18. 

I was then told that in fact the hospital is following national guidance issued by the Royal Colleges that there should be a 7 week delay between a positive test result and surgery. Even though I was asymptomatic, had isolated for 5 days, and tested negative for a further week.

Fortunately Ms Murphy and Dr Appleby overruled this guidance and the surgery went ahead as planned.

I would suggest that your staff should be briefed on the current situation regarding Covid-19 guidelines at the hospital. If I had not questioned this decision, I would still be waiting for my surgery so I do wonder how other, less persistent patients, would have fared!

Unfortunately I was late due to traffic in London I phoned and explained my situation and they were very helpful and understanding and made sure my appointment was still available and spoke to the doctor to make sure he new I was coming.

Unfortunately my experience was completely let down by Dr Maniyars secretary Alison. I had to chase for my follow up letter which included details on my new medication. That took 2 weeks. I then found out the letter had never been sent to my GP, she told me she didn’t have the details, but strangely never thought to call me to ask…even though the letter stated a copy should be sent to the GP. She then finally asked for me to send the details after nearly 4 weeks. One week later, still no letter sent to my GP, I found out she hadn’t added the details to the system. I had to chase and was completely ignored, no response from her. I then called the contact centre, I was told there are daily complaints from patients about this woman… it took for a very helpful lady to ask Alison what was going on… the GP details were then added to my profile…. That was 5 weeks later. I should have started the medication around the time of my consultation 5 weeks previous. For all this woman knew I could be extremely ill and needed that medication quickly. I am shocked that she never ever thought to call me and doesn’t seem fit for the job.

Unfortunately upon my discharge the pharmacy department missed one of the main pain relief medications which was morphine. I didn't realise that it was missing as the lady from pharmacy didn't read it out to me. It was only when I read my discharge notes that it was prescribed. I needed it today because of the pain, luckily my GP prescribed it for me. Also I should have had above knee ted stockings but the hospital only had stock of below knee. The GP is rectifying that for me. I didn't receive a phonecall from the hospital today, I was informed that I would do to check on me.

Unfortunately when i got to floor 1, there was no one at reception. A few people came and went but no one acknowledged me. About 15 minutes later after repeatedly looking up as I was curious about whether I was checked in or not, someone finally spoke to me and asked what I was waiting for. 
I then had the ultrasound however it started late. No one explained the delay. It was a 9am appointment so it’s difficult to understand the reasons for 10 minutes lateness. I was 15 minutes early to the appointment as instructed which just meant I’d wasted about half an hour of my time waiting around. 

I also had a blood test- again I got to the department and there was sadly no one there to welcome me or speak to me. I waited sat on a chair for about ten minutes before someone came out to take the test. 

That said, the check in staff and service on ground floor were impeccable. Friendly, welcoming, efficient and really clear.

Unfortunately, GPs are given too little time to deal with patients and many have little understanding of the emocional fragility mental health patients experience. As a result I now don’t book as many appointments with a GP to discuss my mental health as I need.
Unfortunately, the initial application was lost so it took longer to start the assessment.

Unfriendly and confusing check in. Staff seemed out of their depth and unsure about how to check me in. This did not instil confidence. I would be reluctant to attend the clinic again without significant improvements.
Universally friendly, informed me welcoming staff, with clear details of the procedure and the outcome.

Unlike the first doctor (dr kunchi) i saw at parsons heath , dr pickford knew exactly how to show compassion and actually listened. She then referred me to steph olding who actually made me feel like i wasnt crazy and did her best to help me move forward after having a hard time. She gave me the best advice she possibly could and took the time to really listen and try and help.
Unsure of my symptoms, feeling quite low. Lots of reassurance from HTT. Now able to focus on future, looking at other services.

Until alternate accommodation has been I have felt at all times that I was listened to and treated with care and respect that any person my age would be only to glad to have.I am very grateful for the care and courtesy I have received at all times from all members of staff and I am quite willing to stay here until alternate accommodation has been found for me.

Updates on drop in clinics
Upon arrival nobody was at reception so we had to wait outside for 20 minutes.

Upon arrival the reception staff were fine, when I was taken to get changed I came out of the room and no one was there, I was stood there for a while before someone passing asked if I was okay and took me to where I needed to go, if they had not of walked past I would of been stood there for ages. When I was taken down to the room for the MRI there was little to no explanation of the process and with it being my first I was very nervous. I was told I’d have music playing and I didn’t. I had two injections one was for my bowel the other, I have no idea what this was. I had earrings I couldn’t get out and was told these would need to be covered by tape, they didn’t give me any tape and just said to let them know if they start to pull, how dangerous is that?! I had no awareness of how long I was in there and once done the lady in charge didn’t even say one word to me, let alone ask if I was ok. I was taken back to get changed I came out of the room again and was left, some time later someone walked passed and I asked if I was ok to leave and how to get back to reception. This experience was awful and has put me off having any further treatment here. I was told I’d get my results on Friday, and they came through today late afternoon. I’d really appreciate being refunded for this treatment cost as I feel I was treated so badly and that is not the level of care you should receive, especially when paying those prices. Please contact me as soon as possible to resolve this.

Upon arrival there was some confusion as to why I had come in early for my bloods to be taken which I was advised to do on my telephone assessment the week before. This did mean some time waiting around whilst this communciation misunderstanding was resolved. My bloods were taken but it took a while to sort out.

Upon entering the building I was met with security who was very welcoming and polite and asked me about my appointment and if I could wear a face covering. I was then met by a very pleasant receptionist who sent me up to the correct floor. I was then shown up to the floor by one of the nurses who happened to be going up in the lift. Every member of staff I met was very friendly, the clinic was very clean, and my experience with the doctor (Dr Jayaseelan) was very positive, she made me feel very comfortable. I then went up to Floor 4 for a blood test which was administered by a lovely nurse, who sent me on my way with a latte and biscuit. The whole experience was great from start to finish.

Urgent no urgent a wait defines both!and as like me not urgent to be treated/asked like it was makes me think what!if an urgent person waited couple weeks then they wouldn't of answered!no?no!?also I just asked for councelling not death on my doorstep talking so does that make me want to go back to the GP not really as any help is not the help you ask for!!!

Very polite, kind S&L therpaist who was excellent at demonstrating the therapy/games. But many improvements and resoures required to deliver therapy overall could be made:

1. Ideally before the first session or at first session need to inform parent approximately how much time is needed for therapy per day so parents can start thinking about when they will fit this into their day. In my sons case (with probable ASD) it is not just 5 minutes of special time but around 20 minutes per day in total. My husband and I have had to make time for therapy on weekdays when my son does not attend nursery and weekends. We have 2 other children. If there is more than one child at home need to inform parent that the other children will need to be kept busy in order for the therapy. No TV on, no toys around the room. No time for therapy/distractions means therapy will not work!

2. Writing my own notes in sessions means that I deliver better therapy. This definitely worked for my other son who had therapy in 2019. Parents should be given the option/encouraged to write their own notes to help them deliver therapy correctly at home.

3. Some of the games are very dated (2004!) - in black and white, pictures not clear, very unappealing for a three year old. I think this is a huge area of improvement. Therapy using dated games did not/are not working for my son at home. Nursery also commented the same that the sheets are so old and my son is not interested in them at all. Therapy using vibrant clear pictures was/is much more successful with my son.

4. Online videos of popular therapies to be made available to parents to refer to regaulrly to ensure parents are doing therapy correctly. Even if 1 or 2 can be made this is a starting point and provides motivation and reassurance for parents.

5. More sessions are required for children. I am really worried that the number of sessions he has received is not enough and he will struggle with S&L when he starts school next year.

And after meeting Emily for our assessment we now feel that there is help and care for us as a family. I'm physically disabled and my wife has been living with a brain tumor! And together we have been the only help for our Son. Now for the first time we will have the help we need.
We are being advised and helped every stage with care and dignity

We are currently awaiting assessments for our son to start for his Autism diagnosis, however in the meantime we have a support phone call from a Neurodevelopmental Practitioner which we found incredibly helpful and supportive. The appointment was allocated to us incredibly fast and [name removed], who we spoke with, was so kind, understanding and informative. She immediately followed up with lots of material to help support our son and us as a family.
We are familiar with vaccinations and trust the nhs. The staff were friendly and helpful.

We are trying really hard for our daughter to be diagnosed for this will support her needs in the coming future. Us parents have seen so much change in her as she is growing up/development.
We feel we have given more than enough information on her & her past but we are still fighting her corner.
Would be good if we were heard from our side of our daily evidence with our adopted daughter.

P.s lovely staff.

We arrived on a Saturday morning. There was not a clear explanation of how the room facilities worked as a result. It would have been good if the TV was ‘on’ so that we could use the guide to understand what was available and save any confusion. 
Meals were often delivered 40 to 90 minutes late. This had an impact on medication and the next meals or physio etc. It would be good to order meals from the room using the computer system as this will save time. Catering staff were very busy, English language and confidence was at times, an issue. Trays were not always collected swiftly nor were water jugs replaced. It was very hot too so fresh water and checking on patients would have helped. When the buzzer was used to call catering, the nurses still had to respond and summon catering.

In theory, we could order snacks. They never materialised when we tried.

We cannot thank the team enough, especially [name removed] for the support and care [name removed] has received, it has been exceptional.  I wish I had been given the kinds of tools that [name removed] now has available to her to navigate the challenges she faces and will face in life, many adults will never have that benefit of those tools.

We have watched [name removed] grow and cope as she has begun to use the tools and, although she still has a long way to go on her journey without [name removed]'s weekly presence, we know she will continue in her journey to managing her anxiety.  I wish every child, with or without anxiety or other needs had the opportunity to have this support (even if limited) as pre-empting issues is so much more powerful than fixing them when they appear.

We did agree a 16 week period for my counselling but unfortunately we did not deal with some of the issues because my mother died just before the conclusion of our sessions and as my mother's  behaviour had coloured my life to a great extent, it do feel I may need more counselling regarding the effects she has had upon my life experiences.  The fact that the sessions came to an end when they did in relation to these issues was not the fault of anyone and can only be put down to what is termed as an act of God.  My psychologist did in fact mention that I may be reassessed for further sessions should I feel the need arises.  My mother's  funeral is yet to take place.
We did learn some useful info and were encouraged that help is availible.
We did not get an answer to our question re cost.
We didn’t get the letter re the appointment but other than that the service is great!

We didn’t need a covid check phone call beforehand and we don’t need multiple reminders. The reminder system needs to be different for private individuals as opposed to those dependent upon carers and care homes. A simple text asking you to send C for confirmation just once should be sufficient. This system is operated by hairdressers who have similar issues with lengthy appointments where failure to attend has a major financial impact.
We didn’t realise we would be responsible for getting rid of the yellow bin. Maybe in the future it could be explained better

We experienced sensitive support and guidance at a traumatic time. We felt totally confident in their recommendations for treatment. We felt overwhelmed and perhaps there were a few more questions we would have asked. However a phone call will sort that.
We feel Dad is in the best place for his needs and his comfortable and well looked after.    We particularly like the way all the staff treat Dad with the ultimate respect and dignity.
We feel considerated and respected by everyone in the assessment and review. They tried to understand our needs especially we moved to the country just 2 years ago.
We felt looked after.
We for funding from gosh for additional therapy sessions but I do think all CP patients would benefit from more regular sessions
We found every one very kind

We found it difficult to get to Whitestone, where as the RISE centre in Upper Abbey Street, where latterly [name removed] had her sessions, has really good resources and is virtually unused.

I would be really beneficial if some of the techniques and approach could be condensed into a 6 week course that was run at schools for higher risk/struggling pupils in a group setting.  Whilst [name removed]'s care was excellent, it often felt quite selfish for us to have this when so many young children and teens are struggling with issues, particularly post Covid, and CBT could be helping them but 1:1 care is expensive and intensive, so the waiting list must be huge.
We found the service to be very helpful, and the person helping us polite, sociable and pleasant. Thank you.
We got all the information we needed and were advised on who to see next. My son was seen on time and everyone was respectful. The doctors explanations were clear.

We got an appointment letter stating that we have an appointment on Sunday 17th December, at 10.15 am at the Lighthouse centre. We cancelled our plans, arranged and paid for childcare and made all our way to the Lighthouse Centre to find out that it was closed! This is very unprofessional to say the least!

We had Louise from Dunmow - she vaccinated my son, who afterwards almost fainted.  She acted quickly, professionally and was unbelievably calm and reassuring.  She was quick to reassure my son it was a common reaction and quick to reassure me, a very worried mum.  Thank you Louise.

We had a bumpy start with Clinical Partners, regarding administration and organisation of assessment appointments. Contact details were shared. our appointments had to be rearranged, which delayed the process. However, putting administrative issues aside, the actual clinical appointments were conducted with respect and professionalism and I believe the clinicians understood my needs very well.
We had a little query about wether we were elegible and what criteria we came under

We had an appointment on a Saturday, so we had plenty of attention.
The surroundings were very pleasant and I now wish I had taken full advantage of offers of coffee etc.
We had good treatment
We had great meetings with the team members when they first got involved with our son. The commitment shown was second to none. Very impressed. Thank you all.

We had hoped to have a subsequent talk with the consultant in person or by phone, as my son (who accompanied me) had not been present when I returned from surgery.

Also, when logging into the wifi, a message appeared that the Clinic did not have a 'trusted security certificate'.

We had our home visit today with [name removed] and found her to be really informative and welcoming. 
We feel we have been given lots of information and support to help guide us on our sons autism journey
We had towait for a while to beseen.

We have absolute trust in Mr Imber. he is an extraordinary surgeon and human being. Very professional, concise in his medical expetrise and communication of medical issues to his patients - and yet warm and approachable, without being too familiar. he is the mos professional doctor a parient can wish for.
We have always had long discussions about all of my daughter's needs and all available options so we can pick the best for her.
We have always received a very good service for my child. The staff are kind and caring.

We have been delighted with the care and compassion that we have received from everyone at the Cleveland Clinic.  This was a very hard time for us and they made the whole experience calming, secure and seamless.  We would and already have highly recommended both Professor Jamie Murphy and the Cleveland Clinic

We have been very lucky to be in your establishment with all Staff members so polite, caring and specifically Professor Shetty whose been Instrumental in providing the care I needed Urgently and delicately as it was to do with the Nerve Pain that zi have been suffering for over 5 years with no answer or cure to treat ir minimize the pain I had in my pelvic area. The Doctor is without any doubt in my experience as one of the best Healtcare Professionals I have come across in my entir life with his great level of understanding with my clinical problem and the way to deal with it. Very straighforward and quick in the Diagnosis and the way to treat it. No words can be enough to describe my feelings towards thid great Doctor and the Environent in which I have received my great Care.

We have been waiting to see someone at the lighthouse for 2years collectively because her first gp referral got refused and nobody notified me. So I was waiting for an appointment without knowing she didn't make it as far as the waiting list. I have never once received a response to any emails I have sent and I've sent numerous.
We have got a lot out of therapy and have worked through a lot of our worries. The Therapist has been brilliant and very helpful.
We have had a  number of appointments recently. Itbis not vlear to which one this refers. Perhaps your text should include bisitcdate?
We have had a very difficult year but you, Sian and Norin have stood out with your professional approach and care you have given Dad and to us as a family. We are very grateful.

We have had the best care we could possibly want. Lauren Rule especially goes above and beyond what could be expected. I’m writing this on behalf of my husband Ian Pummery who has brain cancer. She has helped him/us with every possible equipment and so many helpful tips. She is very patient and feels like a friend. I cannot speak highly enough of her.

We have no complaints about the services received but feel that the NHS should provide ongoing services to people with progressive conditions so they don't need to go through a re-referral process if they deteriorate and need further help
We have received a great care nothing to suggest

We have seen Suvitha for 3 weeks now, she is really good with my daughter and very informative. Marnie loves coming and Suvitha already understands Marnie and what she struggles with and enjoys. I am finding the sessions informative and also feeling like I am doing something right when suggestions are made and I am already doing them (it is so nice to have comments about doing right). The suggestions given to me are useful and helping me understand my daughters needs and how to achieve them. Suvitha is easy to talk to and listens to my concerns.

We have seen an improvement in the patient's condition. The nurses are experienced in dealing, and the physiotherapists are excellent and take care of the patient's condition and have plans and goals to improve the patient's condition and make the most of his stay in the hospital. The Arabic food is sponsored by Chef Youssef and Joan is delicious and meets the needs of Arab patients. We hope to expand the Arabic menu, especially with the advent of Ramadan
We need more help to loose weight/diabetes programme and sessions is not enough.
We received a pleasant and comprehensive visit and all our questions were answered.

We received an invitation for the 27 month review, the letter was dated 15th Nov 2023. I've tried calling 3 times, leaving a voicemail each time, no one got back to me. Today my GP contacted us saying they have received a letter stating we had not booked in an appointment yet, and the offer will expire at 30 months. We are at a loss on how to book an appointment.
We received excellent care well done all round

We saw Mr Fox for my husbands shoulder Injury which we had hoped may be suitable for a supra scapular nerve repair. Sadly this wasn’t advisable and not really what we wanted to hear as we had high hopes after 4 years of chronic pain. Despite the less than hoped for news, the reasons were clearly explained in a way that made the decision completely logical. The entire consultation was made with a great deal of care and empathy for my husbands plight and we really appreciated the honest professional opinion and the advice to explore further options.
We think Rose Begby is a very professional, empathetic and experienced speech therapist. We feel she offers huge knowledge and support to our family.

We tried to access the service three years ago through our GP as my son was experiencing tics, and we suspect him of having ADHD. We were denied access and instead referred to Early Help. Three years later my son's tics are worse and we have again tried to gain access to the Lighthouse Centre through the Neu Pathway. We started this journey in January and have only just seen the referral paperwork completed by the Early Help practitioner. Despite evidence provided within the document of the struggles we face as a family daily, the practitioner has stated within the document that he doesn't feel our son has an ND need. We feel we have got no further forward in gaining support for our son and he is suffering for it.

We visited Jo physiotherapist who listened contently, taken care with writing our concerns and notes and invited other staff within our care to help with decision making and second opinions to help move forward.

We waited for 4.5 hrs only to be told that we should have either gone to GP Or AE and not come here. The nurse asked us to go pick any OTC medication as there is sickness going around and it is normal. This was the suggestion after we told her that patient had been awful since few weeks and GP appointment was not available for 2 weeks. She refused to give any prescription medicine. Refused to suggest safe OTC antihistamine and decongestant taking into consideration her asthma. My daughter is struggling to breathe and sleep since two days, suffering from bad cough, headache, breathlessness and she refused to give any medicine……go to your go or a&e…..why did you come to us…
We was both listened to.
We was treated with respect and death with very well.

We were asked to bring in homework but then these items were never used, not an issue but would have been interesting to see what activity would have taken place. 
I think 3 sessions was fine but I think we would have achieved more if we had just a couple more as the children had just began getting to know each other and had began getting the confidence in talking to each other so a few more sessions would have been really helpful.
We were assisted by the nurse Mariana who was compassionate and very helpful towards my elderly Mother and Dr Wu did a thorough examination as well.
We were attended to with great care and help.

We were caring for our lovely Mum at home when she started deteriorating- this is when we called on the services of Palliative Care. 
Somebody sent us Helen, our Ange as we called her! We felt so supported and safe under Helen’s care. She was never minutes away when we NEEDED her and quite frankly we couldn’t have got through these last 2 weeks without her and her team - Susie and Sally. They are all so caring and compassionate.  We can’t thank them enough. They are all such beautiful beings - such special people.
We were given plenty  of practice materials. We were given Psychiatrist support that was very helpful. Much more help was given than expected.
We were given plenty of practice materials. We were given Psychiatrist support that was very helpful. Much more help was given than expected.

We were greeted as we arrived direct to the car park where we were met by another member of the team who showed us to the treatment room. A very smooth run operation quick and efficient was very happy with the overall experience

We were greeted by a large number of staff upon arrival, we already knew how much the consultation fee would be and we we are more than happy with our Consultant who my husband has been seeing for a number of years, previously at the private rooms of the National Hospital for Neurology at Queen Square, London Worryingly,  there does seem to be a problem with aftercare administration.   Since coming to the Cleveland Clinic in November, we have had no official  confirmation letter regarding  the details of that appointment  more importantly during that Consultation my  husband's prescription was changed and  we have had no official confirmation of this change, either by email or written notification.  I did phone the Clinic after a few weeks to let them know that this was the case and the person to whom I spoke assured me she would contact someone in admin to remedy this. To-date we have received no further communication with regard to  the Consultation and   prescription change. If the Clinic is having problems recruiting permanent office staff, use agency staff in the interim.

Regarding overall cleanliness,  in the waiting area prior to seeing the Consultant, there were used beverage cups littering  tables adjacent to the chairs which no member of staff had bothered to remove.  We hadn't ordered the drinks so they just remained there during the l5 minutes or so that we were sitting in that particular waiting area.
We were impressed by the efficiency, the cleanliness, the environment, the kindness and attention of the personnel.

We were late due to a train crash the consultant waited for us and still showed me great care and attention even though I was over half an hour late when I was upset after my appointment the nursing staff came and gave me a cup of tea and asked me if I wanted to go to a private room

We were looked after so well . All staff were excellent and especially Priya (A&E) who was brilliant with my daughter and provided all the necessary information to continue treating her Illness at home . Cannot fault anything . Thanks very much
We were looked after very well.

We were made to feel very welcome during our session, the activities we took part in were very enlightening as to how to approach certain behavioural situations during play.

Our appointment wasn’t rushed at all and Kathryn gave me a lot of good advice to take away with me.
I believe my daughter will benefit from our visit.
We were not kept waiting after assessment. Staff were professional and polite.
We were seen promptly after contacting 111. Due to them sending us to the wrong hospital, the staff were great at explaining why. The staff were excellent and attentive
We were seen very quickly, all the staff were nice and kind. I was also surprised seeing so many nurses working while we were here.
We were seen very quickly. Everybody gave us a chance to talk. Dr was very good.
We were told when we were there that there are 2 designated parking spaces but we were not told about them or where they are in the appointment letter.
We were totally blown away by the care and attention that was provided to us from the first visit to the day we left the hospital.
We were totally satisfied with the services of the Physiotherapists. The way Mum was handled and explained and helped Mum build her confidence.
We were treated very good.
We were treated very well by the doctor and by the translator, both were professional.

We were treated very well from the time we entered the building until the time we left
Everybody we met were courteous and helpful
All our questions were answered in a satisfactory manner and some people went out of their way to find answers for us
We were treated well and kept informed even when we had to wait because the consultant was running late
We were treated with empathy and sympathy.
We were treated with respect and pate.

We were treated with respect and satisfied with the service that we got. We are happy because Emma has even gone out of her way to make further enquiries on our behalf and to do some follow ups about the other procedures.
We were treated with the greatest care and compassion and were given all the information we could have expected at this time.

We were under the impression  that the fast track funding had been applied for but Bindy from [name removed] came the following week and informed us there was no record of this which meant there was a week delay in the application.
I’m not sure if this was a misunderstanding on our part but was not clear. This is the only thing that I could think of the rest was excellent
We were unsure about where we could park. I can't walk well or too far, so it would be difficult if I had to walk from the main general hospital car parking areas.

We were very grateful to have a someone to call if we were worried when Barnaby come out of hospital. When Barnaby had his relapse we were able to contact the service quickly, everyone knew him and his case which was very reassuring also Barnaby responded so much better knowing the staff Anthony and Debra.
We were very happy with the care of the nurses, therapists, and doctors. Cleveland Clinic London has outstanding staff and caregivers.
We were very satisfied with the care and the consultant I could not answer the question about costs as the care is still not completed .
We were welcomed and processed in a polite and timely manner. The staff were proactive and engaging.
We weren't sure where to wait and there were no water cups for a drink

We weren’t greeted when we arrived, A,C  was too high so felt very cold had to move to a different location in the waiting room as I got pain in my head from the coldness. 
The toilets were very poor & old fashioned not tidy paper towels just on side not in towel holder. toilet paper and paper towels on floor. I’m disabled so this was dangerous. The mens toilets my husband used had broken mirror and had been taped up. Not really a very comfortable waiting area and facilities. 
However the doctor I saw was 5 ⭐️ and gave me all the time I needed and was very thorough. friendly and polite.
We wish All the professionals visiting nursing homes could be of some nursing background, so that its easy for both parties to focus on the actual issues and expedite necessary support plan.
We wish to have these session more often
We would all enjoy a longer visit.
We would have liked to have more contact with the Doctors who had diagnosed my husband over the phone and have never had a follow up appointment to see someone
We would have preferred to continue.
We would like to understand when our sons assessments are due to start to understand timelines and if a diagnosis is possibly before he starts school in September 2024 to aid the correct support.
We're very grateful for your support. You may not realise it, but you've been such an advocate to the family.
Wealth of information, really clear slides and pictures.

Website needs updating re car park, currently says cash only but in fact takes cards.

I'd raided the coin bottle for £5 in coins (10p & 20p coins) and then forgot to take my wallet

Machine would only take £2.50 in coins then said "No more coins"....intercom button on machine didn't work so I had to go back inside & queue....

Luckily security guy validated my ticket & out I went
Weekly online review needs update not always relevant.

Welcomed professionally as always : 
All staff are always polite , considerate and willing to help and listen . 
Always very much appreciated.
Welcoming and non-judgemental environment.

Welcoming receptionist, hygienically clean  environment.nursing staff very professional and friendly. Consultant came to see me before and after my procedure and explained the complications preoperatively and the treatment done postoperatively.
Welcoming receptionist.

Welcoming staff, and environment of the waiting room was clean & comfortable & provided good quality refreshments to enjoy while you wait.  Waiting was only brief.  My doctor, Professor James Teo was very personable, a good listener and able to give a good assessment and immediate diagnosis and treatment options and opinion to help me decide the best way forward.  I very much appreciated his calm and friendly manner & expert advice. Thank you.
Welcoming staff. Very caring.
Welcoming, clean and pleasant building. Efficient and friendly staff. Excellent Clinician
Welcoming, explaining to us all about the test. Pleasant, informative, fast, knowledgeable. Everything was great.
Welcoming, understanding and friendly.
Welcoming,, clean, professional, efficient
Well  the obvious thing to be done is test all women  who are  age relevant  for conception  and
Well (and I know this is impossible/stupidly expensive), but to have [name removed] come once-a-week to do the exercises with my Mum!

Well I found it all interesting and from other people as well so we are not alone group sessions are so much better than dealing with one to one. The staff are so brilliant as to what they do and help and guide us in every step of the way. I would still love to be in touch with the team and try get more help as drs don’t listen to us at all .thank you long covid team love the work you do to try help us and supplying the slides etc  the mindfulness and restful ones were great as well helped with the breathing exercises as well.
Well I understood why I needed it I just wondered what meningitis meant
Well cared for but far too hot in the building.
Well cared for.
Well designed nice new hospital with a combination of comfort with a sense of medical competence. I already knew Mr Nathwani, he is an excellent surgeon and this new setting suits him well.
Well explained and kind.
Well informed and good care
Well informed on treatment etc, very respectful and very kind
Well informed staff. Attentive, good follow-up. Prompt appointed times.
Well informed.
Well led and informative.
Well looked after
Well looked after from start to finish of my appointment.
Well looked after throughout
Well looked after, lots of support offerered
Well looked after.
Well organised and informative session for both Mum and I. It was great for Mum to meet other people with Dementia as she has felt as though she is the only person diagnosed, thank you.

Well organised and very efficient. It sometimes very difficult to obtain a visit to a real Doctor, the practice should go back to pre level service. On another note the car park needs to be altered by removing the bushes and a turn left only sign at the exit for safety reasons.
Well organised dedicated staff working in a first rate environment
Well organised professional set up
Well structured and informative.
Well structured and responsive with first class facilities
Well treated, spoken to politely, with smiling faces.
Well treated.
Wendy who I see at SWCH is always kind and makes me feel better in myself as well as my poor feet.

Went above and beyond, kept me informed st all times of situation.
Excellent service.

Went above and beyond.
Staff are fantastic and supportive.
Went through my exercises with me, which was helpful.

Westcall could update patients who are waiting to hear from them with an expected wait time. I’ve been awake all night through fear of missing a call and an appointment. The nurse I spoke to believes I need antibiotics but I haven’t been able to receive any so still have a high temperature.

What I did imagine before I started was that there would be more human input than there was. After a long assessment interview over the phone to get me onto the treatment, I then received a couple of brief telephone calls before the communication moved to email. It's hard to say whether more personal contact would have made any difference. At the same time I'm receiving treatment for my alcohol consumption from v-i-a, and I do have personal contact with them. Inevitably there is an overlap between the two treatments and contact with them has been a help with my CBT.

What I noticed was that one of the hospital’s strengths, at times was also a potential Achilles Heel. To get the best out of a highly diverse team, systems and processes are vital. There were small discernible  breakdowns in this regard, eg food orders that were fumbled, not delivered correctly and sometimes not at all.  The pharmacy took hours to deliver the meds on check out, the shampoo dispenser in the shower was broken and I left the room with it still broken. The foregoing are trivial except that they are likely managed by the same set of central protocols and it is vitally important that the hospital get these 100% correct to ensure that health and safety is also 100% maintained. The Cleveland Clinic has outstanding facilities and world class consultants - it is important that the systems that support this are also maintained to world class standard. Less there be a misunderstanding - individually, the people selected are each gems and I could only wish to someday die in the hands of people such as you have working at Cleveland Clinic. But each of these all-stars needs to be coached and coordinated to deliver the service Cleveland Clijoc is capable of delivering.
What a lovely visit no stress easy parking staff were kind and compassionate. If needed appointment here would be much appreciated.
What gave me the answer is that the staff were caring and attentive.

What they did was ok - The outcome wasn't want I wanted.
I don't know what I expected but I was hoping for more help in getting better.
I was hoping to get more help.
What to do if you get pregnant and want to keep the child

What you could had done better was that I wish I was told what the doctor was going to do to me before she did it rather than asking me that I’m comfortable and happy which she should had done but she should had ask me if I had further questions and what she was going to do throughout the assessment and better explain to me what my condition was thank you .
When HCPs visit can they just give a little more time to listen to patient and for patient to get settled.
When HTT came to see husband, lots of reassurance given. We are now going out and about, going for walks.

When I 1st spoken I was broken sad and didn’t care bout anything 
After speaking to Patsy I was feeling more safe and in control of my feelings and stress levels
Patsy has helped me though a hard time and I’m hopeful I will get a move for a new life to start over 
Thank you it’s people like patsy and others that make a difference to peoples life’s like me 
And she was very nice and understanding 10/10

When I arrive at the reception desk I was totally ignored for a few minutes and I thought it would be courteous for one of the receptionist to at least acknowledge that I was there and that they would deal with me when they finished their current work. Eventually I was asked my name et cetera.

When I arrived the internet was down at the hospital and the physiotherapist did not have access to my x-rays. 

That was not good.
When I arrived the nurse took my vitals in the hallway near the elevator in the third floor !! I’m a Muslim I can’t uncover all my hand like that……you need to address this matter problem soon

When I called the community nursing group by phone, I was led to believe that it would be a long time before we could get an assessment done and even then my Dad might not qualify for an internal catheter. I had to call my GP surgery to ask for help and they referred to the community nursing for a bladder scan. Only as a result of that call did something positive happen. I felt like I was not getting any help until the nurse arrived.
When I came I wasn’t eating the food ,tempted me to eat again with the help of the staff

When I contacted the admissions team advising I was running late, they were friendly and  helpful on the phone with managing and checking that I could still be seen for my appointment. 

Nurse provided seamless care.

When I first got here, should’ve been handled better. I was told it’s protocol, it was not explained to me properly, within minutes I was stark naked.  Also, I was offered the welcome pack when I was naked on the bed, this should have been given before I was naked

When I first rang the surgery I was treated with kindness and compassion from the receptionist. When speaking to Jason, I felt listened to and supported. I feel so much better and can’t thank Jason enough.

When I heard that Cleveland Clinic had opened in London, I immediately decided to come in for a complete checkup because I have dealt with them in Florida and was always impressed by the professionalism and thorough service. The London office did not disappoint. I felt truly well taken cared of.  I was even offered a snack box that included a healthy sandwich, gluten free rice cakes, an apple and a bottle of water. This was greatly appreciated after an overnight fast. They have updated my chart with all of my test results including my doctor's comments. This was so useful and appreciated! Thank You!

When I was at a place that felt like rock bottom I was assigned Emily Pearson-Moase as my primary care mental health nurse. I'd suffered on and off mentally through the years but thought that was just who I was. After a recent episode of destructive and reckless behaviour I found myself in Emily's care. Emily always took my thoughts and feeling seriously, she provided me with a safe space to offload feeling and thoughts I had been battling with. Emily was always there to discuss medication side effects and made me feel heard and respected in terms of adverse side effects. I would have been lost without her when I had my meeting with the psychiatrist, she helped me assemble my thoughts and offered the psychiatrist important information I had left out. Emily is a tremendous asset to the primary care team and was the person I needed at the exact time I needed her. I will forever be grateful to her to getting me to where I am now.

When I was being told all the information, I felt that the staff weren't listening to me and I wasn't being given the best information suited to me at the time. 

I think it would be better to listen instead of pile on the information and all the different options.

When I was first referred from my GP initially I was turned down - An incident the following day triggered my care, however, it could of gone the other way.
I flagged issues regarding my medications towards the end of my care that my prescription was too high - I felt that extra clarity or advice would be helpful when coming off medication.

When I was not well I felt the staff lacked understanding of my situation. They appeared to have no time for me; hostile. As I improved, the situation became easier and relationship with most staff improved also.
When a complaint comes in it needs to be dealt with quickly.
When a therapist leaves make sure you notify the patient and/or find a replacement for anyone they were helping.

When a time is given please the patient gets the maximum of that hour and the exercises are done along with him/her. Avoid asking too many questions and address root cause instead of spending time on documenting. As the patient is in pain and needs remedial therapy.

When arriving on the third floor I was greeted by nurse Cintia who was very friendly and caring. She explained in detail some pre assessments and offered me a tea which was very welcoming. She clearly advised that there may be a slight delay and the reason why.

Additionally everything felt very organised and well structured.

When arriving, Cleveland Clinic was very clean, nice area to sit in with cup of tea before going to the correct floor for my appointment. I arrived and checked in early, paid for my consultation, although there was a slight delay in being seen, I understand that the consultant can over run and have a busy day. However when I went in to see the consultant- he had not been able to look at any of my tests/scan results as they were still downloading. I was surprised by this, as I had spoken to someone a few hours prior to my appointment and went through where I had had my scans, but also the same conversation the week before when confirming my appointment booking. The Doctor was pleasant, however my scan and test results were not seen by the end of the consultation. Also when I asked the Doctor for suggestions/ advice on things that may help my symptoms or make them worse- I was advised to carry on with daily life. I did not find this empathetic as I am unable to carry or with daily life as I had explained already. To then be advised to just do the things I enjoy- to which I re-explained that I can't, hence me going to see the Doctor privately as I did not feel that I can wait until I see the same Doctor via the NHS in November at Queens Square. I was seen on 22/08/23, and today 09/09/23 have still not received any report or communications from the Doctor following my appointment with a summary of the appointment. I have tried to contact his secretary for 2 days as my GP is asking for the report in order to request the further tests that the Doctor advised that I have for before I see him in November.
When being fitted with a cannular for my CT scan in Portland St, one particular technician struggled with this task

When booking the procedure, we specified a particular Doctor.  We received all the documents to confirm this particular Dr was assigned, but when calling to go through the pre op, the nurse mentioned she wasn't sure it would be that Dr and she would have to let us know (and then we were never given a call back to confirm).  

I had to call several times to confirm the bowel prep as the confirmation document explained 1 thing in regards to when to stop eating and the bowel prep doc said another.  Getting through to the correct department for this query was a nightmare every time.  You call the switchboard and they don't have a clue.

Following this procedure, we were told there was no Doctor on file and were given the name of someone we had never heard of so that we could confirm our results would be sent there.  It was my Cleveland Clinic Doctor that transferred me for this procedure!  The administration is quite shocking, not the first time we have had administration issues with The Cleveland.

When calling names could be louder and more clear as was a little difficult to hear the name being called (no hearing issues).
An indication of waiting times would be useful. Waiting room very cold.

When first arriving to the my room after the very kind porter brought us up there was a long period where no one came and introduced themselves or what the plan was for the afternoon. Once I pressed my bell and asked someone came very shortly after.
When moving up a group the level of exercise does not appear much different to the previous level.

When mum was admitted to your hospital she was in a dark place. I was very apprehensive of the path ahead.But in just few weeks you had turn things around, and given me so much needed respite.Thank you for your wonderful care during her stay .

When my appointment was booked I was not given the 15 digit code to setup my video call.  However, when calling the customer service department it was made so simple and reassuring to finalise the details.  Very pleased with the help I received.
When nurse visited she asked [name removed] (patient) if he had long covid and he was upset about this. May be ask the right questions.
When nurses order supplies for catheter please tell us so we know what they are for and to expect a delivery
When people get moved more information should given whether hospital at home.
When starting in the service maybe explain the process a bit more. It is such a scary time
When taking blood pressure the cuff must be of correct size and you need to sit for 5 minutes to get a  accurate reading.
When talking to patients staff could maybe be more aware of body language and how they present to patients who are anxious.

When the survey is completed be able to print out a copy of the answers given. If I had printed out the blank form and filled out manually and then entered in , that would have  worked. Not a big deal!

When the time I walked into the time I left there was a calm and peaceful atmosphere with experienced and friendly staff. My consultant, Daryll Baker, was thorough in reviewing my case and suggesting a way forward

When they asked something to do it they not do it and left patient alone and see next patient they go somewhere else need more to focus on the patient and listen more who wants them.
Other then she is happy here
When they come to me they are always very nice and take an interest in me and take the time to talk to me which I liked I couldn’t ask for any better..
When visit days are moved a call would help as are not using key safe as neighbours have been broken into.

When we were seen, the examination, x-ray and treatment were expeditious. The paramedic we saw (Dan) was really friendly, approachable and apologetic about the wait time. He took his time to talk to my daughter and me and explain everything well to my daughter.

When you have a rigid idea of how people can be treated, and by default blame the patient when it doesn’t work, you’re not actually going to help at all. Staff who have to stick rigidly to a script and may not be qualified in psychotherapies, cannot go off script and design a plan around a patient.
And that’s where the NHS simply gives up until the patient takes action to harm themselves. That’s what has happened to several people I know who all committed suicide when NHS treatments failed for them. And I’m very worried it may happen to me.
When you say you are going to do something please do it. Take in mind the other persons mental health.

When your a patient and not feeling so good you are at your most vulnerable, physically, mentally and emotionally & understandably worried; the team of highly skilled consultants,  fellow doctors, nurses and health care nurse who  looked after me were so kind and critically, made me feel safe. Everyone was outstanding and their complete dedication to deliver exceptional and excellent medical care   was very efficient and they immediately understood the various complications I had & my worry anxiety and concerns. . Between them they were all exceptional. A special thank you to my consultant Mr Nathan, my AAU consultant  Dr Dan Lee and his two fellow doctors, Dr Charlotte and Dr Ben ( sorry I can not remember their surnames ) and to my nurses Ellie, Charlie and the lovely  Klaudia . I am so very much appreciative to you all  and to the catering team and porters who  were so kind and of course the radiology team, led by Heather.. Thank you to you at the the Cleveland Hospital it is an excellent hospital. Your collective  kindness, empathy and  speed and being so thorougher medically was exceptional. Thank you so much.
When your physio want in tell me before I travel. Rather than ignoring me
Whenever I have come to working community I have found the staff to be very pleasant and helpful.
Whenever we have medical related problems, I can call the service to discuss our situation with our Support Nurses.

Where do I begin firstly the place doesnt feel like a hospital more like 5 star hotel. I was here as a day case for a Angiogram. The rooms that you stay in are large and comfortable massive tv comfy bed and chairs rooms and hospital very clean with a new feel too it. ALL staff made you feel welcome and calm as soon as walking through the door. Food is amazing with massive choices for everyone. I wouldnt hesitate in recommending for anyone needing treatment.
Nobody likes going into hospital but this is about as good as it can be I am very nervous person but here I was made and felt very relaxed.
Where possible, advise of time of attendance.

Where to start Sara was so kind and caring and made me feel very relaxed being there and that as a person I counted no matter what. Sara was extremely knowledgeable and helpful, would go that extra mile to be so.

While I understand that psychiatrists are doctors  not therapists, you are dealing with very vulnerable people who need some warmth and better knowledge. To have to Google a common medication shows a lack of experience you wouldn’t expect in someone who has to train so long for this role. There was also a letter of assessment sent with sensitive information that could have been opened by anyone in my family.  I would not want to see this doctor again. He was also very difficult to understand as his English was poor and it made it more difficult to convey the information. It’s great that we are bringing in experts from overseas but they need to be able to communicate well in English.
While I was coming to the reception there were issues with reception staff that was tricky as there was no one to open doors or to ask questions.

While the actual procedure was made as easy as possible, the organisation beforehand could have been better.  Appointments were made for a pre-assessment at the outpatients dept, and blood/COVID tests.  The pre-assessment was very good.  I was given all the information I would need for my stay in hospital, and I had blood tests at the same time.  The following week I returned for a COVID test, which the nurse performed, and unfortunately the results was invalid, so I had to return the next day to repeat it.  Also one of the blood tests had been missed from the original list, so that was done with the second COVID test.  Unfortunately, again, that blood clotted, so I had to return the day before the surgery to have that repeated.  I was travelling from Huntingdon every day, and the possibility that the requisite checks may not be complete by the day of surgery was not reassuring.

Also I was initially told that I needed to be at the hospital at 6.30am on the day of the surgery, and was then phoned to say it had been changed to 10am.  A couple of days before I was phoned again to say it was actually 6.30am. I stayed in a hotel in London overnight the night before the surgery, and considered cancelling this when I thought my admission time was 10am.  If this hadn’t been caught by someone I would have missed my surgery slot.

Whilst Helen is a brilliant SLT and I am very happy with her services, prior to attending a mainstream unit, the assessment, input and advice my son received from the other Speech and Language Therapists in clinic was regrettably not good. Therapy sessions were sparsely recommended and sometimes seemed rushed, advice was very basic and general, there was minimal to no liaison with other professionals working with my son, and there was a serious and concerning lack of continuity of care which prevented any one therapist from truly grasping my son’s abilities  and allowed him to be deprived of the support he needed - rarely did my son ever see the same therapist twice and never did they know what to do with a child who was entitled to their services but not attending a school that was already commissioning them.

Whilst I was very anxious about the investigation and procedure, the staff and facility were excellent at all stages.  I am perhaps buoyed by the positive outcome of the investigation procedure I underwent, but nevertheless found the whole process to be reassuring and of an extremely high standard.

Whilst in the SDEC department condition were abysmal I sat in corridor for at least 24 hrs orherwise it was a chair in the department ,staff were under so much pressure the time and care was nil towards patients it's like a cattle market, at one point we were threatened if we didn't vacate chairs and sit in the corridor on hard plastic chairs we were threatened with security removing us from the department ,including a 90 yr old patient,fortunately that didn't happen .when I eventually went onto the ward SUNRISE A it was a different story staff was helpful and Dr kept me informed at all times I must just stress that whilst in SDEC I was lucky enough to have the privacy of a room and almost past out, the dr allowed me to stay on the bed and I must've nodded off because at this point I had sat on chairs for 24 hrs and I was told I had to leave as beds are not for patient to sleep which is understandable but the manner in which it was executed was not,

Whilst the consultation was fine, I dont think it was necessary. I had had an MRI for my heart which had incidentally identified massing round my thyroid gland. I therefore had an ultrasound test 2 days before my appointment. Whilst this indicated that the massing was benign it identified another small nodule which could be a cause for concern which led to a biopsy being taken of that. I was told that it usually takes 7 days to get results. I asked therefore whether it was sensible to delay my consultation (2 days later) till the results had been obtained. I was told to go ahead with it. I did so but it was really a waste of my time and the consultants, and we have to have another consultation after I get the test results.
I have had another similar experience in relation to my heart where I had to ring up to question the value of an appointment which then led to it being cancelled. I think the clinic could be more proactive in 'managing' appointments
Whilst there was a lot of staff, and no shortage of attention, I felt the service may have been improved had there been a level of seniority inbetween the surgeon and the nurse/s.

Whilst your medical staff and most support workers are most effective your system is way too bureaucratic and full of red tape.  From trying to get an appointment to receiving feed-back on my visits…..it’s a pain in the neck.  While I most certainly will continue with my GP I will look for a smaller more personal office when seeking specialist care.

Even this form is an example of what I am referring to:  you insist that I answer questions that have no relevance to my visit.

Whilst your medical staff and most support workers are most effective your system is way too bureaucratic and full of red tape. From trying to get an appointment to receiving feed-back on my visits…..it’s a pain in the neck.
Whole experience was  very professional but also warm
Whole process easy and straightforward. Staff very welcoming and lovely.

Whole process was very prompt and efficient. Staff were polite and friendly. My cardiologist explained my diagnoses and treatment options in a very plain easy to understand manner. Further tests required were immediately arranged and carried out. Letter summarising consultation  was received the next day. An excellent service leaving me feeling confident I am safe in their care. Thank you.

Wholly professional, kind, supportive and empathetic staff using the most upto date medical technology.  

In short you have the best kit and more importantly the best people, delivering healthcare to me and my wife.  And that is everyone from the wonderful people who open the door and welcome you in to the most senior consultant.

There is telling your staff to care and there is your pateints and customers genuinely believing they do care.  There is a big difference and I believe your team really do care about me and all patients I am sure.  Everyones a VIP!  That's how you are made to feel.  thank you
Wide range of advice regarding various medical conditions.
Will need more mobile help in the not so distant future
Wish I could get to see a Psychiatrist, I know it’s no one’s fault but it takes forever to get meds changed

Wish I was talked to more about my treatment. Talking about treatment plan as soon as something changes. Being involved in decision making process more. Look into making ward environment more neurodivergent friendly. Training on Autism/ADHD for staff to help them understand more.

Wish it was longer as we just got use to it and felt a difference then it finished 
More encouraging when we do as a group and they can help and guide if we do it incorrectly They  said they will send the exercise via email so we can continue at home but I have not received yet.
Wish night staff listened
Wish nurses could stay longer.
